Sophia Anna Bush is an American actress, director, spokesperson, and activist born on July 8, 1982. She is recognized for her roles in films such as John Tucker Must Die (2006), The Hitcher (2007), and The Narrows (2008).

Fox News is a global media holding company that is part of News Corporation, the world's second-largest media conglomerate. Rupert Murdoch is the current chairman and acting CEO of Fox News, as well as the chairman and CEO of News Corporation and its successors, News Corp and 21st Century Fox. James Rupert Jacob Murdoch, the younger son of Rupert Murdoch, is the CEO of 21st Century Fox and chairman of Sky plc.
Gal Gadot was the second highest-earning actress/model in Israel in 2013, behind Bar Refaeli but ahead of Esti Ginzburg and Shlomit Malka, with most of her income coming from acting.
Creedence Clearwater Revival, also known as Creedence or CCR, was an American rock band active in the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Calcaneal spurs are usually identified through an x-ray examination.
The South Wales Coalfield is a coal-rich region in south Wales, particularly in the South Wales Valleys.

The CONCACAF Champions League is an annual football club competition organized by CONCACAF for the top clubs in North America, Central America, and the Caribbean. It was first organized in 1962 as the CONCACAF Champions' Cup.

Mary of Teck became queen mother in 1936 after her husband George's death, but her eldest son Edward abdicated the same year to marry Wallis Simpson. She then supported her second son Albert, who became George VI, until his death in 1952. She died the following year during the reign of her granddaughter Queen Elizabeth II, who had not yet been crowned.
Poseidon grossed $181,674,817 at the worldwide box office on a budget of $160 million.
The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series was first awarded in 1996. Omar Epps and Joe Morton hold the record for the most wins, with three each.

Human trafficking is the trade of humans, primarily for forced labor, sexual slavery, or commercial sexual exploitation. The International Labour Organization (ILO) estimated that forced labor alone generated $150 billion in profits annually as of 2014. Out of the total number of people trafficked, 68% were exploited for labor, 22% were sexually exploited, and 10% were exploited in state-imposed forced labor.
Rio is a 2011 animated film, and its sequel, Rio 2, was released on April 11, 2014.

Francis I, also known as François Étienne or Francis of the Large Nose, was the first King of France from the Angoulême branch of the House of Valois, reigning from 1515 until his death in 1547. He was a key figure in the Italian War of 1536-1538 against Charles V, the King of Spain and Holy Roman Emperor. When his efforts in this conflict proved unsuccessful, he formed a controversial Franco-Ottoman alliance with the Muslim sultan Suleiman the Magnificent.

Peking University, also known as Beida, is a leading research university in Beijing and a member of the C9 League. Established in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking, it replaced the ancient Taixue or Guozijian, which was the Imperial Academy. It also initially served as the highest administration for education in China. Peking University is consistently ranked as the top higher learning institution in mainland China.
Lemmy was known for his appearance, including his friendly mutton chops, his distinctive gravelly voice, and his unique bass playing style.
Global warming has significant effects on humans, including threats to food security due to decreasing crop yields and the abandonment of populated areas caused by rising sea levels.
Australia is a 2008 Australian-American-British romantic historical adventure drama film directed by Baz Luhrmann and starring Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman.
Michael Dwayne Vick, born on June 26, 1980, is a former American football quarterback who played 13 seasons in the NFL, mainly with the Atlanta Falcons and the Philadelphia Eagles.

Canadian folklore encompasses a variety of cultural expressions, including songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather lore, superstitions, and traditional practices like food-making and craft-making. It is primarily transmitted through oral traditions, such as tales, proverbs, and jokes.
The First Motion Picture Unit produced over 400 propaganda and training films that were both informative and entertaining. The unit also produced training films and trained combat cameramen.

James Jones is a notable figure in both literature and basketball. As an author, he won the 1952 National Book Award for his first novel, From Here to Eternity, which was adapted into a film and later a TV series. As a basketball player, he was a high school star, earning Class 6A Player of the Year and First Team All-State honors. In the NBA, he won three championships, two with the Heat and one with the Cavaliers, and reached the NBA Finals seven consecutive times with LeBron James. He also excelled in three-point shooting, finishing third in the NBA in 2007-08 and winning the Three-Point Contest in 2011.
Humphrey Bogart was ranked by the American Film Institute in 1999 as the greatest male star of Classic American cinema.

Computer animation is the process of generating animated images. Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy television series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.
In 2009, Shane McMahon announced his resignation from WWE, which became effective on January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker is an English actor best known for his portrayal of the fourth incarnation of the Doctor in the science fiction series Doctor Who from 1974 to 1981, which is the longest tenure of any actor in the role. He is also recognized for narrating the comedy series Little Britain. In addition to his acting roles, Baker has lent his voice to commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.
Angelsberg is a small town located in the commune of Fischbach, in central Luxembourg.

The Hanford Site is home to a commercial nuclear power plant, the Columbia Generating Station, and several scientific research and development centers, including the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior official who serves as the spokesperson for the executive branch, particularly regarding the President, senior executives, and policies. Appointed by and serving at the pleasure of the President, the position does not require Senate approval. Despite this, it remains a prominent non-Cabinet post due to frequent media briefings that inform the public.

Kentucky, known as the "Bluegrass State," is famous for its fertile soil, horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken. The Bluegrass Region in central Kentucky is home to two major cities, Louisville and Lexington.
Broken Bridges is a 2006 film featuring Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds, and Kelly Preston. Kelly Preston has also appeared in The Cat in the Hat and Old Dogs.
Kesha Rose Sebert, born on March 1, 1987, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper. She was formerly stylized as Ke$ha.
The passage describes the release of two versions of the song "Despacito" on May 5, 2017: an electronic version produced by Major Lazer and MOSKA, and an urban version produced by Sky.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW). It was originally broadcast via closed-circuit television and eventually via pay-per-view television. In 1987, the WWF scheduled a pay-per-view of their own, Survivor Series, on Thanksgiving night and demanded exclusivity from cable providers on carriage of the event. From 1987, Starrcade was broadcast on pay-per-view, the first NWA event to do so. In 2014, the WWE Network included the previous Starrcades (1983-1986), which had been transmitted via closed-circuit television, alongside the rest of the Starrcades in the pay-per-view section, and rated the show as TV-MA due to the amount of violence in the matches, particularly the "I Quit" match between Tully Blanchard and Magnum T.A. Starrcade (1997) was the fifteenth annual Starrcade professional wrestling pay-per-view (PPV) event.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian stunt and action choreographer and film director in Bollywood.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first Star Trek series since Star Trek: Enterprise ended in 2005 and the first series developed specifically for CBS All Access.

Terry Crews played as a defensive end and linebacker in the NFL for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins, as well as in the World League of American Football with Rhein Fire.

Excuse My French is both the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana and a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama, based on Salama's own experiences at a public middle school in Egypt after his return from Saudi Arabia. Additionally, Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew, primarily known as Plan B or Ben Drew, is a British hip hop recording artist, actor, film director, and producer.

A floppy disk, also known as a floppy, diskette, or disk, is a type of disk storage made of a thin and flexible magnetic storage medium enclosed in a rectangular plastic case lined with fabric to remove dust particles.

Guatemala experienced chronic instability and civil strife from the mid to late 19th century. From 1960 to 1996, the country endured a bloody civil war fought between the US-backed government and leftist rebels, including genocidal massacres of the Maya population perpetrated by the military.
Forceps are handheld, hinged instruments used for grasping and holding objects. They are commonly referred to as tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps outside of medicine.
The Closer began its seventh and final season on Monday, July 11, 2011, after finishing its sixth season as cable's highest-rated drama.

Dr. Jack Shephard, played by Matthew Fox, is the protagonist of the ABC television series Lost, which aired from 2004 to 2010 over six seasons and 121 episodes. The first season had an average of 16 million viewers per episode.

Matthew David McConaughey is an American actor born on November 4, 1969. Since 2011, he has focused on dramatic roles in films such as The Lincoln Lawyer, Bernie, Killer Joe, The Paperboy, Mud, Magic Mike, The Wolf of Wall Street, Dallas Buyers Club, Interstellar, The Sea of Trees, and Free State of Jones.

Robert Palmer was a writer, music journalist, and musician. He is best known for his books, including Deep Blues, his music journalism for the New York Times and Rolling Stone magazine, his work producing blues recordings and the soundtrack of the film Deep Blues, and his clarinet playing in the 1960s band the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum (1912-1986) was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer, best known for overseeing the completion of the Mount Rushmore National Memorial after the death of his father, Gutzon Borglum, in 1941. Gutzon Borglum designed and led the project from 1927 until his death, with the assistance of his son, Lincoln Borglum. After Gutzon's passing, Lincoln took over as the leader of the construction project.

The film "Underdog" is directed by Frederik Du Chau and written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. It features a cast including Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, with voice talents provided by Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The 100 is a TV series that follows a group of teenagers, including Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, Octavia Blake, Jasper Jordan, Monty Green, Raven Reyes, Finn Collins, John Murphy, and Wells Jaha, as they return to Earth from a space habitat called "The Ark" after a nuclear apocalypse. The series also focuses on Dr. Abby Griffin, Clarke's mother, Marcus Kane, a council member on the Ark, and Thelonious Jaha, the Chancellor of the Ark and Wells' father.

The Concert for Bangladesh was a pioneering humanitarian aid project that, despite subsequent financial issues, successfully raised awareness and funds while inspiring future initiatives like Live Aid.

Mani Ratnam is a highly influential filmmaker in India, particularly known for his contributions to the Tamil film industry. He is credited with transforming Indian cinema and bringing a new perspective to it.

The Freeport Doctrine was articulated by Stephen A. Douglas during the second of the Lincoln-Douglas debates on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois. The debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic Party candidate. The debates in Freeport, Quincy, and Alton drew especially large numbers of people from neighboring states, as the issue of slavery was of monumental importance to citizens across the nation.

Easy A is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck and written by Bert V. Royal. The film stars Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice is an American author known for her gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. She began her writing career with the publication of Interview with the Vampire in 1976 and continued writing sequels in the 1980s. Although her early works received mixed reactions, she gained popularity with critics and readers in the 1980s. She was married to poet and painter Stan Rice for 41 years until his death from brain cancer in 2002.

Camden is a city in Camden County, New Jersey, with a population of 77,344 according to the 2010 United States Census. It is the 12th most populous municipality in New Jersey. At the beginning of the twentieth century, Camden's population was primarily made up of European immigrants. A city is defined as a large and permanent human settlement.
The Canyons is a 2013 American erotic thriller-drama film directed by Paul Schrader and written by Bret Easton Ellis, who also wrote the screenplay for the critically derided film.

The Lincoln-Douglas Debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic Party candidate. The debates were held in seven towns across Illinois.

Homer is the name attributed by the ancient Greeks to the author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, two epic poems that are the central works of ancient Greek literature. The Thicket is a mystery/suspense novel written by American author Joe R. Lansdale.

Christopher Scott Kyle (April 8, 1974 – February 2, 2013) was a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper. He was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas, on February 2, 2013.

Audioslave was a four-piece band featuring Soundgarden's Chris Cornell and Rage Against the Machine members Tom Morello, Tim Commerford, and Brad Wilk. Brad Wilk, known for his drumming in Rage Against the Machine and Audioslave, began his career with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage in 1991. Currently, he plays in Prophets of Rage with Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991, includes Zack de la Rocha, Tim Commerford, Tom Morello, and Brad Wilk.

Janelle Monáe Robinson is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records. In 2010, she released her critically acclaimed first full-length studio album, The ArchAndroid, a concept album sequel to her first EP, released by Bad Boy Records.
Winter's Tale is a novel written by Mark Helprin in 1983.

Lake Providence is a town and the parish seat of East Carroll Parish in northeastern Louisiana. The University of Mississippi has a diverse student body, with about 55% of undergraduates and 60% overall coming from Mississippi, 23% being minorities, and international students from 90 nations.
The series "Flaked" was renewed for a six-episode second season in July 2016, which is set to premiere on June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr was a prominent figure in New York politics, serving as a U.S. senator and New York State Attorney General. He was elected twice to the New York State Assembly and reached the pinnacle of his career as vice president.

The Soyuz spacecraft, designed by the Korolyov Design Bureau in the 1960s, was initially developed for the Soviet human spaceflight program and the Soviet manned lunar programs. It replaced the Voskhod spacecraft and has been in service ever since. The Soyuz was first launched with 8 unmanned test flights, followed by 19 manned launches.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine broke up in 2000 due to tensions over the band's direction, leading to de la Rocha's departure and a low-key solo career. The remaining members formed the rock supergroup Audioslave with Chris Cornell, which recorded three albums before disbanding in 2007. The same year, Rage Against the Machine announced a reunion and performed at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival. Their fourth studio album, "Renegades," was released on December 5, 2000, by Epic Records.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30 or simply the SENSEX, is a free-float market-weighted stock market index of 30 well-established and financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Tata Motors is listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange, where it is a constituent of the BSE SENSEX index, the National Stock Exchange of India, and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is a Southeast Asian country on the Indochina Peninsula. It is the 14th-most-populous country in the world, with an estimated 92.7 million inhabitants. Vietnam borders China to the north, Laos to the northwest, Cambodia to the southwest, and Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia across the South China Sea. Since 2000, Vietnam has had one of the highest economic growth rates in the world and, in 2011, had the highest Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies. Vietnam remains one of the world's four remaining one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film written and directed by John Gatins in his directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh (23 March 1931) was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary who became a folk hero of the Indian independence movement due to his dramatic acts of violence against the British in India and his execution at the age of 23.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut in the 2016 Indian Hindi-language biographical sports drama film "Dangal," directed by Nitesh Tiwari.

James VI and I, born on June 19, 1566, and died on March 27, 1625, was the King of Scotland as James VI from July 24, 1567, and the King of England and Ireland as James I from the union of the Scottish and English crowns on March 24, 1603, until his death. The kingdoms of Scotland and England were individual sovereign states with their own parliaments, judiciary, and laws, though both were ruled by James in personal union. He was a major advocate of a single parliament for England and Scotland. During his reign in England, James VI and I faced many difficulties with Parliament.

Danielle Cormack is a New Zealand stage and screen actress born on December 26, 1970. She is known for her roles in various television series and films. She was part of the original cast of the soap opera Shortland Street and gained recognition for her portrayal of Amazon Ephiny in Xena: Warrior Princess. Other notable roles include Cynthia Ross in The Cult and Shota in Legend of the Seeker. She has also appeared in the film Separation City and the Australian series Rake. One of her most notable recent works was her portrayal of Bea Smith in the Foxtel prison drama Wentworth, where she starred for four years before leaving the show in 2016.
Rob Sheridan is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer, born on October 11, 1979. He is best known for his extensive work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade is an actor known for his roles in films such as Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, and Grown Ups. He also co-wrote and starred in the 2015 comedy film Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, directed by Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett, born on August 16, 1958, is an American actress.

Artpop, Lady Gaga's second consecutive number-one album in the United States, debuted at the top of the Billboard 200 with 258,000 copies sold in its first week. Despite mixed reviews, it sold 757,000 copies in the U.S. and 2.3 million copies worldwide, making it the ninth best-selling album of 2013.

John Frusciante's fifth and final album with the Chili Peppers, Stadium Arcadium, was released in 2006. It is also the group's last album to feature guitarist John Frusciante, who confirmed his departure from the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, implemented policies known as Thatcherism. She is considered one of the most influential politicians in British history, although debates over Thatcherism continue.
Duff McKagan is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author. He has also written weekly columns for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com on a variety of topics.
Tom Baker is an English actor known for his acting roles and narration work in commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia, officially known as València, is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia and the third-largest city in Spain, with approximately 800,000 residents in the administrative center. It is also Spain's third-largest metropolitan area, with a population between 1.7 and 2.5 million. The Valencian Community, or Valencian Country, is an autonomous community in Spain, with Valencia as its capital.
Buffy Summers was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The series "Make It or Break It" ended on April 26, 2012, with its third season being the final one. The series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is an interdisciplinary subfield of computational linguistics that develops methods and technologies to enable computers to recognize and translate spoken language into text. It involves knowledge and research from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Applications of speech recognition include voice user interfaces, such as voice dialing and call routing, domotic appliance control, search, data entry, preparation of structured documents, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft Direct Voice Input. The field has seen significant advances, evidenced by the adoption of deep learning methods by major industry players such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC.

Richard Alf (1952-2012) was an American businessman and former comic book store owner who co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International and served as its chairman starting in 1970. The convention was initially founded as the Golden State Comic Book Convention in 1970 by a group of San Diegans, including Shel Dorf, Richard Alf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry. It was later renamed the San Diego Comic Book Convention.
The film Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 Fist of Fury, which featured Bruce Lee in the lead role.

France's Dubuisson and South Africa's Van Zyl are tied for the lead at 16 under par, with Rory McIlroy and Kiradech Aphibarnrat close behind at 15 under. McIlroy, aiming for his first title since May, has shot three consecutive 67s, including an eagle on the 12th hole. Despite a few setbacks, including three-putting on the 3rd and 10th holes, McIlroy remains confident in his ability to secure a win. The former world number one is also targeting a third Race to Dubai title in four years, currently leading England's Danny Willett by 271,214 points with three events remaining after the Turkish Open.

Sheikh Ali Salman emphasized the need for meaningful national dialogue in Bahrain, calling for concrete solutions and a representative from the royal family to engage with the opposition. He expressed readiness for dialogue but highlighted divisions within the royal family, with hardliners opposing concessions. Despite skepticism from young protesters, Sheikh Salman advocated working with reformists like Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, who has supported accommodation with the Shia majority. He criticized the UK's private urging of reform and called for public pressure, while also urging the release of opposition leaders and activists to ensure successful dialogue.

Christopher Hogwood, a prominent figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service planned for a later date. Hogwood was a renowned conductor who worked with numerous orchestras worldwide. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and led it for three decades across six continents. The AAM produced over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. His 1980 recording of Handel's Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson is considered one of the top 20 recordings of all time by BBC Music Magazine.

Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge and later with notable musicians like Zuzana Ruzickova and Gustav Leonhardt. He began his career as a keyboard player and musicologist with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and was a founder member of the Early Music Consort of London. He served as the artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, and held academic positions at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell.

Tributes from colleagues and friends highlight his significant contributions to music and his influence on many musicians. Christopher Purvis, honorary president of the AAM, praised his generosity and role as an ambassador for historically informed music. Richard Egarr, AAM's music director, acknowledged Hogwood's legacy. Dame Emma Kirkby and David Thomas from Trinity Laban Conservatoire of Music and Dance remembered him as a natural academic, a genial person, and a proponent of letting music speak for itself.

The number of homicide victims in Scotland fell to 57 in 2015-16, the lowest in 40 years. Sharp instruments, mainly knives, were involved in 51% of cases. While most accused had unknown alcohol or drug status, 31% were under the influence. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson emphasized the need for continued efforts in education, enforcement, and support services. However, Scottish Labour's Claire Baker cautioned against over-optimism, pointing to revised figures from the previous year and rising sexual and violent crime rates.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland, becoming the first team to lose to the Black Cats in the Premier League this season. Despite scoring first with a goal from Dan Gosling, Bournemouth was unable to find an equalizer after Sunderland's Victor Anichebe and Jermain Defoe scored. Bournemouth manager Eddie Howe expressed frustration with the team's lack of scoring, despite creating enough chances to win multiple games. Howe emphasized the importance of moving on from the loss and focusing on future games.

Australia detains migrants trying to reach its shores by boat and takes them to offshore processing camps to be eventually resettled elsewhere. Mr Abbott told Australian media that the only way to prevent people from dying at sea was to "stop the boats." The New York Times described the policy as "brutal" in an editorial, saying the "ruthlessly effective" policy was "inhumane, of dubious legality and strikingly at odds with the country's tradition of welcoming people fleeing persecution and war." Mr Abbott said the image of Syrian three-year-old Alan Kurdi, who died trying to reach Greece by boat with his family, was "very sad." He said, "If you want to stop the deaths, if you want to stop the drownings you have got to stop the boats."

On Thursday, Mr Abbott angered Australian Jewish groups by saying the so-called Islamic State (IS), from which many of the migrants to Europe are fleeing, was worse than the Nazis. He said, "The Nazis did terrible evil, but they had a sufficient sense of shame to try to hide it. But IS militants, he said, "boast about their evil, this is the extraordinary thing." The Executive Council of Australian Jewry Robert Goot said the comment was "injudicious and unfortunate," saying there was "a fundamental difference between organized acts of terrorism and a genocide systematically implemented by a state as essential policy." Mr Abbott later said he stood by his comments but that he was not in the "business of ranking evil."

The United States has suspended bilateral talks with Russia regarding the cessation of hostilities in Syria, citing Russia's failure to adhere to its commitments and its military actions in Aleppo. The US accuses Russia and the Syrian government of targeting critical infrastructure, including hospitals, and preventing humanitarian aid from reaching civilians. Russia, in turn, expresses regret over the US decision and accuses Washington of failing to fulfill its own obligations and shifting blame. The suspension of talks comes amid intensified attacks on Aleppo, where hundreds have died, and 250,000 people remain trapped. Both sides will continue discussions on counter-terrorism operations to avoid clashes.

The Policy Exchange proposed selling high-value social homes when they become vacant to raise £4.5 billion annually, potentially funding 80,000 to 170,000 new social homes. This initiative aims to reduce the social housing waiting list by 500,000 and create the largest social housing program since the 1970s. Critics, including Labour and the National Housing Federation, argue this would force low-income families out of affluent areas, creating segregated communities. Labour suggests using a bank bonus tax to fund affordable housing instead. The government supports councils using social housing efficiently and has invested £19.5 billion in affordable housing, aiming to deliver up to 170,000 homes.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, a 25-year-old from Swansea, died last week at his home, amidst an ongoing measles epidemic in the city. While laboratory tests confirmed a diagnosis of measles, further tests are required to determine the exact cause of death. Mr. Colfer-Williams had recently been treated for asthma at Swansea's Morriston Hospital and developed a rash a few days after being discharged. He visited an out-of-hours GP with a rash covering his body, except for his arms, and was found dead the following morning. Public Health Wales is conducting additional tests to establish the cause of death. The family is unaware of how Mr. Colfer-Williams contracted measles, as no close family members, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter, have the disease.

Vincent Hudson, 54, of Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offense involving a boy under the age of 16. The attack reportedly took place in 2001, and Mr. Hudson is due to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

The match between Gateshead and Guiseley ended in a 1-1 draw. Guiseley took the lead in the 15th minute with a goal from Jake Lawlor. Gateshead equalized in the 62nd minute with a goal from Wes York. Both teams made substitutions during the match, and there were a few yellow cards shown. The match was described as a promotion-chasing match for both teams.

Bristol Sport Ltd, the owner of the football club, plans to replace two stands to increase capacity, as an alternative to building a new stadium at nearby Ashton Vale, which has been delayed by a town green application. The majority shareholder, Steve Lansdown, confirmed the redevelopment plans at a shareholder meeting on Tuesday, which were approved by Bristol City Council in November. Lansdown stated that the section 106 agreement would be signed soon, and if there is no judicial review by March, the redevelopment plans will begin in May.

Cuadrilla, the firm conducting shale gas drilling (fracking) in Lancashire, has suspended operations following a 1.5 magnitude tremor on Friday, the second in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) noted that both tremors shared a "similar location and mechanism." Fracking involves shattering hard shale rocks underground to release gas, a process that can cause earthquakes. Environmental concerns have been raised, particularly in the US, where shale gas leakage into drinking water has been alleged. However, the Commons energy select committee has called for support for fracking in the UK, arguing that environmental issues can be mitigated with tight regulation and good industry practice. The BGS is monitoring the situation and has stated that injecting pressurized water into rocks at depth, as done in fracking, can cause earthquakes.

Ipswich Town secured a 3-0 victory over Queens Park Rangers, with goals from Grant Ward, Luke Varney, and Tom Lawrence. Ipswich's win, which included a miscue by QPR's goalkeeper Alex Smithies, lifted them to 14th place, above QPR in the standings. Despite a late effort by QPR's Sandro, Ipswich dominated the match, with several near misses and a strong defensive performance. Both managers reflected on the game, with Ipswich's Mick McCarthy praising his team's performance and QPR's Ian Holloway emphasizing the need for mental toughness and improvement.

Wells, 23, had a strong performance in the T20 Blast last season, scoring 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66. He expressed excitement about the club's positive direction and praised the elite performance environment created by the coaches, which is motivating the players to be a part of it.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured their second consecutive win by defeating third-placed Chinnor 29-12. Coach Churcher praised the performance of the front row and front five, who made over 70 tackles in the game. Despite the win, Churcher believes there is still room for improvement and emphasized the importance of building on last weekend's performance. The Reds will face seven teams below them in the table in their next eight games, as well as league leaders Old Elthamians.

The police have arrested a 28-year-old Bangladeshi citizen, Nazrul, also known as Nazu, at a railway station in Kolkata (Calcutta) for the alleged rape of a 74-year-old nun. This marks the sixth arrest in the case, with eight suspects identified, two of whom remain untraced. The incident, which occurred on March 14 in Ranaghat town, involved the ransacking of a convent school, theft of money, and the rape of the nun. The police acted on a tip-off that Nazu, who had fled to Bangladesh after being identified from CCTV footage of the attack, was due to return to Kolkata by train. The earlier five arrested suspects have all named Nazu as the person who raped the nun. In May, the police arrested Milon Sarkar, described as the leader of the gang involved in the attack, though his specific role remains unclear. The incident has caused outrage in India, leading to street protests in many cities across the country.

The interactive video features Robert Opie discussing how various factors like the domestic freezer, washing powder, and cheaper imports have influenced UK consumer preferences. It also highlights changes in ownership and rankings of major UK brands. A non-interactive version of the content is available for users with older browsers, along with links to additional resources on topics such as freezing food and brand rankings.

Two incidents of fraud involving callers claiming to be from BT have been reported. In the first incident, a 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills was tricked on September 15th. The second incident occurred a week later in Stranraer, where a woman lost money to a caller who gained remote access to her computer. PC Siobhan Pellett warned the public to be cautious of cold calls and never give out banking details over the phone, as reputable businesses never ask for such information.

Duffy, 37, has signed a one-year contract with Featherstone, the third-placed Championship side, after leaving Swinton Lions. He will lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse on Saturday before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Mark Campbell, the chairman, expressed excitement about Duffy's appointment, praising his remarkable job at Swinton despite difficult circumstances. Duffy, who played for Leigh, Widnes, and Salford during his 16-year playing career, has been replaced by his former assistant Stuart Littler at Swinton.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew with a medic and a coastguard search and rescue helicopter were dispatched to Sker Beach, near Kenfig Nature Reserve, at 12:50 GMT on Sunday. A rider with head injuries and hypothermia from lying unconscious on wet sand was treated and flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

The UN's International Telecommunication Union (ITU) has decided to dedicate a radio frequency for satellite tracking of planes, enabling real-time tracking anywhere in the world. This decision, made at the World Radiocommunication Conference (WRC) in Geneva, comes in response to the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 in March 2014. The current ground-based radar system leaves about 70% of the world's airspace uncovered. The new system will allow satellites to receive automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) transmissions from aircraft, improving global flight tracking. The UN's aviation arm, the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO), has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines, including aircraft sending their position at least every 15 minutes or more in case of emergency.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at the age of five in 2002, has been found living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez, 53, was arrested and is being held at the Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio with a $250,000 bail. He is charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver's license in 2012. The FBI, Alabama police, and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children confirmed Julian's identity after receiving a tip on October 30. Julian's mother has been notified of his recovery. Authorities suspected Bobby Hernandez of being involved in his son's disappearance at the time.

Firefighters spent several days at the site in Duncan Street following the blaze on 2 March, which reduced train services and caused travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the fire. The firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, the fire service said. Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited, whose site was run by Asset and Land Group, could not be contacted for a comment. It has until 7 August to appeal the decision. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) visited the premises nine times in the last 12 months. Geoff Harris, GMFRS area manager, said: "The site operators, Asset and Land, have been broadly compliant with fire safety legislation throughout that time." The fire service raised concerns to the EA in February over the impact a fire could have on nearby residents, transport and the environment. "The EA were very interested in our concerns, which resulted in our fire safety officers conducting joint visits to the site with EA staff, the EA decided to take enforcement action against the site operators," Mr Harris said. An EA spokesman said: "After consideration of all the facts relating to the company and the site, the EA has now decided to revoke the environmental permit. "Subject to any appeal, the revocation takes effect on 7 August, which means after that date the company will no longer be able to operate from that site. The company is still required to remove all the waste." The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

The pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia has proposed two bills in response to the crisis in Ukraine, particularly focusing on the Crimea region. The first bill suggests that a referendum or a plea from a territory's leaders could be sufficient to allow a territory to become part of the Russian Federation, bypassing the current requirement for a treaty with the neighboring state. This is particularly relevant given the strong pro-Russian sentiments in Crimea, where many residents already hold Russian passports. The second bill aims to expedite the process for issuing Russian passports to Ukrainians, particularly Russian-speaking individuals, by removing several requirements such as state tax, previous residence in Russia, and sufficient funds. This would allow Ukrainians to apply for Russian citizenship more quickly and easily. The preamble of the bill references the need to support Ukrainians, particularly Russian-speaking ones, against perceived threats. The proposed legislation is seen as a response to the ongoing crisis and the perceived disintegration of the Ukrainian state.

McLaren's F1 history has been a cycle of triumph and decline. They have won 182 grands prix, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles. Despite their current struggles, they have two world champions in the cockpit, including Fernando Alonso. The slump started in 2013 due to chassis design issues, and now the problems lie with the Honda power unit. McLaren's greatest successes were with Honda in the late 1980s and early 1990s. They have had periods of success followed by dips in form. The team is currently in a difficult period, but they believe they are on the path to recovery and future success.

Thomas Baker, a 44-year-old man from Everton, was shot in the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on January 27. He later died in the hospital. Three men from Liverpool, aged 29 and 32, have been arrested and are being questioned by the police. Detectives believe that the suspects had been waiting outside the Phoenix Gym at the market for about an hour before the shooting. The police are searching for a silver VW Polo that left the scene at high speed and traveled along several roads. They are also appealing to people captured on CCTV near the market to come forward, as they may have information that could be crucial to the investigation.

The passage discusses various ways to celebrate Christmas online, blending tradition with modern technology. It highlights Everyday Church Online, which streams virtual services and features a Star Wars-themed Christmas sermon called "The Hope Awakens." Another example is the game Guardians of Ancora, aimed at children, where players rediscover Bible stories to bring light to a fictional world, with special Christmas quests about the birth of Jesus. The passage also mentions creative nativity videos, such as The Digital Story of Nativity, which tells the story through social media posts, and Christmas Starts with a Baby's Giggle, which transitions from a modern setting to the traditional nativity scene. Additionally, it discusses the Manga Messiah, a Bible-based comic book available in multiple languages, including Arabic for refugees. Finally, it touches on the use of social media by churches and Christian groups to share spiritual messages during the holiday season.

The eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is examining a request to take over 250 hectares of common land for development. Backers, including Blaenau Gwent council, have offered around 320 hectares of replacement land. Experts have presented conflicting accounts regarding the potential damage to habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales stated that it was "difficult to conclude" that the replacement land was of equal value but did not oppose the development overall. The developers' ecology report claimed a "net gain" in biodiversity due to plans to enhance nearby habitats, which the Gwent Wildlife Trust disputed. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation, and Welsh government ministers will have the final say on whether the plans can proceed.

Chechen Muslim clerics, in response to a report by Novaya Gazeta, called for "retribution" against the journalists, accusing them of insulting their faith and the dignity of Chechen men. The report, published on 1 April, alleged that over 100 people had been detained in Chechnya on suspicion of being homosexual, with at least three killed. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report and stated that detainees were tortured. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations. The LGBT Network is helping victims flee Chechnya and plans to file a case with the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to prosecute the perpetrators.

Investing Solutions, a lettings agency, and Fresh Start Housing, a charity, have been working together to house single homeless men in London. The agency claims housing benefits for each tenant, which is higher than the rent paid to landlords, making the venture profitable. The agency has received over £2.1m from Wandsworth Council in the past two years. However, tenants have reported poor living conditions, including lack of heating and hot water, rats, and damp. The agency and charity deny any illegal activity, but a homeless group has criticized their relationship. The Department for Communities and Local Government has stated that local authorities are responsible for safeguarding taxpayers' money in the private rented sector.

In a warm-up match before the Eurobasket qualifiers, Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and NBA player Ben Gordon added 13 for Great Britain. GB led for most of the first three quarters, but the Dutch, led by Worthy De Jong's 18 points, took the lead in the third quarter and held on to win despite a late GB comeback. GB coach Joe Prunty emphasized the importance of completing every play and maintaining intensity on both ends of the floor. He also praised Gordon's performance, particularly his strong stretch in the third quarter.

The Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) is set to debate a request from Conor McGregor and Floyd Mayweather to use 8oz gloves for their upcoming bout, which is set to take place at 154 lbs. NAC rules state that fights at this weight require 10oz gloves, but lighter gloves can be used if waivers are signed and the NAC feels the move is justified. The NAC will debate the matter publicly before announcing its decision.

McGregor, who will make his boxing debut in what could be the richest fight in history, has used 4oz gloves during his UFC career. He welcomed Mayweather's Instagram post last week, stating that he is coming sprinting at Mayweather with bricks. Mayweather, who will come out of retirement for the bout, had not submitted a necessary waiver document at the time of his Instagram post.

The NAC executive director, Bob Bennett, has stated that the health and safety of the fighters is the number one policy and that to deviate from the regulations at a difference of 7lbs would be for the chairman and commissioners to determine. Bennett has also stated that there were several reasons to approve the fight, including McGregor's UFC rival Nate Diaz's performance against him in the past.

Since sanctioning the fight, Bennett has had access to three videos showing McGregor's progress and has advised McGregor's camp to employ a boxing referee to feel comfortable with the rules. This led to the hiring of Hall of Fame official Joe Cortez, who oversaw an "out of control" sparring session between McGregor and Paulie Malignaggi. Malignaggi has since left the camp after reacting angrily to images of him on the canvas during a sparring session.

Fleet Street, once the heart of British journalism, is losing its last two journalists as the Dundee-based Sunday Post closes its London office. For decades, it was synonymous with the nation's biggest newspapers, with nearly every national paper and several provincial newspapers having offices within a half-mile radius. The first British daily newspaper, the Daily Courant, was published there on 11 March 1702. At its height, Fleet Street was the pinnacle of a journalist's career, known for its many bars and pubs constantly occupied by journalists both socializing and seeking stories. However, the street's grip on power began to crumble as media tycoon Rupert Murdoch moved his papers to a purpose-built complex at Wapping in east London in 1986, leading to a bitter, year-long dispute that ended in defeat for the unions. By 1988, most national newspapers had moved away from Fleet Street to other parts of London, adopting new, cheaper computerized printing technology. The buildings they left behind gradually morphed into other uses, marking the end of an infamous era of British history.

J.K. Rowling faced criticism on Twitter after donating £1 million to the campaign for a No vote in the Scottish independence referendum. She revealed that she had been called a traitor for her political views and had blocked some abusive Twitter users she believed were supporters of the Scottish National Party (SNP). Rowling also mentioned that she had responded to other nice SNP supporters and discussed how much she had in common politically with many of them. The SNP won 56 of the 59 seats in Scotland in Thursday's election and is now the third-largest party in the UK.

The study by the University of Edinburgh found that children from deprived backgrounds were twice as likely to face police action than better-off children who commit the same crime. Living in poverty increased the likelihood of violence among both boys and girls. The study also found that a history of being in trouble with the police was the strongest predictor of whether a young person was not in education, employment, or training by the age of 18. Poorer young people were about five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision than their better-off counterparts. Household poverty was identified as an exacerbating factor that increased the likelihood of young people offending. People who lived in extreme poverty were much more likely to be the victims and perpetrators of crime. Gender was also identified as one of the most powerful predictors of violence, with boys being three times more likely than girls on average to engage in violent acts. Girls from poorer backgrounds were twice as likely as girls from more affluent households to be involved in violent crime. The study tracked 4,300 young people in Edinburgh since 1998 to better understand changes in their behavior and lifestyles. The study was funded by the Economic and Social Research Council, the Nuffield Foundation, and the Scottish government. The study's findings highlight a destructive dynamic where poverty increases the risks of violence, and contact with the juvenile justice system increases the risks associated with poverty. The study also found that the recent fall in crime rates in Scotland has not benefitted areas with the most chronic rates of crime. The findings suggest that crime tends to be highly concentrated amongst poor people and within poor neighborhoods, and this has not changed despite crime being at its lowest level for decades. The Scottish government has a long-standing record of protecting the poorest and most vulnerable in society and is tackling poverty and inequalities head-on through a number of initiatives, including a £296m investment to limit the damaging effects of the UK government's welfare cuts.

Karl Haugh, 25, was fatally stabbed in a laneway in the Marian estate in the early hours of Sunday. Robbie Walsh, of Island View, Kilrush, has been charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr. Haugh and has been remanded in custody until August 14. Two other men arrested in connection with the killing were released without charge, and files are being prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions. At Ennis District Court on Tuesday, Det Sgt Padraig Frawley stated that it will be alleged that Mr. Walsh was one of three people who entered the Marian Estate in Kilkee shortly after 01:00 on Sunday and called to houses in the estate looking for Mr. Haugh. It will be further alleged that while in the estate, the accused and the two males came across Mr. Haugh and another man, and a fight ensued where weapons were used. During the altercation, Mr. Haugh received a stab wound to his back. Garda arrived at the scene where knives and golf clubs were recovered. Mr. Haugh was brought by ambulance to Limerick University Hospital, where he was pronounced dead at 06:00 local time. Police recovered a knife handle and a blade at the scene of Mr. Haugh's death, and the blade had blood on it. A judge said the state had given evidence of tension in the area of Kilkee as a result of the killing.

Phil Flanagan, a Fermanagh MLA, tweeted in May 2014 questioning if Tom Elliott, a former UDR member and current MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, would reveal how many people he harassed and shot during his service. The tweet was deleted within an hour, and Flanagan issued an apology stating that his comments were untrue. The High Court reserved judgment on compensation, and the insurance firm covering MLAs at Stormont refused to cover Flanagan. Elliott expressed disappointment in the time taken to resolve the matter but was pleased with the outcome.

Hawick Knitwear, a company established in 1874 and now managed by Benny Hartop, has increased its production to meet rising demand. The company, which employs over 230 staff, has seen a boost in sales of its new Hawick Knitwear-branded range launched in January, as well as growth in its established private label business. Production has increased to 9,500 sweaters per week, up from 7,500 last year, in response to a surge in orders from both domestic and international markets. Hawick Knitwear sells its products in several European countries and also in the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. The company's success is attributed to the dedication of its staff, and Mr. Hartop is optimistic about its future.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by a car driven by Brian Wright, 55, outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright, who denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, told Luton Crown Court that he was blinded by the setting sun and could not remember if the traffic lights were red or green. The court heard that Wright's VW Golf failed to stop for a red light, hitting Blackburn as she was escorting a woman and her six-year-old daughter across the road. Wright expressed remorse for the incident, saying he has thought of nothing else since it happened. The trial continues.

The passage discusses a NATO anti-submarine warfare exercise named "Dynamic Mongoose," highlighting the growing concern over Russian submarine activity. The exercise involves 10 NATO warships, including the USS Vicksburg and the Royal Navy Frigate HMS Portland, searching for a German U-boat, U33, which is acting as the unseen enemy. The U33's mission is to avoid detection and attempt to take out the command ship, the USS Vicksburg, and an oil tanker.

The exercise underscores the difficulty of locating submarines in vast ocean areas, likened to looking for a needle in a haystack. It also points out the technological advancements and challenges in anti-submarine warfare, including the use of sonar, sensors, and underwater drones. The importance of long-range maritime patrol aircraft in these operations is emphasized, with a mention of Britain's lack of such aircraft, which is seen as a significant vulnerability.

The passage concludes by stating that the exercise is a reminder that some nations, including Britain, cannot conduct anti-submarine warfare alone and that the UK's lack of maritime patrol aircraft will need to be addressed in the government's forthcoming defense and security review.

The passage describes the escalating violence and humanitarian crisis in South Sudan, focusing on the ethnic targeting and mass displacement of civilians. Over 340,000 people, many of them children, have fled to Uganda, making it the largest recipient of refugees this year. The violence, initially a power struggle between Dinka and Nuer tribes, has now spread to Equatorians, leading to widespread atrocities such as killings, rapes, and ethnic targeting. Refugees recount harrowing experiences of survival and loss, while Uganda struggles to accommodate the influx despite its welcoming policies. The international community is urged to intervene as the crisis worsens.

McKenzie, 38, will fight Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship at York Hall on 12 November. He became a professional boxer in 2013 after quitting football two years earlier. McKenzie has a record of eight wins and one draw from his nine fights. He is the son of former British and European champion Clinton and is trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The coalition is investing £330 million in new NHS facilities across England, including £33 million for a new Bridgwater Community Hospital. The current hospital, built in 1813, is outdated and cramped. The new hospital will have 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and space for mobile scanners. It will be built on land at Bowers Lane, pending planning permission, and is expected to be completed by autumn 2014. The remaining balance will be paid for by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust.

A man was fatally shot in the chest outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near the city center. The victim was either in or near a black Mercedes he had been driving. Armed police sealed off the area, and the victim was taken to Northern General Hospital but died from his injuries. Local residents said the man was a member of a family who live close to the scene of the shooting and that relatives had been gathering for a family celebration when the attack occurred. There have been several shootings in Sheffield in recent weeks, although all previous incidents have been in the north of the city and not near Upperthorpe.

The passage discusses the activities of hacker groups involved in the Ukrainian conflict. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, conduct cyberattacks against Russian and separatist targets, including DDoS attacks, hacking CCTV systems, and disrupting electronic payment accounts. They claim to have uncovered evidence of Russian military involvement in Ukraine. On the opposing side, Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, targets Ukrainian government websites and electronic systems, aiming to disrupt military plans and spread anti-government propaganda. They have also leaked documents and made unverified claims about the downing of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17. Additionally, Anonymous International, also known as b0ltai or Shaltay Boltay, leaks documents from the Kremlin, focusing on Russia's domestic affairs and occasionally covering Ukraine. The group's methods and sources are unclear.

Tricia Marwick, the presiding officer, was moved to tears as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond bid farewell to the Scottish Parliament ahead of the election on May 5. McNeil, who has served since the parliament's establishment in 1999, warned that Holyrood could learn from Westminster, particularly regarding the committee system. He emphasized the need for accountability, scrutiny, and opposition. Salmond, who served as First Minister from 2007 to 2014, reiterated his belief that Scotland was "not divided, but diverse" and welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood under the Scotland Bill, though he insisted it did not fulfill the pledges made by unionist politicians during the referendum campaign. He concluded his address by expressing that there was no greater honor than being a member of the Scottish Parliament and serving the people of Scotland. Annabel Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative MSP, also bid farewell, joking about her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She will gather evidence from pensioners, their friends, and families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will highlight both good and poor care and its impact on older people. The commissioner will assess factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Care providers, social care staff, and public bodies will also be consulted. The chair of Care Forum Wales, Mario Kreft, expressed support for the review but criticized the lack of a provider expert on the advisory panel.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, saw a pre-tax profit increase of £800,000 to £3.5m in the year to the end of June 2016, despite a £1m drop in turnover to just over £100m. The company, which manufactures and supplies feed for the beef, sheep, dairy, pig, and poultry sectors, also operates a network of 19 shops across Scotland under the Country Store brand. International sales grew over the year, both in Europe and in new markets further afield. In accounts filed with Companies House, the company acknowledged the challenges faced by the agriculture industry but expressed confidence in being well-positioned for whatever business challenges Brexit may bring.

The body of a man in his 70s was found at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon. A man in his 80s was also taken to hospital. Detectives want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, and have warned people not to approach him. He is described as white, about 6ft (1.8m) tall, with straight, greying, collar-length hair and of average build. He is believed to have been wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers and a dark blue, light blue and white checked short-sleeved shirt with a button-down collar. Anyone with information has been urged to contact police or Crimestoppers. Officers have been conducting additional patrols in the area to provide reassurance to residents.

The IMF's latest assessment of the global economy indicates a weakening baseline, with a likely downgrade of its current forecast of 3.4% for global growth in April. This comes after weaker-than-expected trade figures from China, showing a 25% plunge in exports from a year ago. The IMF's comments highlight the delicate juncture of the global economy and the ongoing ramifications for businesses and industries that have bet on China's growth story.

The council leader, Dave Stewart, announced that the Cowes crossing would be free until July 2 to allow for feedback and in recognition of the problems surrounding the new ferry. The council has also ordered a review of the project by auditors. The ferry has faced several issues since its launch, including breakdowns, running aground, and being suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training issues. Cars have also been damaged while getting on and off the ferry. Shopkeeper Angie Booth expressed concerns about the impact on local businesses and asked about compensation. Transport councillor Ian Ward stated that compensation was up for discussion and addressed the issues, attributing them to teething problems and rectifiable issues.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday, resulting in the death of a 32-year-old man at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until the early evening for investigation.

Matching Models, an international temp agency based in London, has faced criticism for its job advertisements that specify physical appearance, such as requesting a personal assistant with "a classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup." The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) has called these ads "appalling, unlawful, and demeaning to women," and has asked the agency to clarify its hiring practices. Women's equality campaigners have also criticized the ads, with Sam Smethers, chief executive of the Fawcett Society, stating that they are "straight out of the 1970s" and likely violate equality legislation.

The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended the ads, stating that "looks are important" to their clients. She cited specific client requests, such as a businessman wanting a "sexy female driver" and an Indian businessman requesting a blonde, blue-eyed, Greek woman. Jansen also mentioned that MTV wanted models with tattoos and piercings.

Employment lawyer James Lynas has stated that the ads are "clearly unlawful" and that anyone can complain to the EHRC, which has the power to intervene. He also mentioned that an employment tribunal could find the use of phrases like "beautiful and attractive" as discriminatory against older women.

The 2010 Equality Act prohibits employers from discriminating against candidates based on various factors, including age, sexual orientation, marital status, number of children, disability, race, and religion. Employers must also be able to demonstrate that specifying clothing sizes is essential to the nature or context of the work.

The shooting occurred at a hostel attached to the private Pragati Residential School in Bangalore city. The alleged gunman, Mahesh, was an office assistant at the school. He is accused of shooting 18-year-old Gautami in the head with a pistol and severely injuring another student, Sirisha. Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt and has been remanded until April 12th. Gun crime at schools and colleges in India is rare, although firearms are often used to settle feuds. In 2007, a 14-year-old schoolboy was shot dead by two fellow students at a school near Delhi.

Glaad's Where We Are on TV study analyzed shows airing between June 2016 and May 2017, finding 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, including 16 transgender characters, up from seven the previous year. However, over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters, such as Poussey Washington and Bea Smith, were killed off, often violently. The study also noted a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, attributed to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's president, Sarah Kate Ellis, acknowledged progress but emphasized that numbers alone do not tell the whole story.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, has announced his decision to step down ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed. This comes after criticism over a £10.25m loan to Northampton Town FC from the borough council, which he led, to rebuild Sixfields stadium and develop nearby land. A significant portion of this money is now missing and is under police investigation for alleged financial irregularities. The majority of his party's local executive council had indicated they would vote to deselect him. Mackintosh, who had previously intended to stand for re-election, stated that it is the right time for his constituents to have a new representative.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old police officer, was charged with murder and four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon by a public official after firing a rifle into a car full of teenagers, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards. The incident occurred in April in Balch Springs, a Dallas suburb, when police responded to reports of underage drinking at a house party. Officers initially claimed the car reversed "aggressively" towards the officer, but footage showed the car driving away from him. Oliver was fired a few days later for policy violations. He is currently free on bail and faces five to 99 years in prison if convicted. The Dallas County District Attorney's office is proceeding with the case, and if Oliver is convicted, he would be the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas County since 1973.

The passage discusses the upcoming move of the Trump family to the White House, focusing on the decision of Melania Trump and her son Barron to delay their relocation. It highlights the historical context of First Ladies and their roles, noting that only two other First Ladies in U.S. history have not lived in the White House during their husbands' presidencies. The text also explores the public's reaction to Melania's decision, with some criticizing it and others supporting it. Additionally, it provides insights into the roles and responsibilities of First Ladies throughout history, including their public duties and personal priorities. The passage concludes by mentioning the potential involvement of Ivanka Trump in fulfilling some of the First Lady's duties.

The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, has been tasked with investigating the initial police response to a call from a 72-year-old man who was later found dead at a sheltered housing complex in Inverness on 27 October. Police Scotland stated that they are "fully engaging" with the investigation and await its findings. A report on the commissioner's findings will be submitted to the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) in due course.

The passage describes a yellow wind warning issued for several counties in Wales, with gusts of up to 75 mph expected, particularly in the west of the mountains. The winds are coming from an unusual easterly direction, which could add to their impact. Disruption to travel on roads and at sea is likely, and a tree has already fallen in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing one of the main routes into the town. The council has stated that the road is expected to remain closed for most of Monday to allow for clean-up work.

The Giants took an early lead with a goal from player-coach Derrick Walser, but the Panthers quickly equalized with a goal from Jeff Dimmen. In the second period, Mike Forney scored a powerplay breakaway goal to give the Giants the lead again, but Andy Bohmback equalized for the Panthers. Mike Radja then scored from an acute angle, and James Desmarais extended the lead to 4-2 before David Ling scored a late goal for the Panthers. The two teams will meet again on Saturday night in the second match of their double-header. Nottingham currently leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 points and Belfast with 25 points.

The Chinese Grand Prix was marked by a chaotic start, with multiple collisions on the first lap. Sebastian Vettel of Ferrari finished second despite a first-lap collision with teammate Kimi Raikkonen, who fought back to fifth place. Lewis Hamilton, starting from the back, faced numerous challenges, including a broken front wing and five pit stops, ultimately finishing in a lower position. The race was significantly influenced by the safety car's introduction on lap four due to the opening-lap incidents. Vettel and Raikkonen's recovery efforts were notable, with Raikkonen passing Hamilton in the closing stages. Hamilton, despite his efforts, struggled with car damage and faces a significant points deficit to Nico Rosberg in the championship race.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a former German footballer, has become the most prominent player to publicly reveal his homosexuality. His announcement has been met with widespread support from former teammates, football administrators, and public figures. Hitzlsperger's decision is seen as a significant step in addressing homophobia in German football, a topic that has been largely ignored.

Sidwell, 34, has played a key role in Brighton's promotion to the Premier League, making 32 Championship appearances this season. With his contract set to expire, he hopes to sign a new deal and contribute to Brighton's success in the top flight. Sidwell believes he has exceeded expectations and deserves the opportunity to play in the Premier League again. Brighton's recent win over Wigan secured their promotion, and they are now aiming to win the league title in their final two matches.

Blackpool and Colchester United played to a 1-1 draw in a match marked by missed opportunities and dramatic saves. Blackpool took the lead in the 12th minute with a goal from Jamille Matt, assisted by Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalized in the 17th minute through Kurtis Guthrie after a goalmouth scramble. Both teams had chances to win, with Blackpool's Tom Aldred missing a crucial header and Colchester's George Elokobi and Guthrie coming close in the first half. The match ended with Colchester down to 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle in injury time.

The 29-year-old Reid, who has previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season as they were relegated from League One. He could make his debut for Colchester in Wednesday's EFL Cup first-round tie against Championship side Aston Villa. Colchester started the season with a 3-1 defeat at Accrington on Saturday.

The UK Police Memorial Trust is appealing for £1.5 million to construct a permanent memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire, to honor the courage and sacrifice of police officers and staff who have lost their lives over the past 250 years. The memorial will bear the names of more than 1,400 officers and staff and will include a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out and given to the families of fallen officers as a personal memorial. The government has committed £1 million towards the £4 million needed for the memorial, which is expected to be completed by 2019. The memorial was prompted by the murder of PC Keith Palmer in an attack outside the Houses of Parliament in March, which highlighted the need for a place where the nation can honor and commemorate the police service and where family, friends, and colleagues of those killed on duty can carry out personal acts of remembrance.

Manchester United remains 15 points clear at the top of the Premier League table with eight games left after a 1-0 win at Sunderland. Manager Alex Ferguson emphasized the team's focus on upcoming games rather than past achievements. United has won 25 of their first 30 matches and is aiming to surpass Chelsea's record 95-point haul from 2005. Ferguson plans to make changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea due to injuries sustained in the Sunderland match. Despite a tough second half, United's determined defending and courage secured the win.

Google's chairman, Mr. Schmidt, defended the company's tax practices, stating that they comply with legal requirements and pay the taxes mandated by law. He emphasized that it is the government's responsibility to change tax laws if it desires companies to pay more taxes. Google paid £10 million in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011. Schmidt also called for a debate on international tax reform and suggested that corporate taxes should be levied where economic activity and risks occur, rather than where products are consumed. Meanwhile, Margaret Hodge, head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, proposed the establishment of a new committee to oversee the tax arrangements of major firms, allowing for confidential hearings to prevent companies from hiding their tax affairs.

NHS Improvement aims to reduce agency staff costs by £1 billion by the end of this financial year, after spending £3.6 billion on agency staff last year. A cap was introduced in October, saving £600 million so far, limiting payments to 55% above normal shift rates for most staff. Progress is promising but still short, with NHS trusts 10% down on their targets. The figures do not cover NHS bank staff or overtime spending. League tables of the best and worst-performing trusts on agency spending will be published later this year, along with information on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust. Examples of excessive agency fees were found, highlighting the need for further action.

The Longford Town Centre, once a symbol of Ireland's economic boom, now stands as a reminder of the country's economic downturn. However, local traders like Matt O'Brien are starting to see signs of recovery. O'Brien's family-owned men's clothing shop has seen an increase in business over the past year, although it is still below pre-recession levels. To adapt, the shop has expanded into childrenswear and dress hire.

The opposition party, Fianna Fáil, criticizes the government for not doing enough to support the midlands region. They argue that the investment in water meters should be redirected to improving broadband infrastructure. The government, on the other hand, points to the planned Center Parcs tourism development in Ballymahon as a sign of their commitment to the region. The project is expected to create 1,000 jobs when it opens in 2019.

Despite these positive developments, traders like O'Brien believe more needs to be done to support local businesses, such as addressing parking charges that may deter visitors. The message from the midlands is one of cautious optimism, with a call for further action to boost the local economy.

The competition, featuring eight teams, concludes on May 29 in the same stadium. Each team plays twice, with the top four advancing to the play-offs. BBC Sport provides updates on scores, fixtures, and results. Leading run-scorers include Warner (294), Kohli (267), and De Villiers (249), while McClenaghan (9), Kumar (8), and Rahman (7) lead in wickets. Four England players participate: Eoin Morgan for Sunrisers Hyderabad, Jos Buttler for Mumbai Indians, Sam Billings for Delhi Daredevils, and Kevin Pietersen for Rising Pune Supergiants. The detailed fixture list spans from April 25 to May 29, with matches mostly at 15:30 BST, some at 10:30 BST. The play-offs are scheduled for May 24, 25, and 27, leading to the final on May 29.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs found that the number of plastic carrier bags has increased by 200 million since 2013. Many of these bags cannot be recycled and are often thrown away after use, ending up in rubbish dumps and rivers, causing significant environmental problems. To encourage people to reuse their plastic bags, a 5p charge will be introduced in England from October. Supermarkets in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, where a similar charge is already in place, have seen a decrease in the number of bags used. Campaigners hope that the charge in England will reduce the number of bags being thrown away, helping the environment.

A school roof was ripped off in Rhosgadfan near Caernarfon, Gwynedd, and hundreds of homes across Wales experienced power cuts due to high winds. Train delays, speed and lane restrictions on major bridges, and ferry cancellations also occurred. The winds eased into Friday evening, but a blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend has caused at least one festive event to be postponed.
