Michael B. Jordan expressed excitement about his upcoming role in the film Black Panther, which will be directed by Ryan Coogler, with whom he previously worked on Creed. Jordan will star alongside Chadwick Boseman and Lupita Nyong'o. The film is set to be released in February 2018.

The theatre, founded in 1875, is part of a larger east wing restoration project to transform Alexandra Palace into a new cultural destination. It is hoped the theatre will reopen in 2018 and be used for theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music. The Heritage Lottery Fund (HLF) is contributing £18.8m towards the project, while Haringey Council is contributing £6.8m. The entire east wing will be refurbished at a cost of £26.6m, with the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust committed to raising the final £1m by summer 2017. The theatre still has much of its original decor and stage machinery in place and was created to showcase opera, musicals, plays, and all kinds of entertainment, even hosting early cinema screenings. The BBC studios, at the eastern end of the Palace, will also be repaired and refurbished. The glazed east court will become a space for the public and for exhibitions.

James Milner, a former Manchester City player, has retired from international football after winning 61 caps for England. He made his senior debut in 2009 and was a squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships, although he only played for three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player, with 46 caps after his first appearance in 2004. He scored his first and only international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova during the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers.

Marcy Smith and her family escaped a devastating house fire in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, thanks to her son David's quick thinking. The fire, caused by burning rubbish in the wood stove, engulfed their home rapidly, destroying it and killing their pets. The fire alarm did not sound. The family, wearing only pyjamas, fled with nothing but their lives. The community has since rallied to support them with donations. Marcy expressed immense pride in David, who was the only one awake at the time due to being on FaceTime with his father, emphasizing the crucial role he played in saving their lives.

The energy drinks giant was reportedly considering a £200m offer for the Premier League club, West Ham. Sullivan and Gold, who bought a majority stake in the club in 2010 in a deal that valued it at £105m, now own more than 85% of the club. Since the move to London Stadium in August, West Ham has also been linked with takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups. Last year, Sullivan mentioned the possibility of selling a minority shareholding to clear debts, but he and Gold intended to pass on the ownership to their children.

The MTV Movie Awards featured fan-voted awards, including best kiss and best shirtless performance, and served as a promotional platform for summer blockbusters. The Fault in Our Stars won best movie, and its star, Shailene Woodley, won multiple awards. Bradley Cooper, Channing Tatum, Meryl Streep, and others also won awards. Kevin Hart received the comedic genius award and brought his kids on stage. Robert Downey Jr. received the Generation Award from his Avengers co-stars. Clips from upcoming movies, including Pitch Perfect 2, Trainwreck, and Ultron, were shown.

St Mirren has acquired 21-year-old Cammy Smith on loan from Dundee United. Smith, who has scored five goals this season, made his Aberdeen debut in 2012 and has scored four times in 89 appearances for the Pittodrie side. St Mirren manager Jack Ross is pleased with the acquisition, describing Smith as a good player and a mature boy who will be a good fit and provide another option in the attacking area. St Mirren, who are at the bottom of the Championship, will host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council has announced that its Jetpatcher machines will now be used to repair potholes, with the aim of filling in 145 potholes per day over the next four months. Additionally, extra staff will be deployed to repair drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and to clear debris from gutters.

The incident occurred on EnQuest's Thistle platform, off Shetland, in December 2016. Rigging supervisor Steve Innes and fellow Wood Group contractors discovered they had been exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while working on pipe equipment. They were not wearing proper PPE at the time. EnQuest and Wood Group conducted a joint investigation and took additional precautionary steps. The level of exposure was less than 1% of the reportable level to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE). However, Mr. Innes expressed concerns about cancer risks and ongoing blood tests. He criticized EnQuest for failing in its duty of care and called for openness and transparency in handling safety incidents. The HSE did not investigate as the incident was not reportable under the RIDDOR system and no staff raised the issue separately.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) in Singapore is returning a bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari to India after it was discovered to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu. The sculpture was purchased in 2007 for $650,000 from New York dealer Art of the Past, whose manager later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities, including the bronze sculpture. The decision to return the sculpture came after discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), which submitted an official request for its return in May. The museum plans to take legal action to seek compensation for the fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km. It was felt in Milan, Florence, Bologna, and Modena. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage, but phone lines and power supplies were cut in the Garfagnana area, and schools were evacuated as a precaution. Several aftershocks were felt across a large area. Italy is prone to earthquakes, and in 2009, almost 300 people died in a quake in L'Aquila. Six scientists and an ex-official were convicted of multiple manslaughter for giving a falsely reassuring statement about the danger of tremors felt before the 2009 quake.

Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, has successfully grown a fruit in South Yorkshire, despite initial doubts about the region's climate. The fruit is still attached to the plant and not yet ripe for consumption. Grant expressed his joy at the achievement.

Rockstar has delayed the release of the latest version of their open-world adventure game until March 24th, citing the need for additional testing and polishing. While this may disappoint some fans, the company has also announced that eagerly-awaited online heists will be available on consoles before the PC release date. Additionally, Rockstar has released screenshots from the PC version of GTA V, promising even greater levels of detail and support for up to triple monitor configurations. Fans can also ensure their PCs meet the minimum specifications required to run the game.

The 76-year-old artist, who had been shortlisted in 1991 and made the longlist on three other occasions, won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work Squint (19) at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. Judge Ansel Krut described the painting as "quite extraordinary" and technically subtle, with a minimal language that builds a broad field of great sympathy. The painting depicts a leper squint, which were holes made in the sides of medieval churches for undesirables to look through to the service. The artist said the relatively small size of the painting, about 7ft in height, was one of the reasons he entered it into the competition. He plans to spend the prize money on "stretches, canvas and - particularly - good quality paints." The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with previous winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

The offices of the pro-government newspapers Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit were attacked by masked assailants early on Thursday. The attacks occurred almost simultaneously, with both buildings being hit by gunfire and having their windows shattered. No casualties were reported, and the fires at the Yeni Safak building were quickly extinguished. Police have cordoned off the areas and are searching for the attackers, but no group has claimed responsibility for the attacks.

The 24-year-old, previously under contract with the Stags, has agreed to join Marcus Bignot's side on a free transfer. He scored three goals in 23 appearances while on loan at Crawley during the first half of the season. The former Burton player will officially join the Mariners on 1 January, becoming Bignot's first signing for the team.

Wenger, whose contract runs until the summer, has been linked with the England job but says he is focused on his current role. Southgate, who took over from Sam Allardyce in September, has a World Cup qualifier against Scotland and a friendly against Spain to prove himself to the Football Association. Wenger believes Southgate has the opportunity to show his quality and that the most important thing is competency, not big names. Additionally, Wenger confirmed that Arsenal will offer a new contract to defender Hector Bellerin, despite interest from Barcelona and Manchester City, and that midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss "one or two" more games due to a hamstring injury.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at approximately 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police is conducting a joint inquiry with the Health and Safety Executive, and the company is fully cooperating with the investigation.

The Scottish government has announced a new charter arrangement to resolve a dispute over seafarers' pay on two freight boats serving the Northern Isles. The RMT union had claimed that some workers on the Hellier and Hildasay, operated by Seatruck under a contract with Serco Northlink, were paid less than £4 an hour. Seatruck argued that the national minimum wage did not apply to the crew, many of whom are non-UK residents. Serco Northlink, which was awarded the £243m Northern Isles contract in 2012, had offered to bridge the pay gap and backdate it, but Seatruck declined. The new charter arrangement, which will see contracted-out services return to operator Serco Northlink, will ensure that all crew members are paid at least the minimum wage. The change is expected to come into force early next month, subject to some financial and regulatory details being finalized.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May, six days after an incident at the Rockley Park site in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, of Apple Close, had admitted intervening in an argument between Mr Dickie and his mother. He shouted "yes" and was visibly shaking after the verdict was announced by a jury at Winchester Crown Court. The trial heard that Mrs Mitchell and Mr Dickie had been in a relationship for several years and were going through a "down phase" when Mr Mitchell visited his mother at the park on 7 May. In the evening, Mr Mitchell accompanied his mother and Mr Dickie to the holiday park bar and got "tanked up" on alcohol. The two men had a confrontation outside and were separated by members of the public. Mr Mitchell had pleaded guilty to common assault in relation to the fight. He and his mother Samantha, 57, also of Apple Close, also admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying about the course of events. The court heard the pair had initially told police that Mr Dickie had pushed Mrs Mitchell and she had pushed him back. But Mr Mitchell later told police that he had tried to push the couple apart, causing what he described as a "tragic accident". The pair will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a renowned songwriter and producer, passed away in London last week at the age of 66 after a brief battle with cancer. Known for his hits like "Off The Wall," "Baby Be Mine," and "Boogie Nights," Temperton's work with Michael Jackson and Heatwave made him a legend in the music industry. His private funeral has already taken place, and his family has requested privacy during this difficult time.

Born in Cleethorpes, North East Lincolnshire, Temperton's love for music was influenced by his father, who used to put a transistor radio in his crib. After working in a frozen food factory, he joined the disco group Heatwave, where his songs became big hits. His talent caught the attention of producer Quincy Jones, leading to collaborations with Michael Jackson on albums like "Off The Wall" and "Thriller."

Temperton's work has been recorded by numerous artists, and he won a Grammy in 1990 for his work on "Birdland." He was also nominated for two Oscars for his contributions to the soundtrack of "The Color Purple." His approach to songwriting was simple: "Write something you love first."

Tributes have poured in from various artists and music industry figures, highlighting his significant contributions to music. Despite his low profile, Temperton's impact on the music world is undeniable.

Swansea University researchers, alongside a team from the UK and Brazil, discovered over 450 ancient earthworks in the Brazilian Amazon, dating back 2,000 years. These "geoglyphs" were hidden by rainforest until modern deforestation revealed them. Unlike Maya pyramids or Stonehenge, these sites were likely used sporadically for rituals and were not visible above the forest canopy. Soil analysis revealed that the geoglyphs were built among taller vegetation, and the surrounding environment was transformed by humans over 6,000 years, focusing on economically valuable trees. This suggests a form of "prehistoric supermarket" and indicates that some of Acre's forests may still bear the legacy of these ancient agroforestry practices.

Nick Kyrgios, the Australian tennis player ranked 12th in the world, defeated world number 29 Sam Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to progress to the second round of the Shanghai Masters. Kyrgios, who won the Japan Open on Sunday, admitted to feeling tired and bored during the match, attributing his fatigue to the travel and lack of sleep. Last year, Kyrgios was fined $1,500 for a foul-mouthed outburst at the Shanghai Masters, which he described as a "circus."

The human papilloma virus (HPV) vaccine, which is currently given to girls aged 12 and 13 to protect them from cervical cancer, could also protect against head and neck cancers, according to scientists and charities. HPV, which is sexually transmitted, is responsible for 5% of the global cancer burden, and cases of head and neck cancer, which predominantly affect men, are increasing. The Welsh government is waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before deciding whether to extend the vaccination program to boys.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old suffering from a rare blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, passed away after a brave fight documented on social media. His story, shared on the Jak's Journey Facebook page, touched many with his positive attitude and love for Rangers FC. Despite his illness, Jak attended a school prom held in his honor, where he was greeted by former Rangers captain Barry Ferguson. He received the Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity. After doctors decided to stop treatment, Jak's family urged donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research. His legacy lives on through fundraising efforts, including a special football match.

Egypt secured a 1-0 victory over Uganda in their Africa Cup of Nations match, with Abdallah El Said scoring the winning goal in the 89th minute, assisted by Mohamed Salah. Uganda had a goal disallowed for offside earlier in the match. The win sets up a decisive match against Ghana for the top spot in Group D, while Uganda, already eliminated, will face Mali in their final group game.

Lancashire County Council has designated land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for a new railway station. The decision follows a comparative study by Network Rail, and the council plans to acquire the necessary land. The proposed station could provide two direct trains to Liverpool per hour, and the chosen location allows for future expansion. Skelmersdale, designated a new town in 1961, is one of the largest towns in the northwest of England without its own railway station.
Police discovered plants in an elaborate grow house during a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning. A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman was found with serious injuries on a pavement in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, late on Sunday. She was dragged by the neck through several streets and underwent an emergency operation before being flown to a specialist clinic. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from nearby Bad Muender, later handed himself in to authorities. Both the victim and the suspect are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive for the attack is not yet clear, and police have secured the area and called for witnesses to come forward.

The study, conducted by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, analyzed data from 4,600 workers in Australia. It found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise, but are 25% less likely to receive one. This challenges the "reticent female" theory, which suggests women avoid asking for more money. The study also found no evidence supporting the idea that women are reluctant to ask for a salary increase due to fear of upsetting their boss or deviating from a perceived female stereotype. The researchers considered factors such as employer size, industry, parental status, and qualifications. The study suggests that there may be an element of pure discrimination against women. However, it also found that women and men under 40 are negotiating pay and conditions at the same rate, indicating a potential shift in negotiating behavior among younger generations.

Oxford City Council has been searching for a suitable new burial site for many years, but all council-owned sites identified have been discounted due to various factors such as size, ground conditions, high water table, or covenants restricting use. The last increase in burial space in Oxford was in 1932, and the two remaining cemeteries with space are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021. After these cemeteries are full, only the reopening of family plots, the use of reserved plots, and the interment of ashes will be possible. The council has not given up and is still exploring options.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, will feature an augmented reality app allowing visitors to access online information, including videos and band interviews, by scanning signs and posters on-site. This feature will also enable global audiences to interact with the festival and experience its atmosphere remotely. The app will be updated with new content before and during the event, providing instant access to information, interviews, and ticket purchasing.

The 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed that the horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary hemorrhage." Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, but he had never collapsed before and had shown no symptoms of post-race ataxia on Saturday. The horse had won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. Trainer Oliver Sherwood described him as the "horse of a lifetime." The report concludes that Many Clouds was the victim of a hemorrhage rarely seen on the racetrack.

The case involves a 34-year-old defendant, Davina Ayrton, formerly known as David Ayrton, who was convicted of raping a 15-year-old girl in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. The victim reported the attack in 2014 to a care home worker. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties and attempted suicide last summer, denied the charge. The judge remanded Ayrton into custody, citing risks to herself and the likelihood of failing to attend court. The trial at Portsmouth Crown Court was described as unusual and challenging. Protocols have been established for Ayrton's detention in a male prison.

The Serbs lost 6-4 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio. This loss came a day after Djokovic was knocked out of the singles by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. Djokovic, 29, suffered a surprise third-round defeat at Wimbledon in July when he lost to American Sam Querrey. The 12-time Grand Slam winner came back to claim his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

The passage describes an upcoming chainsaw carving competition in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, featuring over 20 competitors from various regions including Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US. Participants are restricted to using only chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human shapes. The defending champion, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will return to compete for the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a 27-year-old rugby player for Wales and Ospreys, has been sidelined with a serious foot injury since September. He is close to returning and hopes to be fit for the Six Nations in February. Webb has renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, expressing his commitment to his home region and his desire to continue playing for Wales.

The incident began on Tuesday morning when US border agents encountered two men carrying backpacks near Sumas, Washington. One man dropped his backpack, fired a weapon at the agents, and fled, while the other man, Jeffrey Laviolette, was taken into custody. The fugitive, Nathan Hall, was arrested in British Columbia early on Wednesday morning. The backpacks contained 58lb (26kg) of ecstasy, and one backpack also contained a California driver's license with the name of William Nickerson but a picture of Nathan Hall. Investigators later arrested Kali Henifin and Ryan Lambert, who were allegedly planning to pick up the men and transport the drugs to San Francisco. The three defendants in US custody face conspiracy as well as drug possession and distribution charges. The wooded area east of Sumas is a well-known smuggling route for drugs and firearms.

The NSPCC's Childline service has seen a significant increase in the number of children seeking counseling for online abuse, with over 4,500 cases reported in the past year compared to about 2,400 in 2011-12. The actual number of children suffering from online abuse is believed to be much higher. Children as young as seven have reported being tormented, abused, and scared to go to school due to online trolls. Childline's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, emphasized the devastating impact of bullying, especially cyber-bullying, which can follow children home and become a constant source of persecution. She urged adults, parents, and teachers to intervene and protect children, as bullying does not stop on its own. The report is being released at the start of Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti-Bullying Alliance, which is working with parents, schools, and other organizations to combat the problem. One young person shared their experience of being told to kill themselves by a group of online players, highlighting the emotional distress caused by such incidents.

The US abstained from vetoing a UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to Israeli settlement construction, leading to a strain in US-Israel relations. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office requested the postponement of a planned vote on authorizing new settlement homes to avoid further straining relations with Washington ahead of a speech by US Secretary of State John Kerry on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The resolution, which passed on Friday, stated that the establishment of settlements "has no legal validity and constitutes a flagrant violation under international law and a major obstacle to the achievement of the two-state solution and a just, lasting and comprehensive peace." Israel rejected the resolution, and Netanyahu responded by summoning the ambassadors of the US and the 14 countries on the Security Council who voted in favor of the resolution, recalling Israel's ambassadors to New Zealand and Senegal, cutting aid to Senegal, and canceling a visit by Ukraine's prime minister. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas has said the resolution "paves the way" for the upcoming conference on Middle East peace in France on 15 January.

The Queen's 90th birthday celebrations include a series of events and tributes. A new stamp featuring four generations of the Royal Family has been released, and the Queen visited Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office and Alexandra Gardens for the opening of a new bandstand. Political leaders, including Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, expressed their admiration for the Queen's service and dignity. Prince William praised the Queen as a guiding example and addressed criticisms of his commitment to royal duties, emphasizing the importance of finding his own way at the right time. The Queen's actual birthday on April 21 will include a walk around Windsor and the unveiling of a plaque marking The Queen's Walkway. The day will conclude with the lighting of a beacon, followed by a series of over 900 beacons across the UK and around the world. On Friday, the Queen will have lunch with US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama at Windsor Castle. The Queen celebrates two birthdays each year, her actual birthday on April 21 and her official birthday on a Saturday in June.

West Ham United secured a 2-0 victory over Cheltenham Town in the EFL Cup, with goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew in the first half. Despite a respectable performance from the League Two side, they failed to test West Ham's goalkeeper Adrian sufficiently. The match saw several substitutions and missed opportunities for both teams, but West Ham's early goals proved decisive. Cheltenham's exit marked the end of League Two's representation in the competition.

A hospital radiographer, Aidan McNicholl, 36, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion on Sunday. Andreas Werner, 46, of Leipzig, pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court. He was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not see value in Werner being sent to jail, as they accepted it was a momentary lapse. Werner was remorseful and could offer no explanation for the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from Southall, west London, is a dangerous British jihadist who attempted to sneak back into the UK after spending time in Syria. He was a member of Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated with Islamic State, and was involved in propaganda efforts aimed at recruiting young British Muslims. Khawaja's activities in Syria included posting videos and pictures of his personal jihad, some of which depicted gruesome scenes of death. He was arrested upon his return to the UK and is now facing a possible life imprisonment for his role in the conflict. The reasons for his return and his intentions remain unclear, but he is considered a significant threat by British authorities.

Kayden Jackson, 22, has signed with Barnsley as their third signing for next season. He scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season. Jackson turned down a contract offer from Wrexham for next season. Barnsley's caretaker boss, Paul Heckingbottom, described Jackson as having "pace to burn" and being able to "get at defenders," stating that he will fit in well with the team's style of play.

Bottles of Vanish detergent have been washing up on Cornwall's beaches, including Poldhu Cove, after a container from the MV Blue Ocean was lost at sea during stormy weather in May. The National Trust and Cornwall Council have been clearing the bottles, which pose a risk to wildlife, and have advised the public to keep children and dogs away. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency stated that while the MV Blue Ocean did lose a container, there is no evidence linking it to the bottles found on the Cornish coast. Cornwall Wildlife Trust has expressed concern about the impact on marine life.

The incident occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at about 14:00. Several other people received minor injuries in the crash. The road was closed and diversions were put in place via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland said inquiries into the incident were ongoing.

Dervite, a 28-year-old French center-back, made 14 appearances last season, contributing to Bolton's second-place finish in League One and securing promotion. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in all competitions. Dervite follows David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan in signing new contracts with Bolton after their promotion to the Championship.

The Liberal Democrats and Labour have a history of forming alliances to defeat the government on various issues, including Brexit. However, their cooperation broke down when MPs rejected amendments on EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal. The Lib Dems accused Labour of conceding everything and giving people false hope, while Labour accused the Lib Dems of grandstanding and building up false hope. Despite this, the Lib Dems remain committed to working with peers from across the House to fight for the issues they agree on, while Labour predicts residual tensions between the two parties.

The passage discusses the declining priority of defense in UK politics, as evidenced by its low ranking among electorate concerns and limited attention in party manifestos. It highlights the impact of recent military interventions on public sentiment and political focus. The UK's defense capabilities have been reduced, with cuts to the army, navy, and air force, leading to capability gaps such as the absence of Maritime Patrol Aircraft. Defense spending has fallen relative to other nations, and there is uncertainty about meeting the NATO 2% GDP target. Political parties differ on key defense issues like Trident renewal and aircraft carrier capabilities, with potential further cuts looming due to fiscal pressures.

Barcelona has made a complimentary tax declaration of €13.55 million to cover any potential interpretations of the contracts related to Neymar's transfer. The club paid £48.6 million for Neymar, but it has been alleged that the actual cost was much higher. The club denies any tax-related crime and insists that the original tax payment was in line with their fiscal obligations. The case is still under investigation, and there has been no confirmation whether the case will be dropped after Barcelona's payment. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances for Barcelona this season, as well as netting three in seven Champions League matches.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old father from Nottingham, was killed in a motorway crash caused by Albert Kenneth Newman, a retired driver who was driving the wrong way. Mr. Luciw's family believes that older drivers should undergo regular driving tests to prevent such tragedies. His brother, Simon, emphasized the need for tests involving a driving instructor to assess driving skills accurately. The family also suggested that free bus passes for seniors could ease the transition if licenses were removed.

The crash occurred near Kegworth, Leicestershire, when Mr. Newman's car collided with the van Mr. Luciw was traveling in. Andy Harrington, the van's driver, sustained serious injuries and continues to suffer from sleepless nights. He supports the idea of medical examinations for retired drivers, stating that Mr. Luciw would still be alive if Mr. Newman had not been on the road.

Currently, drivers over 70 in the UK must renew their licenses every three years by filling out a self-assessment form, which does not include a medical or driving test. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) stated that there are no plans to restrict licensing based on age, as evidence does not indicate that older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents. They emphasized that drivers must report any medical conditions that might affect their driving, and if they do not meet the medical standard, their driving entitlement is immediately removed.

Caroline Abrahams, charity director of Age UK, highlighted the importance of older people being able to drive for their independence and daily activities. She emphasized the need to support older drivers to continue driving safely for as long as possible.

The story raises questions about the balance between ensuring road safety and supporting the independence of older drivers.

The passage discusses concerns and controversies surrounding transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence. Many women have reported debilitating side effects, leading to legal actions and protests. An independent review, chaired by Tracey Gillies, concluded that the procedures should not be routinely offered and recommended informed choice and mandatory adverse event reporting. However, the review process has been criticized, with two members quitting in protest and allegations of report alterations. Health Secretary Shona Robison confirmed the recommendations would be implemented but noted that a ban on the procedures is beyond the Scottish government's power. Independent expert Alison Britton will examine the review process and its conclusions.

Laura Muir broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old British 5K record by 14 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow on Wednesday, with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. McColgan initially raised concerns about whether Muir's race met all the criteria set by UK Athletics for record-breaking attempts, but British Athletics confirmed that Muir's time was expected to be classified as official. McColgan praised Muir's performance and said that she had the ability to win world medals. She also noted that Muir's race tactics needed improvement to start winning medals. Muir had previously broken her own British 1500m record and reached the 1,500m Olympic final at Rio 2016.

Jung won aboard Sam, a late replacement for Fischertakinou, who contracted an infection in July. France's Astier Nicolas took silver, and American Phillip Dutton won bronze. GB's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th, just 10 months after being placed in an induced coma following a fall. Fox-Pitt, aboard Chilli Morning, produced a faultless performance in the final show-jumping phase but had already been ruined by a disappointing performance in the cross-country phase. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth on Cooley Rorkes Drift.

Andy Murray, the 30-year-old Briton, secured a spot in the last 16 of the tournament by defeating 29th seed Fabio Fognini 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5 in a match that lasted two hours and 39 minutes. Despite a tense and up-and-down match, Murray managed to win five games in a row to seal the victory. He will now face Frenchman Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday. Fellow Briton Johanna Konta also advanced to the second week with a 6-4, 6-1 win over Maria Sakkari of Greece.

The Limavady Magistrates Court heard that paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014, where police found several people still at the bar. Till receipts showed alcohol was being served as late as 04:49 BST. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, both of Kevin Lynch Park in Dungiven, were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. A defense solicitor told the court that the licensing laws in Dungiven "were not strictly adhered to" and that the premises had not been run properly. The judge described the case as "as bad a case as I have come across" and expressed concern that he did not have the power to impose a custodial sentence. Ms. O'Neill, the license holder, was fined £3,000, while Mr. Thomas was fined £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt, launching the Ulster Unionists' manifesto titled 'Real Partnership,' emphasized the need for partnership over domination and called for the election to be a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle. He defended his controversial remarks about transferring votes to the SDLP, stating he wouldn't withdraw them and expressing confidence in his position. The manifesto outlines actions on waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, prioritizing the York Street interchange, supporting the LGBT community, and ensuring no group is worse off due to Brexit. Nesbitt highlighted the importance of addressing incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption in Stormont.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden confirmed that a motion will be presented to the assembly for approval, aiming to bring Northern Ireland in line with England and Wales. The proposed law, known as 'Turing's Law' after World War Two code-breaker Alan Turing, would grant posthumous pardons to men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences and allow living men to apply for a pardon. The motion is expected to include provisions for both posthumous and living pardons for gay and bisexual men. Minister Sugden emphasized the importance of equal treatment and the opportunity to address past injustices. The motion will now be considered by the assembly.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, Scotland, set a new Scottish record in the mile with a time of 4:19.12, surpassing Yvonne Murray's 1994 record of 4:22.60. This achievement also places her second on the British all-time list, behind Zola Budd's 4:17.57. Muir, who finished fifth in last year's World Championships, expressed her excitement and satisfaction with the new record. She is now focusing on securing a spot for the Olympics in Rio at the British trials in Birmingham from June 24 to 26. Muir, who is also a veterinary student, started her season with an 800m victory in Montbeliard, France, and will compete in a 1500m race in Stockholm next week.
The passage presents images from 26 Scottish beaches recognized for their exceptional water quality.

The Met Police barrister, Richard Horwell QC, stated that the Russian state was likely behind the murder of Alexander Litvinenko, who was poisoned with polonium-210 in London in 2006. The suspects, Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi, had no personal motive to kill Litvinenko, and attempts to extradite them have failed. Horwell emphasized that the evidence suggests Russian state involvement, but this does not necessarily implicate President Vladimir Putin. Litvinenko's defection to the UK and his criticism of Putin were cited as possible motives. The inquiry also highlighted the risk to the public from polonium radiation and the suffering caused to Litvinenko before his death. The suspects left a trail of polonium, but they have not provided a credible explanation for the scientific evidence against them. The inquiry was adjourned until Friday.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed as the new captain of the Australian cricket team, succeeding Michael Clarke, who announced his retirement after Australia's Ashes defeat. Smith, who has already captained the team in three Tests, will also lead the Twenty20 team in the absence of the injured Aaron Finch. David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain, despite a history of disciplinary problems. National selector Rod Marsh expressed confidence in Smith's leadership abilities and Warner's maturity and development as a senior figure in the team.

The passage discusses Mr. Farron's views on LGBT rights and his voting record on related legislation. Despite refusing to directly answer whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, he expressed strong support for LGBT rights and equal marriage. He emphasized the need to extend marital rights to transgender people and explained his vote against the Equality Bill in 2007 as being due to concerns about individual liberties, though he did not specify these concerns. Mr. Farron reiterated his commitment to equality and his intention to prioritize LGBT rights as leader of the Liberal Democrats.

Accord Healthcare is set to use the former Sanofi drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, which closed in 2015 resulting in 450 job losses, for its pharmaceutical production. The company hopes to fill many of the new positions with ex-Sanofi staff. The investment is expected to have a positive impact on the area, with Newcastle City Council leader Councillor Nick Forbes stating that it will strengthen the region's reputation as a hub for the science and healthcare sector. Accord Healthcare, a global player in the pharmaceutical industry, develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 pharmaceutical products to around 60 countries worldwide.

The local authority announced that Richard Ellis, the council's former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, is leaving at the end of his contract on Friday. Ciaran Monaghan, head of the chief executive's office, and Ewan Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are also departing under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn, leader of the opposition SNP group, believes these departures indicate the council's difficulty in retaining senior staff and anticipates more departures in the coming months. Council chief executive Angela Scott expressed gratitude for their dedication and professionalism.

The English rider crashed at this year's TT and the Fireblade bike has been plagued by mechanical problems. Martin told MCN that he was quitting road racing but later clarified his position on Facebook, stating that he has no plans to do anymore road racing on the Hondas this year. He did not race at the North West 200 after his teammate John McGuinness crashed in practice and will not compete in next month's Ulster Grand Prix. He described the TT as a disaster and said he did not enjoy it, aside from walking the dog and racing the Mugen. He also mentioned that the bike won't be competitive at the Ulster Grand Prix and the team decided to withdraw him from the event. He expressed his desire to race classics and oddball stuff.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in Nigeria's recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which had been in power for 16 years. The APC's Muhammadu Buhari, who won the presidential election last month, will be inaugurated on May 29. The PDP lost key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, as well as Adamawa, one of the states most affected by the Boko Haram insurgency. However, the PDP managed to retain control of Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC also retained power in Lagos, Nigeria's commercial capital. The elections were marred by violence in some areas, but overall, they were more peaceful than in previous years. The PDP will now have to rebuild itself under a new leader, as voters sought change due to widespread allegations of corruption and the party's failure to address the insurgency in the north-east.

The report by Mighty, a US-based environmental lobby group, accuses Olam, a Singapore-based agricultural commodities trader, and its main stakeholder, Temasek, of contributing to the haze caused by slash-and-burn practices in Indonesia. The report alleges that Olam created a "secretive market for rogue palm oil companies" and that Temasek, as the majority stakeholder, is indirectly financing these unsustainable practices. Both Olam and Temasek have denied the allegations. Olam's CEO, Sunny Verghese, stated that the company has a strict "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" compliance policy and that it is in the process of vetting and verifying its suppliers. Temasek, on the other hand, emphasized that it does not direct the business operations of its portfolio companies, including Olam. The report also raises concerns about Olam's operations in Gabon, where it is accused of clearing rainforests for palm oil plantations. Olam defended its actions, stating that its partnerships in Gabon are responsible and transparent.
The restaurant started offering puppy platters after a new law permitted dogs to dine at restaurants, provided they stayed outdoors.

Forward Fernando Forestieri (knee) is a doubt having only been able to play from the bench in the last two games. Derby County striker David Nugent (groin) could return after missing Monday's draw with Huddersfield. Midfielder Jacob Butterfield is hoping for a recall after coming off the bench to score a late leveller against the Terriers.

Pakistan's ban on YouTube, imposed in 2012 after the controversial film "Innocence of Muslims" sparked protests, has been lifted following the launch of a Pakistan-specific version of the platform. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) confirmed that all internet service providers have been directed to restore access to YouTube. The government stated that it can now directly request the blocking of offending material through an online process, but YouTube clarified that such requests are subject to review and will be recorded in its Transparency Report. While some young Pakistanis welcomed the move, activists are calling for greater transparency regarding the terms of the agreement between Google and the government.

Domenico Scala, the Swiss-Italian head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is facing calls to step down due to a perceived conflict of interest with Gianni Infantino, another Swiss-Italian presidential candidate. In 2015, Scala and Claudio Sulser, both members of the Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, withdrew from the election process due to their shared nationality with Sepp Blatter, the incumbent Swiss candidate. However, Andreas Bantel, a spokesman for Scala, has stated that there is no conflict of interest in this election as there is no incumbent president and the regulations do not require Scala to step down. Musa Bility, the head of the Liberian FA, has threatened to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday. Bility, who was denied participation in the election, has pledged his vote to Prince Ali and urged fellow Africans to do the same. The election, which will take place in Zurich, will be voted on by FIFA's 209 members.

Two men, Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed in a flashover explosion at Harford Attachments in Spar Road on Monday morning. The explosion is believed to have been caused by a build-up of toxic fumes and some sort of ignition, resulting in a fire-ball effect. The men's bodies were removed from the site on Tuesday afternoon, and a forensic search has been carried out at the company, which makes buckets for diggers. The Health and Safety Executive's inspectors and electrical safety experts are gathering evidence.

Tunisia and Morocco faced challenges in participating in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Tunisia was on the verge of expulsion due to complaints lodged against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) during the 2015 tournament. However, they avoided expulsion by apologizing. Morocco, on the other hand, was initially banned from the 2017 qualifying draw but had the ban overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas). Both teams are now set to participate in the 2017 tournament, with Tunisia in Group A and Morocco in Group F.

The charge follows a mass fracas in the 95th minute of the game at Etihad Stadium, which Chelsea won 3-1. City had forward Sergio Aguero and midfielder Fernandinho sent off, but Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas will not face any further action. Aguero, 28, received a four-match ban for his second dismissal for violent conduct this season, following a high and late challenge on Chelsea defender David Luiz. Fernandinho clashed with Fabregas in the scuffle that followed Aguero's challenge, and the Brazil midfielder will serve a three-match ban. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

Wales and other parts of the UK have some of the worst cancer diagnosis rates in the developed world. A pilot scheme in Cwm Cynon and Castell-nedd focuses on patients suspected of having cancer but showing no urgent signs or symptoms. This follows a visit by Welsh health officials to Denmark, where improved diagnostic systems have enhanced cancer survival rates. In Wales, there is concern that patients without clear symptoms may wait too long for a diagnosis, as they do not easily fit into a specific treatment pathway. This can result in multiple referrals and tests, taking several weeks. The fear is that many patients begin treatment only after their cancer has progressed.

In the pilot scheme, 40 doctors in Cwm Cynon can refer patients to a diagnostic center at the Royal Glamorgan Hospital, Llantrisant, within seven days. About six patients per week are expected to be seen and undergo various tests, ideally on the same day. Currently, only 35% of patients with concerning symptoms in the Cwm Taf area receive a diagnosis. Doctors aim to diagnose a majority of patients with less obvious symptoms earlier. A similar clinic will be established at Neath Port Talbot Hospital as part of another trial by the Abertawe Bro Morgannwg Health Board.

The trials, developed over the past 12 months following a visit by Welsh specialists to Aarhus, Denmark, aim to address concerns about Denmark's cancer survival rates. Dr. Gareth Davies, Associate Director of the Wales Cancer Network, believes the scheme will reassure patients and accelerate the diagnostic process. Dr. Gareth Jordan, a GP in Aberdâr, thinks the pilot could significantly impact patients' lives by enabling earlier diagnoses. If the Cwm Cynon pilot, which will last six months, is successful, the service will be extended to other health boards in the region.

England leveled the series with a dominant win over Pakistan at Old Trafford, securing victory with a day to spare. Joe Root, promoted to number three, was named man of the match for his outstanding performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second. He also contributed with four catches and a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance, describing it as "as good an innings as I've seen." England's strong batting and disciplined bowling were key to their success, while Pakistan struggled with shot selection and confidence. The third Test is set to begin on August 3 at Edgbaston.

The British and Irish Lions, led by head coach Warren Gatland, have named Rob Howley as part of their backroom team for their tour of New Zealand. Forwards coach McBryde will assume head coach responsibilities for the third time, having previously led Wales on tours in 2009 and 2013. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) will appoint assistant coaches to support McBryde on the summer tour. WRU chief executive Martyn Phillips stated that discussions with other individuals about the summer tour are at an advanced stage, and the full management team will be confirmed next week. Union chairman Gareth Davies believes that the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team and Welsh rugby as a whole.

Hull City ended a six-game losing streak with a 2-1 victory over Southampton, despite losing strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane to first-half injuries. Southampton took an early lead with a penalty from Charlie Austin, but Hull's Robert Snodgrass, who came on as a substitute, scored the equalizer and assisted Michael Dawson for the winning goal. Hull's goalkeeper, David Marshall, made several crucial saves, and Sam Clucas made a remarkable goalline clearance to secure the win. Hull's victory was their first in the league since August, while Southampton's loss followed their Europa League win against Inter Milan.

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision with a tractor on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, at about 14:15 BST. The motorcyclist lived locally, according to Lincolnshire Police, who have appealed for witnesses to come forward. The tractor driver was not injured. The B1191 was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

Macedonia has been in turmoil since 2015 due to covert recordings that allegedly reveal corruption at the highest levels of government, including vote-rigging and cover-ups of killings. President Ivanov's decision to cancel an investigation into these claims has been met with condemnation from both the opposition and EU officials, with EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn stating that the move is not in line with the rule of law and puts Macedonia's EU membership ambitions at risk. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev has called the move illegal and urged protesters to gather in the capital Skopje.

Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Swansea's match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's dismissal. The club aims to appoint a new manager quickly, with Paul Clement as the top candidate. Curtis expressed concerns about the club's potential relegation, highlighting the challenges of returning to the Premier League. He also discussed the club's history, including its rise from near bankruptcy and its reputation for exciting, possession-based football. Curtis believes the team has lost its way since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014, with frequent management changes and player departures affecting the club's identity. Despite this, he thinks the current squad is capable of avoiding relegation and emphasizes the importance of staying up for the club and the local community.

Dagenham & Redbridge's relegation from League Two was confirmed after a 3-2 loss to Leyton Orient, despite a late comeback attempt with goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona. Orient's Armand Gnanduillet scored the winner, keeping their play-off hopes alive. Dagenham, who reached League One in 2010, will return to the National League under manager John Still, who previously led the club from the Conference to League One. Still criticized the team's lack of organization and discipline, while Orient's interim manager Andy Hessenthaler emphasized the importance of professionalism and winning games for a play-off spot.

Steven Gerrard, the former Liverpool captain and England international, is set to return to his old club as a youth coach in February. This will be his first job since retiring as a player in November after a 19-year career. Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp described the appointment as "wonderful news" and said he had a "good long chat" with Gerrard about his future plans. Gerrard, who made his Liverpool debut in 1998 and won multiple trophies during his time at the club, had been linked with the manager's job at League One side MK Dons but said the opportunity came "too soon" for him. He is also working towards his Uefa A coaching licence, which is required to manage in the Premier League.
Morton secured a comfortable victory with goals from McManus and Forbes in the first half, and McManus and Johnstone in the second half, despite a goal from Alloa's McAusland before half-time.

Ofsted has uncovered evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions in three illegal schools in Birmingham, which have now been closed. Ministers are consulting on plans for more regulation of places teaching for more than 6 to 8 hours a week. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools in England, has expressed serious concern that children are at risk of being abused or radicalized. Any place where children are taught for more than 20 hours a week has to register as a school. Some places describing themselves as part-time education centers or "flexi schools" are operating within the law providing support for home-educated children. However, Ofsted and ministers are concerned that some are taking advantage of the legal right to home educate to operate illegal schools. The government has provided funding for a team of six inspectors to investigate illegal schools. While most of the places visited by Ofsted so far have been in Muslim communities, inspectors may also turn their attention to similar unregistered tuition centers operated by other groups. The education secretary has asked Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution against unregistered schools it has identified.

Lilliard Gin, based at the Born in the Borders visitor center in Jedburgh, is set to become the first new distillery in the Scottish Borders in nearly 200 years. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes highlighted the potential to make the region a "distilling excellence" hub, emphasizing the unique scale of their operation and the use of local botanicals to capture the flavor palette and terroir of the Borders. The gin is named after Lilliard, a legendary figure from the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545, reflecting the local landscape and the strong female production team. John Henderson of Born in the Borders praised the distillery's alignment with their ethos of local sourcing, expressing excitement for the upcoming production and tasting of Lilliard Gin.

In August 2013, Harry Whitlam was fatally struck by a vehicle driven by Gary Green at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, near Leeds. Green, who was more than twice the legal driving limit, had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before the incident. He was prosecuted under health and safety legislation, as the incident occurred on private land, and was sentenced to 16 months and two weeks in jail after admitting to failing to ensure the safety of others. The Health and Safety Executive described the case as "extremely tragic" and Green's behavior as "reckless." Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed the family's enduring grief and the hope that Harry's life would be remembered beyond the tragedy.

The Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) has partially upheld Luis Suarez's appeal against his four-month ban for biting Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup. While he remains banned for eight more competitive international matches and cannot play in organized matches until late October, he is now allowed to train and play in friendlies. This means he can participate in Uruguay's upcoming friendlies and make his competitive debut for Barcelona in El Clasico against Real Madrid. CAS deemed FIFA's original suspension excessive, as it would have impacted Suarez's career post-ban. However, the World Players' Union, Fifpro, expressed disappointment that the sanctions were not further reduced.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race in which competitors must tackle a 380-metre course, hurdling over haystacks, scrabbling up a steep slope, and dodging water pistols. The pair will now compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond, in response to concerns raised by Swansea East AM Mike Hedges about potential job losses at the DVLA due to the scrapping of the paper tax disc system, assured that any reductions in staff would be managed through redeployment rather than redundancies. The new electronic system, set to replace the tax disc in October 2014, will allow for monthly direct debit payments. While this may lead to changes in job roles and necessitate training on new processes, the minister emphasized the commitment to redeployment, providing reassurance to the DVLA employees.

The EU is pressuring Hungary to withdraw three laws, including one targeting the Central European University (CEU), which could force its closure. Hungary's Higher Education Law, signed in April, could force the closure of the Budapest-based CEU, which ranks among the top 200 universities in the world in eight disciplines. Hungary is also forcibly housing asylum seekers in secured shipping containers, raising serious questions about its compatibility with EU law. The EU objects to Hungary's tight controls on asylum seekers and non-governmental organizations (NGOs), as well as the higher education law. Critics say the education law could lead to the closure of the prestigious Central European University, founded by philanthropist George Soros. Thousands of Hungarians have held protest rallies against the laws in recent months. The Hungarian government, under Prime Minister Viktor Orban, is under sustained pressure from European institutions to withdraw the three laws, two of which have already been passed. The EU rules envisage that such decisions as stripping a member country of its voting rights should be approved unanimously. Hungary's right-wing Fidesz government of Prime Minister Viktor Orban is under sustained pressure from European institutions to withdraw the three laws, two of which have already been passed. The EU objects to Hungary's tight controls on asylum seekers and non-governmental organizations (NGOs), as well as the higher education law. Critics say the education law could lead to the closure of the prestigious Central European University, founded by philanthropist George Soros. Thousands of Hungarians have held protest rallies against the laws in recent months.

The live-action adaptation of Beauty and the Beast will feature Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou. Joining the cast are Emma Thompson as Mrs. Potts and Kevin Kline as Maurice. Bill Condon will direct the film, which is set to begin filming in May at Shepperton Studios and will be released in US cinemas on March 17, 2017.

Adrian Gill, a celebrated columnist for the Sunday Times since 1993, passed away from cancer. Known for his fearless and witty writing, Gill's final column, reflecting on his diagnosis, will be published posthumously. Despite his illness, he expressed gratitude for his life. Gill, who had dyslexia, began his career in the 1980s and was renowned for dictating his copy. His writing, though popular, often sparked controversy, including criticisms for remarks about Wales and a review of Clare Balding's TV programme. Tributes from journalists and public figures highlighted his unique talent and impact on journalism. Gill, who had four children, was engaged to his long-term partner Nicola Formby at the time of his death.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa, was allegedly attacked in Ulan Bator after a performance where he wore a red deel embroidered with a swastika, a traditional Mongolian symbol of eternity. Russian news reports stated he was hit with a bottle and repeatedly kicked in the face, leading to a 10-day coma. The Russian embassy, while investigating, called local press reports "distorted." Amraa's lawyer, father, and a band member denied social media claims that he shouted "Heil Hitler" during the show. The suspect, a Russian diplomatic officer, was not arrested, with police citing the injury as not serious, not due to diplomatic immunity.

Campaigners from the action group Plane Stupid staged a protest on the northern runway of an airport at 03:30 BST on Monday, opposing the airport's expansion plans. The protesters have been charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security-restricted area of an aerodrome. They are set to appear in court on 19 August. The Metropolitan Police have stated that security at the airport will be reviewed.

Glamorgan's total was dominated by Nick Selman's mature 101 off 144 balls, his second first-class century. But seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles made sure wickets fell at regular intervals in cloudy conditions in the Welsh capital. Gloucestershire struggled in turn as the bowlers remained on top all day. Selman's century, after being dropped on eight in the first over, was a welcome return to form for the Brisbane-born opener after a string of low scores following his hundred against Northants at Swansea. Aneurin Donald's quick-fire 36 off 30 balls was the next best contribution as Taylor and Miles prospered in the afternoon. Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten scrambled Glamorgan to a consolation bonus point. Gloucestershire's innings was a question of survival in the evening gloom, with the day ending evenly balanced. Glamorgan are being led by Michael Hogan for the first time in the absence of Jacques Rudolph, who has a neck problem.

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after he chatted online with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. He admitted to two charges at Mold Crown Court on Friday and will be sentenced next week. Hughes said he was planning to make a false report to the police so that officers would come to the scene, and then he would shoot them on the Dee Estuary. The threats were made on two occasions, late at night, while Hughes was drunk. Judge Niclas Parry, who was told the defendant had a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009, remanded him in custody pending sentence. During a previous hearing, Hughes's legal team said he had not intended to kill himself and would not have carried out any threat to kill police officers. The court heard at the time that North Wales Police was particularly concerned because the defendant was on bail, awaiting trial for firearms offences, of which he was subsequently cleared.

In a match where Surrey posted a total of 255-7 after being reduced to 8-2, Davies and Ben Foakes' partnership of 130 was crucial. Yorkshire's run-chase was undermined by Stuart Meaker's three-wicket burst, including key wickets of Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Tim Bresnan's 68 wasn't enough as Yorkshire were all out for 236. Despite a good start, Yorkshire fell short, with Davies' dropped catch proving costly. Surrey's skipper Gareth Batty praised the team's performance, while Yorkshire's captain Alex Lees expressed disappointment at not capitalizing on their good start.

A 56ft (17.1m) converted trawler, located 6 miles (10 km) west of South Stack, radioed Holyhead coastguards at 07:00 BST due to a pump on board being unable to cope with the incoming water. The RNLI lifeboat crew placed a pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner, will miss the Commonwealth Games in Australia next year due to her veterinary medicine studies. Despite her disappointment, she prioritizes completing her final year at university. Muir achieved fourth and sixth place in the 1500m and 5,000m events at the World Athletics Championships, setting a new outdoor personal best in the 5,000m. She expressed happiness with her performance and sees potential for future success, including at least two or three more Olympics. Muir also mentioned the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target.

Liverpool's struggles this season are evident, with their title challenge appearing distant. The absence of Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge's injuries have left a significant gap in their attacking prowess. The team's defensive issues persist, and their set-piece efficiency has declined. Despite these challenges, Steven Gerrard remains a key figure for Liverpool, showcasing his importance in midfield. The upcoming match against Chelsea presents a tough test, with Liverpool needing a significant improvement to compete. Gerrard's future at the club is uncertain, but his determination and skill suggest he still has much to offer.

The £45m facility in Kilmarnock will house primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare center. East Ayrshire Council plans to name the campus in honor of William McIlvanney, a renowned writer born and educated in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney, known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir," gained recognition with his first novel, Remedy Is None, and wrote acclaimed works like the Laidlaw trilogy, Docherty, and The Big Man. He was also an influential poet, journalist, and broadcaster, contributing to political and sporting life in Scotland. McIlvanney died on December 5 at his Glasgow home.

An area near the swimming pool in Gourock was evacuated for most of the morning and early afternoon due to the discovery of a British sea mine from the 1940s or 1950s. Residents within 500m of the device were advised to stay indoors, while a half-mile exclusion zone was enforced at sea. Ferry services were disrupted, and small boat owners were told not to sail during the operation. The mine was moved to a safer location before being dealt with due to its deteriorated state. The evacuation was a precautionary measure, and there was no immediate danger to the community. Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their patience during the operation.

UK Sport has allocated £345 million to 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for the Tokyo 2020 Games, a slight decrease from the £347 million allocated for Rio 2016. This funding aims to maintain the historic success of Rio, with a target of 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals. However, several sports, including archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby, and badminton, have had their funding cut or removed entirely. Badminton England's chief executive, Adrian Christy, expressed shock and disappointment at the decision, especially given the sport's bronze medal win in Rio. UK Sport's CEO, Liz Nicholl, defended the cuts, stating the need to prioritize funding to protect medal potential. Additionally, funding for new sports like baseball/softball, karate, skateboarding, sports climbing, and surfing is yet to be confirmed, pending further evaluation of their medal potential.

The East Cliff Project LLP plans to demolish three Victorian hotels in a conservation area in Bournemouth to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. The development will include a 90-room hotel and two buildings, one nine-storeys and the other seven-storeys, comprising 122 assisted-living apartments. The plans were approved by the council, with seven votes in favor and three against, despite strong objections from English Heritage and some residents. The council believes the development will help tourism and improve living conditions for older people in the town.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, was off-duty on a night out in Brecon when he was attacked and killed by Jake Vallely. Vallely, 24, will be sentenced on 8 December. The attack occurred outside a bar called The Cellar, where Pte Boyd was punched, knocked to the ground, and beaten until he no longer moved. Vallely then dragged his body from the scene before fleeing. The trial heard that Vallely had been on a seven-hour drinking binge and was boasting about being the "hardest man in Brecon" before the attack. His friend, Aaeron Evans, was cleared of any involvement in the attack. The community of Brecon was shocked by the attack, and Pte Boyd's family described him as an "all-rounder" with a promising career ahead of him. They also expressed their gratitude towards the community for their support during this difficult time.

Andrew Travers, the chief executive of Barnet Council, left his position by "mutual agreement" following a significant error on election day. Voters were initially turned away from all 155 polling stations in the borough because their names were missing from the poll list. The council has apologized for the problems and offered emergency proxy votes to affected residents. An independent investigation has been launched, and the council's review will conclude by the end of May. The findings will be presented publicly to the General Functions Committee. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will take over temporarily while longer-term arrangements are put in place.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1 in a match where Josh Gillies scored the first goal with a free-kick, but Wrexham equalized before halftime through Sean Newton's set-piece. Ryan Bowman secured the win for Gateshead with a header in the second half. Gateshead's manager, Malcolm Crosby, praised the team's improvement in the second half, while Wrexham's manager, Gary Mills, expressed disappointment with their second-half performance and missed chances.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 ranks Norway as the best country for the social and economic welfare of people over 60, while Afghanistan and Mozambique are the worst.

The OneWeb project aims to create a network of at least 600 spacecraft, potentially expanding to over 2,000, to provide global broadband coverage, with a focus on connecting every school. This ambitious endeavor requires a shift in satellite manufacturing, moving from traditional, high-cost methods to high-volume, low-cost production. Airbus, in collaboration with OneWeb, has established assembly lines in Toulouse, France, and plans additional lines in Florida, utilizing innovative techniques like trolley robots and streamlined supplier chains. The first satellites are set to launch in April next year, with a goal of deploying over 800 satellites by the mid-2020s. This project represents the largest rocket campaign in spaceflight history and is part of a competitive race among companies like SpaceX and Boeing to establish mega-constellations. OneWeb, registered in the UK's Channel Islands, emphasizes the economic benefits for the UK and adherence to strict debris mitigation standards, aiming to de-orbit satellites within two years.

The UK government's recent spending review has placed "unprecedented pressure" on public expenditure in Scotland, according to Mr. Swinney. The Scottish government argues that cuts imposed by the UK government since 2010 mean that its discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 than it was in 2010-11. Mr. Swinney stated that 4.2% of that reduction would come between now and 2019-20. He also mentioned that the chancellor has imposed real-term cuts on Scotland every year from now until 2020, with more than £1 billion of those cuts still to come.

Despite these challenges, Mr. Swinney emphasized that the Scottish government is determined to defend and protect key priorities such as schools, hospitals, and the police service. He highlighted the government's achievements in delivering better outcomes for the people of Scotland, including more police, lower crime, better schools, tuition-free university education, and a record-level health budget.

A spokesman for the UK government's Scotland Office responded by stating that the Scottish government will have £390 million more in spending available next year, which rises to £750 million if its underspend is included. The spokesman also mentioned that the stability of the UK economy means the block grant will be almost £30 billion and suggested that the Scottish government should focus on utilizing its new powers and getting the best for Scotland.

Labour's public services spokeswoman, Jackie Baillie, called on Mr. Swinney to back up his anti-austerity posturing with something real and emphasized the need for a long-term budget. She criticized the Scottish government for spending more time on spin than explaining its record and pledged that Scottish Labour would offer a real alternative to austerity with different decisions on tax.

The passage highlights the challenges faced by individuals with severe disabilities and their families due to the lack of suitable toilet facilities. Standard accessible toilets often fail to meet the needs of those requiring additional assistance, such as hoists or changing benches. Campaigners, including Lorna Fillingham, are advocating for mandatory Changing Places toilets in larger buildings like shopping centers and cinemas. These facilities, larger and better equipped than standard disabled toilets, are essential for over a quarter of a million people in the UK. Despite being included in Building Standards guidelines since 2009, they remain only a recommendation, leading to inconsistent implementation. The passage also shares positive examples, like Arsenal Football Club's installation of a Changing Places toilet, demonstrating the impact of such facilities on inclusivity and accessibility.

Italian consumer organizations have filed a formal antitrust complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's, accusing the company of imposing excessive rents and high fees on its franchisees. The complainants argue that this practice, along with long contracts that prevent franchisees from switching to competitors, leads to higher prices and reduced consumer choice. The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and European unions are supporting the complaint. McDonald's has defended its practices, stating that it shares risks and rewards with its franchisees, which has contributed to the success of its business model. The European Commission will now review the complaint to determine whether to launch an investigation.

A social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve, has gone viral. The campaign began as a hashtag on Facebook and Instagram by Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father is on the pastoral staff. The church's senior pastor, Gary Beattie, said he was amazed by the support Josh and his family have received. A mystery donor paid for a massive billboard with the hashtag #prayforjosh, which was erected at Holywood playing fields. There has also been a huge outpouring of support on Twitter for the Bangor Grammar pupil, with his classmates using the now-global hashtag.

The UK government plans to close Brecon Barracks, a historic military site in Brecon, Wales, as part of a broader reorganization of military buildings and regiments. The decision has sparked criticism from local MP Chris Davies, who condemned the closure and launched a petition against it, citing the barracks' long history and its importance to the local economy and military tourism. The closure is expected to affect about 85 civilian staff and 90 military personnel, although jobs are not thought to be at risk. The nearby Sennybridge training ground and infantry school are not expected to be affected. The reorganization also includes the creation of a specialist light infantry center at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan, and the closure of Cawdor Barracks in Pembrokeshire in 2024 and a storage depot at Sennybridge in 2025. Labour's Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith acknowledged the need for restructuring but warned of the impact on local livelihoods and the uncertainty faced by those affected.

The House of Lords European Union Committee has released a report highlighting the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry post-Brexit. While the industry is a small contributor to GDP and employs only 12,000 fishers, the Lords emphasize that it must not be marginalized in Brexit negotiations. The report points out that most commercial fish stocks are shared with other EU coastal states, and the UK exports the majority of its fish to the EU while importing a significant portion for domestic consumption. This necessitates continued market access, which may come at the cost of increased EU access to UK waters. The report also suggests retaining elements of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) post-Brexit and adhering to scientific advice for quotas. Additionally, it raises concerns about the potential for four different fisheries management regimes in the UK.
