Despite these challenges, many in the fishing industry see Brexit as an opportunity for fairer shares and better management, as evidenced by the recent EU agreement on new quotas. The government has stated its aim to ensure British companies have maximum freedom to trade with the single market while reviewing fisheries management for sustainable stocks and fair access to quotas.

Edward Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, leaked documents revealing extensive US government surveillance programs. The US National Security Agency (NSA) has been collecting vast amounts of data, including phone records and internet activity, through programs like Prism. This program allegedly provided "backdoor" access to servers of major tech companies, enabling the monitoring of private communications. While the US government defends these actions as necessary for national security, Snowden and privacy advocates argue they infringe on individual rights. The revelations have sparked global concern about data privacy and the extent of government surveillance.

Open AI, a research venture backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, aims to advance digital intelligence for the benefit of humanity, free from financial obligations. The venture's goal is to ensure that AI is developed in a way that is safe and beneficial to society, with a focus on individual human wills and liberty. While some experts, including Elon Musk and Stephen Hawking, have warned about the potential risks of AI, others argue that the threat remains remote. Open AI plans to spend only a small fraction of the $1 billion pledged in the next few years.

L/Bdr Parkinson, a soldier who was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006, carried the Olympic torch on 26 June. He was flanked by hundreds of people and walked for nearly half an hour with the help of an assistant. His nomination stated that the brain injury he sustained took his speech, but not his personality and sense of humor, and that he now speaks unaided. He spends 12 hours a day in the gym and rehab, and the rest of his time raising money for military charities and as patron of the Pilgrim Bandits. His mother Diane said the responses to his torch carrying had been phenomenal and that Ben was really buoyed up by the support and friendship he had been shown. She said that Ben had way over 5,000 friend requests on Facebook, which limits friend associations to 5,000 per personal page. Facebook suggested that he create a page instead of a profile or use the subscribe feature so that people can see his public updates without becoming a friend.

The poverty rate in the United States was 15% in 2011, with 46.2 million Americans living in poverty. This rate remained unchanged after three consecutive years of increases. The real median household income decreased by 1.5%, and the average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, as measured by the Gini index, increased by 1.6%, marking the first annual rise since 1993. Additionally, the percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased from 16.3% to 15.7%. Poverty in the US reached a record high of 15.1% in 2010.

The 25-year-old cricketer, Jos Buttler, has signed a new deal with Lancashire, committing him to the club until 2019. Known for his short-format expertise, Buttler has achieved England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball ton against Pakistan last year. Ashley Giles, the cricket director and head coach, praised Buttler's talent and his positive influence on the team, particularly in their T20 Blast final victory last year. Buttler, who has been playing in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians, will return to Lancashire for Friday's T20 Blast home game against Durham.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour. The government's Disposal Services Authority is handling the sale and wants to award at least one of the frigates to a UK ship recycler to determine the capacity of the UK's industry in the field. The Ministry of Defence has said it will "consider all options" for the frigates to ensure "best financial return for the taxpayer." The BBC understands that no proposals to preserve the ships have been submitted. Those who have registered an interest are finalizing their bids with viewings set to take place in late February and March. A final decision is not expected until the spring.

Originally designed as a specialist anti-submarine ship, the Type 22 frigate evolved into a powerful surface combatant with substantial anti-surface, anti-submarine, and anti-aircraft weapons systems. They were also known for having excellent command and control and communication facilities, making them ideal flagships on deployments, with a complement of about 280 crew. Last year, the aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal was sold as scrap for £3m.

Since 1987, racial and political tensions have caused instability and international isolation in Fiji. A coup by indigenous Fijians overthrew the elected, Indian-dominated coalition in 1987, leading to a series of adverse events, including the introduction and subsequent withdrawal of a constitution enshrining indigenous Fijian political supremacy. Another coup in 2000, led by George Speight, resulted in the country's first ethnic Indian prime minister, his cabinet, and several MPs being held hostage for weeks, causing harm to the economy and Fiji's international reputation. Persistent tensions culminated in a bloodless military takeover in 2006, Fiji's fourth coup in 20 years. Fiji was suspended from the Commonwealth in 2009 due to a lack of progress towards democracy but was reinstated after free elections in 2014. The population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with minimal mixing and deep informal segregation. Despite relying heavily on sugar and tourism, Fiji's economy is diverse, with mining and a strong services sector, though it has been hampered by persistent trade and budget deficits, making it one of the world's largest per capita recipients of aid.

Syria missed the deadline to hand over its chemical weapons stockpile, citing attacks by "terrorist groups" on shipments. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad defended the government's actions, denying the use of barrel bombs and accusing the US of supporting terrorists. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported civilian casualties from barrel bomb attacks, while state media denied rebel control of Aleppo's central prison. The US expressed concern over the delay in chemical weapons transfer, with Russia setting a new deadline for completion. The OPCW acknowledged security concerns slowing down the process.

The Booker Prize, now in its 46th year, is open to all authors writing in English, regardless of nationality. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall on Tuesday night. The shortlist includes three British writers, two Americans, and an Australian. The favorite to win is Mukherjee's The Lives of Others, set in 1960s Calcutta, followed by Richard Flanagan's The Narrow Road to the Deep North. Other nominees include Howard Jacobson's J, Ali Smith's How to Be Both, Joshua Ferris's To Rise Again at a Decent Hour, and Karen Joy Fowler's We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves. Fowler's book is the best-selling among the nominees. The judging panel is chaired by AC Grayling. Coverage of the ceremony will be on the BBC News Channel and BBC Arts.

The Supreme Court will hear arguments on whether to grant an appeal against a Court of Appeal ruling that lifted a ban on identifying a celebrity, referred to as PJS, in the media in England and Wales. An interim injunction will remain in place until the end of the hearing. The Court of Appeal had given PJS until 10:00 BST on Tuesday to apply to take the case to the UK Supreme Court, and ruled that there must be no publication leading to disclosure of the celebrity's identity before 13:00 BST on Wednesday. The Sun on Sunday wants to publish an account of alleged extra-marital activities by PJS, who argues he has a right to privacy and has taken legal action. The Court of Appeal ruled that PJS was unlikely to be able to get a permanent injunction, as details about the allegations were now "so widespread" that confidentiality had "probably been lost".

Fosse Park, near junction 21 of the M1, was purchased in August for £345.5 million. Plans are being developed to improve parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of the units. Ernie White, leader of Blaby District Council, mentioned that the new owners have discussed potential planning issues with the council. Paul Clarke, director of investments at Crown Estates, stated that they aim to address parking and congestion issues and improve the quality of common areas to enhance the overall experience at Fosse Park.

The live-action remake of Beauty and the Beast has sparked controversy due to a "gay moment" involving the character LeFou. The film was scheduled for release in Malaysia on Thursday but was held for a "review" of its content by the Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF). The LPF approved the film with a "minor edit concerning a gay moment" and granted it a "P13 parental guidance classification." However, the release date has yet to be announced. The decision to review the film in Malaysia has been criticized by netizens, with many calling it "stupid and laughable."

Landlords who rent properties to more than three unrelated people must apply for a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) license, which can cost up to £1,000. Failure to obtain a license can result in a fine of up to £20,000. Southampton City Council estimates that there are 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. HMO tenants frequently raise concerns about fear of eviction and living in poorly maintained properties. Nationally, mandatory licensing for HMOs applies to houses of three or more storeys and occupied by five or more unrelated people. In Southampton, the licenses affect properties in specific areas, and the council has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for non-compliance.

Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil are attempting to avoid a second election, with Fianna Fáil willing to facilitate a minority government but not support a program for government. Water charges are a major obstacle to reaching an agreement, with Fianna Fáil seeking their immediate removal and Fine Gael seeing a role for them. A commission to consider the future of Irish Water is being considered. Following the election almost two months ago, no party was able to form a majority government and TDs have so far failed to elect a taoiseach.

The Sorrento, a ferry owned by Italian company Atlantica di Navigazione, was traveling to Valencia when a fire broke out on one of its car decks, about 27km from Mallorca. The fire quickly got out of control, and the passengers were evacuated onto lifeboats. Several ships, including two passenger ferries, were sent to help, and the passengers and crew eventually boarded one of the ferries, the Puglia. At least three people were injured, with one seriously hurt, and were taken to the hospital by helicopter. The rescued passengers were on their way back to Palma de Mallorca and were expected to arrive at the port in a few hours. Psychologists were being asked to go to the port to provide counseling. The reason for the fire was unclear, and the Balearic Islands port authority tweeted that the Sorrento may sink in its current position.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs highlighted cases of individuals, including students, claiming to have voted twice in the recent general election, which is a criminal offense. The Commission recommended better integration of individual electoral registers managed by councils to identify duplicate entries. Despite concerns over duplicate applications, a record 46.8 million people were registered to vote, with a turnout of 68.7%, the highest since 1997. There was a surge in applications after Theresa May called the snap poll on 18 April and leading up to the 22 May deadline, with 2.9 million applications received over the six-week period. Several constituencies, especially those with large student populations, saw an increase in their electorate by more than 10%. However, the lack of a direct link between electoral registers and the online registration service led to a significant proportion of duplicate applications, causing administrative and financial burdens. The Commission called for clearer information on registration sites and a verification function to address this issue. Labour warned against making it harder for young people to register to vote and called for police resources to prosecute those suspected of voting twice.

Lawrence Phillips, a former star football player at the University of Nebraska and NFL player, was found dead in his prison cell on Wednesday. He was serving a sentence of more than 30 years for assaulting a former girlfriend and driving his car into a group of teenagers. Phillips had been accused of killing his former cellmate, and a judge found enough evidence to try him for the death of Damion Soward. His coach at Nebraska, Tom Osborne, described him as an intelligent person with good qualities but also with anger issues and personal demons.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and official soldier, was promoted to lance corporal at an event in Chester celebrating eight years of the Mercian Regiment. The promotion was awarded by Brigadier Andrew Williams for "good behavior." Private Derby XXX is the 30th mascot ram in a lineage dating back to the Indian Mutiny War in the mid-19th century. The first Private Derby was acquired in 1858 by the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot and became the Mercian Regiment's mascot when it formed in 2007. Lance Corporal Derby XXX joined the regiment in February 2014. He has his own army number, is paid for his rations, and takes holidays during the mating season on the Chatsworth Estate. He has also participated in public events, such as switching on Christmas lights in Ashbourne and meeting Prince William at a memorial unveiling.

Liverpool staged a remarkable comeback to defeat Borussia Dortmund 4-3 in a thrilling Europa League quarter-final, with Dejan Lovren scoring the winning goal in injury time. The match was marked by dramatic swings in momentum, with Dortmund initially dominating and taking a 2-0 lead within nine minutes. However, Liverpool, inspired by manager Jurgen Klopp's motivational tactics and invoking the spirit of their 2005 Champions League victory, rallied to score three second-half goals. The victory not only advanced Liverpool to the semi-finals but also symbolized Klopp's impact on the team, instilling belief and determination. The match was also notable for the electric atmosphere at Anfield, with both sets of fans contributing to a memorable night.

The EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee met in London to discuss the UK's strategy for leaving the EU. Mr. Davis emphasized the importance of collaboration with Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, committing to regular meetings and information sharing. However, Mr. Russell criticized the UK government's lack of clarity on its EU market access plans, stressing the importance of single market membership for Scotland's economy. The Scottish government plans to oppose the UK government's appeal to the Supreme Court regarding the triggering of Article 50.

The passage discusses a study on a flock of 13 cloned sheep, including four clones of Dolly the sheep, living on a farm owned by the University of Nottingham. The study aims to determine if cloned animals age normally and remain healthy. Concerns about cloning include the potential transfer of "age-memory" from adult cells, leading to premature aging and associated diseases. The original Dolly died at six-and-a-half years old from a virus and osteoarthritis, raising questions about premature aging in clones. The current study, involving exhaustive tests on the cloned sheep, focuses on cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. The results, to be published next week, could have significant implications for the future of cloning.

Shutter Speed, trained by John Gosden and ridden by Frankie Dettori, won the Musidora Stakes at York, beating Vintage Folly by a length and three quarters. Despite the soft ground, Shutter Speed performed well and will now head to the French Oaks at Chantilly, while stablemates Enable and Coronet will compete in the Epsom Oaks. Trainer John Gosden will assess the ground before deciding whether to run Cracksman in the Dante Stakes, a Derby trial. Tasleet, trained by William Haggas and ridden by Jim Crowley, won the Duke of York Stakes, beating Magical Memory and Comicas.

The pound initially fell against the dollar and euro but recovered in mid-afternoon trading before falling again. The "volatility index" hit levels last seen in the 2008 financial crisis. The Leave campaign argued that the pound simply retreated to March levels. The pound was down 0.2% against the dollar at $1.4226. Against the euro, sterling was down 0.6% at €1.2605 and weakened by 1% against the Japanese yen to just over 151. Investors have been spooked by data showing the chances of a Remain vote have fallen, although markets have also been rattled by global economic worries. With 10 days to go before the referendum vote, two polls at the weekend put the Leave camp ahead, while betting firm Betfair said the implied probability of a vote to Remain had now fallen to 68.5% from almost 80% a week earlier. Hedge funds have been placing bets - short-selling - on expectations that the value of sterling will sink further. The bears are in town. Polls show it's now too close to call and markets are responding with some very twitchy activity. Sterling has shed more than 2% in two sessions to retrace its April lows. Worries about the economic impact of leaving the EU were also blamed for a big fall in Asian stock markets. Japan's Nikkei index closed 3.5% down, while Hong Kong's main index slid 2.5%. The reaction on London's FTSE 100 was muted initially, with the index down 0.3% in morning trading. However, the FTSE 100 ended the day down 1.1% at 6,044.9 points, with Lloyds Banking Group the biggest faller, down 4.2%. On Sunday, Leave campaigner Nigel Farage told BBC1's Andrew Marr Show that sterling had recently been strengthening. "Sterling is up since March. Since Brexit became a possibility, sterling is up and FTSE is exactly the same level it was in March," he said. He also pointed out that a weaker pound was good for UK exporters. Last week, official figures showed that the UK trade deficit narrowed in April on the back of a jump in exports.

The Iron are currently sixth in the National League, just outside the play-off spots. Despite a tough loss to Barrow, who extended their unbeaten league run to nine games, Cowley remains positive. He acknowledges the challenges of being a part-time team and embraces the journey, stating that it has been remarkable so far.

The passage discusses a significant shift in Northern Ireland's planning system, set to take effect in April 2015. Currently, planning decisions are made by the Planning Service, but from next year, local councils will take on this responsibility. This change is seen as an opportunity to democratize the planning process and allow councils to develop community and development plans. However, concerns have been raised about the potential for discrimination and favoritism, harking back to issues in the 1960s. Environmental groups like Friends of the Earth emphasize the need for transparency and a strict code of conduct to ensure fairness. There are also calls for more transparency regarding political donations, as the new powers could have significant financial implications for developers and objectors. Some politicians oppose the move, citing security concerns for donors, while others argue that the £7,500 limit for declaring donations is largely irrelevant in Northern Ireland.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was found injured by her owner, Sarah Nisbett, in Niddry View, Winchburgh, on Friday, March 14. Teenie had been shot twice in the shoulder and once in her left back leg, which had to be amputated. The Scottish SPCA is urging anyone with information about the incident to contact them. The charity said Teenie was "incredibly lucky" to survive. The Scottish government held a consultation on licensing air weapons last year, but a majority of responders opposed the plan. Under the proposed scheme, anyone wanting to own an air gun would need to demonstrate they had a legitimate reason for doing so. A total of 87% of respondents rejected the idea, with some describing it as "draconian" and "heavy-handed."

Liverpool has signed Belgium international Christian Benteke from Aston Villa on a long-term contract, making him their second most expensive signing. Benteke, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa, expressed his happiness to join Liverpool and his desire to win trophies. Liverpool struggled for goals last season, and manager Brendan Rodgers has added Benteke to revive the team's attack. Benteke missed the 2014 World Cup due to an Achilles tendon injury but returned to action last October and scored 15 times to help Villa stay in the Premier League and reach the FA Cup final. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert and former Liverpool striker John Aldridge believe Benteke will do well at Anfield.

The study, commissioned by Tablets for Schools, found that while there is no clear evidence of academic improvement for pupils using tablet devices, the rapid growth of tablet computers in the classroom is one of the ways in which young people are immersed in technology at school and home. Tablets are now being used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools, with 9% of schools having an individual tablet device for every pupil. The highest use of tablet computers was within academy schools. The study found that the number of tablet computers in schools is expected to rise from about 430,000 to almost 900,000 between 2014 and 2016. While researchers cannot isolate the impact of technology as the specific cause of a rise in attainment, head teachers reported a positive impact, and there is evidence that they help to motivate pupils who might otherwise be disengaged. The study also found that within a sample of schools where every pupil has a tablet computer, a quarter of secondary pupils described themselves as internet "addicts" and about two-thirds took a computer device or smartphone to bed with them, used for social media or watching videos. The study suggests that touch-screen computers were particularly useful in helping boys and poorer pupils to learn to read. Simon Mason, head of Honywood Community School in Essex, is a strong advocate of tablet computers in schools, stating that they create a "sense of empowerment" for young people and reflect the reality of how pupils live at home and what they will find at work.

The exhibition Growing Up in the City at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs capturing the lives of children over more than 100 years. The images, spanning from the 1880s to the 1990s, provide a social history of life in Liverpool and illustrate how childhood has changed over time. The exhibition includes a portrait from 1887 of the Rollo children dressed in costumes for a fancy dress ball, as well as a photograph of a young maid from around 1900. The exhibition was curated by Kay Jones, who selected the final 25 images from hundreds in the National Museums Liverpool's collections. The exhibition is on display until September 25.

Anderson, a 27-year-old center-back, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join their National League rivals. He has previously played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy. Keating, a 21-year-old striker, has been recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. Keating has previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, and his move is subject to international clearance. Nicholson described Anderson as a leader and Keating as young and hungry. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone and have only won one of their last six games.

The law in Bolivia now allows 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization, reflecting the country's economic needs as one of the poorest in South America. It also imposes harsher punishments for violence against children, including a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide. The law, signed by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera in the absence of President Evo Morales, aims to balance the reality of child labor in Bolivia with international treaties. More than 500,000 children already work in Bolivia, many in extreme conditions. The government hopes the law will help eradicate extreme poverty. The International Labour Organization is studying the legislation to determine if it breaches international regulations on child labor.

The 50-year-old actress and former talk show host, O'Donnell, shared on her blog that she experienced a heart attack after helping a woman struggling to get out of her car. She searched online for "women's heart attack symptoms," which included sudden nausea and aches, and took a few aspirin before visiting a cardiologist the next day. The cardiologist inserted a stent into an artery that was 99% blocked. O'Donnell revealed that the type of heart attack she had was known as the "widow maker" and warned her readers to know the symptoms and call 911. She also mentioned that she did not call the emergency services. O'Donnell recently hosted The Rosie Show on the Oprah Winfrey Network, but the show was canceled in March due to low ratings.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a boy from Harrow, was fatally stabbed in an alleyway near a party in Belvedere Way, Kenton, after a scuffle with a group of youths. The incident occurred around 00:30 GMT, and he was pronounced dead an hour later. Another 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in stable condition. Che had been invited to the party, which was described as well-organized with adults present. He was not involved in an earlier altercation with a group of youths denied entry but was targeted later. A 21-year-old man and two boys, aged 15 and 16, have been arrested on suspicion of murder, while a 14-year-old boy has been arrested on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

Denmark has implemented a new model of care to improve cancer diagnosis and survival rates, addressing long waiting times and vague symptoms. The model includes three routes: fast-track diagnosis for patients with alarm symptoms, diagnosis centers for patients with undiagnosed symptoms, and "yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms. The changes have led to better organization of patient diagnosis and improved survival rates, with Denmark catching up to other European countries. The Welsh health service can learn from Denmark's approach to breaking down barriers between GPs and specialists.

Powys council has won a competitive bidding process to take over the role of regulating estate agents from the disbanded OFT. The council will receive £170,000 a year to carry out this work, which includes issuing warning and banning orders against dishonest or law-breaking agents. Complaints about estate agents will still be handled by local authority trading standards departments, but cases involving breaches of the Estate Agents Act will be referred to Powys. James Munro, who will lead the new team, hopes this will demonstrate Powys' ability to take on more contracts and outside work in the future.

NHS Employers has approved a plan to reshape the 1.3 million-strong workforce to address staff shortages and changing care needs, following a Nuffield Trust review recommending additional training for nurses and other health workers to take on tasks traditionally performed by doctors and GPs. While unions warn against using this as a quick fix for NHS problems and stress the need for proper funding, NHS Employers sees it as an opportunity to improve patient care and staff roles. However, the British Medical Association cautions that increasing workforce skills should not come at the expense of doctor training and expertise.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place outside the First depot after a crash at 03:00 GMT. The A36 road closure, which was lifted at 14:00 GMT, caused disruption and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour. Investigations are under way into how the collision happened. First said that while parts of its services had resumed a normal schedule, it would take a few hours for all services to return to normal. Managing director James Freeman said: "We are hoping we will have a full service running in time for the evening commute. We would like to thank the public for their support and understanding and staff for going beyond their call of duty to help manage the situation and recovery."

The proposed £1.3 billion Swansea tidal lagoon project has sparked a dispute between Natural Resources Wales (NRW) and Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) over the potential impact on fish populations. NRW estimates that the lagoon could result in the deaths of 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout annually during their migration to and from local rivers. TLP disputes these figures, claiming they lack a clear scientific basis and are based on unrealistic scenarios. TLP's own computer modeling suggests a worst-case scenario of 2% mortality for all fish species. The disagreement has led to TLP accusing NRW of refusing to share its methodology for calculating the figures. NRW, however, asserts that it has shared a significant amount of information and data with TLP over the past year and a half and that its findings are based on the best available evidence. The Welsh Government supports the project but seeks clarity on the UK government's position.

The announcement of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body in Northern Ireland was made by DETI Minister Arlene Foster. The body, to be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB), aims to provide strategic leadership and direction for marketing activities in the agri-food sector, which is crucial for the region's economy with almost 100,000 jobs. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill supports the initiative but notes potential implications for other organizations, including her department, and looks forward to discussing the plans with AFSB.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a tree-planting event at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, inviting the public to participate in creating a living tribute to the estimated 40,000 people from Ireland who lost their lives in WW1. This project is part of a larger initiative to plant millions of native UK trees across the country. The trust aims to plant 40,000 trees at Brackfield Wood, along with carpets of wildflowers including poppies, creating a space for wildlife and reflection. The event offers a unique opportunity for individuals to contribute to this historical project, with the charity providing saplings and advising volunteers to wear appropriate footwear.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for her thriller Someone Else's Skin, which tackles domestic violence and so-called honor crime. The book was described as "an emotionally exhausting and powerful story" and "so finely written and tightly written" by the judges. The award was presented at the start of the annual crime writing festival in Harrogate, North Yorkshire. US author Sara Paretsky, who created detective VI Warshawski, received an outstanding contribution honor for her 23-year career writing about VI Warshawski, a female private investigator from Chicago. Paretsky was praised for changing the way readers thought about female writers and for creating a strong female protagonist. She also set up Sisters In Crime, an organization to support female crime writers around the world.

Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner, broke his finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes expressed excitement about Santner's return, stating that his injury was a significant loss to the team's chances of qualifying. Santner will rejoin the Rapids after the ICC Trophy in England. Additionally, Worcestershire signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, 47, was killed in 2008 by a speeding car with stolen license plates as he tried to hail a taxi on a dual carriageway in Kiev. The car did not brake or stop. The coroner, Dr. Elizabeth Earland, recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, stating that the evidence was overwhelming and that Mr. Pring had been unlawfully killed. The coroner also mentioned the difficulty of investigating a death abroad.

Mr. Pring's wife, Ganna Ziuzina, who was 19 years younger, tried to claim his assets within days of his death. The couple had met online in 2006 and married in 2007 following a four-day engagement. Mr. Pring's family believes that Ms. Ziuzina had some involvement in his death to inherit his money and property. The inquest heard that Ms. Ziuzina sold Mr. Pring's Range Rover, contents from his flat, and moved funds from his bank account. She was also having an affair with a Ukrainian man.

The inquest was told that strenuous attempts had been made to get Ms. Ziuzina to attend, but without success. In a statement, Ms. Ziuzina said she had made three separate statements to Ukrainian police and did not believe she could add anything further.

Det Con Jonathan Watts, from Devon and Cornwall Police, said Mr. Pring was hit by a car with no lights, speeding at 75 mph. Witnesses at the scene described the killing as a deliberate act. The Ukrainian police initially closed the inquiry into his death but relaunched it in 2011 as a murder inquiry. The case is still active but not actively pursued.

Charlie, a young boy from Merseyside, has been battling illness since the age of three. After a third relapse in April, his family was informed that there were no further treatment options available for him in the UK. However, an anonymous donor has stepped forward to cover the costs of experimental T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital. This generous act has left Charlie's parents, Sophie and Rob Fearns, "ecstatic" and "overwhelmed." With financial clearance from the hospital, Charlie's treatment is set to begin as soon as possible, bringing hope to his family during a challenging time.

Apple has introduced a two-step verification system for iCloud in response to recent hacks that exploited third-party software to steal intimate photos of celebrities. This system requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted mobile phone number or via Apple's Find My iPhone app, in addition to their username and password, when accessing their account from a new device. If the code is not entered, access to iCloud and purchases from iTunes, iBooks, or the App Store are blocked. However, the system remains an opt-in choice, and some experts suggest that Apple should make it the default option. The recovery key, a 14-character code, can be used to regain access to the account if the trusted device is lost or stolen, but there are concerns about the risk of losing or stealing the recovery key. Apple plans to more aggressively encourage users to turn on two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

Billericay, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, has been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is investing £10,000 a week in the club. The club recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky. There are reports that Mark Wright, a former non-league football player and runner-up in I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, may buy 20% of the club and become a director, although the details of the deal have not yet been released.

Mr. Ashley, owner of Sports Direct and Newcastle United Football Club, has been asked to provide evidence regarding the treatment of his workers following a BBC investigation into the company's warehouse practices. He has been invited by the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee to a public meeting at Westminster, but has not accepted any of the proposed dates. The committee has given him until March 21 to respond, warning that failure to do so may result in further action, including seeking the support of the House of Commons for a complaint of contempt. Sports Direct has previously pledged to review worker rights with oversight by Mr. Ashley.

The report Putin. War, completed by Ilya Yashin and colleagues after the assassination of Boris Nemtsov, accuses President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for his own political gain. It presents evidence that Russian soldiers and equipment were crucial to the rebels' successes in eastern Ukraine, despite Russian denials. The report estimates Russian spending on the conflict at 53 billion roubles and documents military units and weaponry. However, publishing and distributing the report has been challenging due to fear and lack of public interest. While many Russians are aware of their country's involvement, they see it as support for independence rather than aggression. The opposition views it as a politically motivated war orchestrated by Putin to boost his popularity.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire on Monday at 11:00 BST. A post-mortem revealed that the 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn in Rotherham died from head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and are currently in custody.

The passage discusses the tensions between the Welsh and UK governments regarding the Article 50 letter and the devolution of powers post-Brexit. Welsh First Minister Carwyn Jones has expressed frustration at not being consulted on the letter's content, highlighting a lack of respect for the devolved administrations. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns defended the UK government's approach, emphasizing the need to act in the interests of the whole UK. The letter mentions increased decision-making powers for devolved administrations, but there are concerns about the accompanying funding. The UK government's intentions regarding which powers will be devolved remain unclear, with some suggesting a potential shift of EU funding control to Westminster.

Two cars were damaged in an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed his disgust at the attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community. The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page stated that police were carrying out their duties when they were attacked and appealed to parents to know where their children are and what they are doing.

Mr. Charney, the founder and former CEO of American Apparel, was ousted last year due to employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds. The company's board filed court documents stating that Mr. Charney repeatedly violated the company's sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies, including sending illicit emails to female employees and making racially derogatory taunts. The board stated that it did not expect Mr. Charney to ever return to the company. Mr. Charney's lawyer, Keith Fink, claimed that many of the statements made by the company were false and accused the company of invading Mr. Charney's privacy in an attempt to extort him and gain leverage over him. Earlier this month, American Apparel was granted a restraining order preventing Mr. Charney from making negative statements about the company and attempting to remove board members.

The British basketball team will face Greece in a rematch at the Copper Box in London, following their earlier 92-64 defeat in Patras, Greece. The game will be available for live streaming on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app from 17:30 to 19:30 BST. This match is Britain's only home game before they compete at FIBA EuroBasket 2017, which begins in September with a qualifying group in Istanbul, Turkey. After the Greece game, coach Joe Prunty's team will travel to Poland for a four-team tournament, their final warm-up games before EuroBasket starts.

The passage describes the transformative impact of the iPhone, introduced by Steve Jobs in 2007. Initially met with skepticism, the iPhone revolutionized the way we live, particularly in photography and mobile connectivity. The author recounts their experience of handling the iPhone for a news piece, highlighting its significance as a step change in technology. Despite initial reservations about the hyperbole surrounding its launch, the author now recognizes the iPhone as a pivotal moment in history, marking the beginning of the mobile-connected era. The passage also notes the broader impact of smartphones, with over two billion users, and their role in disrupting various industries.

The RSPCA has confirmed that all cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, have ingested a toxic substance, leading to the deaths of four cats in the past two weeks. The most recent victim, seven-month-old Meereen, died on Monday after consuming antifreeze. The RSPCA is appealing to residents to ensure that pesticides and chemicals, particularly antifreeze, are stored safely to prevent further poisonings.

The Greek government, led by Syriza, is set to implement further austerity and liberalization measures as mandated by creditors, despite previously opposing such measures. Despite this, there have been no protests on the streets of Athens, and Greece's resorts are bustling with tourists. The calm may be due to the anticipation of the announcement of the terms of the new bailout deal, which will provide €86 billion of new credit to Greece. The Greek government's near-death experience in July, with the closure of banks and the collapse of economic activity, may have led Syriza to become disciples of TINA ("there is no alternative"). Despite failing to deliver an end to fiscal austerity and causing monetary austerity, Syriza remains popular. The new bailout deal may only hold if Syriza can offer hope of better times ahead, and creditors may need to ease the burden of Greece's unsustainably large debts.

Ross Kemp will return to EastEnders for a brief appearance to reunite the Mitchell brothers with their mother, Peggy, played by Barbara Windsor, for her final episodes. Peggy's character, who left in 2010, returned on Friday to tell her son Phil that her cancer had returned and will be killed off in emotional scenes to be screened in the spring. Kemp, who played Grant from 1990-1999 and again in 2005 and 2006, said it was an opportunity he could not turn down and that it felt right for the Mitchell brothers to be reunited with their mother for the last time. EastEnders executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins said it was an opportunity to show Ross Kemp and Steve McFadden at their very best.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon was convicted of the murder of Alice Ruggles, whom he had stalked before fatally attacking her last October. Alice's parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, recounted the moment they learned of her death and their immediate suspicion of Dhillon. Dr. Hills expressed guilt for having reassured Alice that the police were aware of the situation and that ignoring Dhillon would resolve the issue, only to realize the gravity of the situation after her death. The family has since established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking, aiming to remember Alice for her vibrant personality and positive spirit. Dhillon, 26, was sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison.

The UK government has delayed its final decision on the Hinkley Point C nuclear power plant project, despite EDF's approval of the £18 billion investment. The project, which aims to provide 7% of the UK's electricity, has faced criticism for potential environmental damage, escalating costs, and foreign government involvement. The government's delay has raised concerns about the UK's energy supply and climate commitments. EDF's financial capacity has also been questioned, with some executives resigning over the project's risks. Environmentalists argue for more investment in renewable energy.

The newly-designed divorce application form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person with whom the spouse has committed adultery. Family lawyers argue that involving a third party adds conflict and complexity to the process. The Ministry of Justice clarified that there is no obligation to name the third party. However, the form's design may encourage applicants to fill in the name, potentially increasing conflict. Naming the third party makes them part of the court case, leading to potential delays and additional costs if they do not respond. The form's guidance states that naming the third party is not normally necessary, but some lawyers fear that most applicants will not read the fine print.

The Welsh forestry industry faces a conflict between environmental policies and commercial forestry needs. While ministers emphasize native broadleaf species and recreational access, the timber industry, worth over £450 million annually, has lost 16,000 hectares of commercial forest since 2001. Confor advocates for re-planting to meet demand, but bureaucratic hurdles and environmental concerns hinder progress. The Welsh government seeks a balanced approach through schemes like Glastir, aiming for high-quality woodlands that benefit the environment, economy, and society. However, the current rate of new woodland creation falls short of long-term targets, impacting the timber industry's potential growth.

A boy was seriously injured after being struck in Coatbridge. Emergency crews were called to the scene on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School at about 16:40. The boy was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is believed to be serious.

The Arctic Convoys of World War II were a series of maritime missions that traveled from Britain to northern Russia to resupply the Soviet Union. The convoys faced constant threats from German U-boats and aircraft, as well as severe weather conditions. By May 1945, the Arctic route had claimed 104 merchant and 16 military vessels, with thousands of Allied seamen losing their lives. The Russian Embassy intended to award the veterans with the Medal of Ushakov in 2012, but the Foreign Office initially blocked the move due to rules stating British soldiers could not receive a foreign medal for an act that occurred more than five years ago. However, an exception was made, and President Vladimir Putin presented the first medals during his visit to London in 2013. The Ushakov medal is awarded to sailors who have displayed courage in defending Russia or its interests.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation report highlighted significant issues with the enforcement and organization of community payback sentences, including delays in offenders starting their work and leniency when they failed to attend. Inspectors reviewed 100 cases and interviewed 86 offenders, leading to 15 recommendations for improvement. Problems included offenders not being adequately punished for non-attendance and a lack of focus on rehabilitation. Despite some positive feedback on the quality of work and offenders gaining skills, the report called for urgent action to address these shortcomings. The Ministry of Justice has accepted the recommendations and is working to improve the system.

The paper ran a front-page headline calling the comedian a "hypocrite" because he campaigns for economic and political "revolution" to help poorer people, yet he lives in a luxury home. It's an accusation often made against the star. How can such a rich man claim to speak up for the poor? Viewers of Brand's vlogs - The Trews - are familiar with the inside of his spacious London home. It looks lovely and airy. It has wooden floors and exposed brickwork. When the St Trinian's star was outside the prime minister's Downing Street home - supporting a campaign by residents of an east London estate who fear they will be turfed out of their homes to allow richer renters to move in - Brand was asked about his own accommodation by a TV reporter. "Part of the problem is the super-rich buying property in London, isn't it? What kind of rent are you paying?" Brand wasn't very happy with the question. He called the Channel 4 News journalist "a snide", before walking off. Newsbeat contacted Brand to see if he was really going to take legal action against The Sun and its owner Rupert Murdoch. He didn't reply, though he has been tweeting about The Sun and it's accusations of hypocrisy - using the hashtag #TheSunLogic. The star's been condemned as a hypocrite plenty of times before. Here's how he's explained it in the past. "Don't think I'm unaware of the inevitability of such a charge. I know, I know. I'm rich, I'm famous, I have money... There is no doubt that I as much as anyone have to change. "Revolution is change. I believe in change, personal change most of all. Know, too that I have seen what fame and fortune have to offer and I know it's not the answer. "Of course I have to change as an individual and part of that will be sharing wealth, though without systemic change, that will be a sweet, futile gesture." "I can't deny that I've done a lot of daft things while I was under the capitalist fugue, some silly telly, soppy scandals, movies better left unmade. "It's easy to attack me, I'm a right twerp, I'm a junkie and a cheeky monkey, I accept it, but that doesn't detract from the incontrovertible fact that we are living in a time of huge economic disparity and confronting ecological disaster." "Now I'm rich and I complain about inequality they say I'm a hypocrite. I'm beginning to think they just don't want inequality on the agenda because it is a real problem that needs to be addressed." "A system that has posited me on a lilo made of thighs in an ocean filled with honey and foie gras'd my Essex arse with undue praise and money. "The hypocrisy ... is a problem that can be taken care of incrementally."

Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, is known for his significant contributions to genomics and synthetic biology. He played a key role in accelerating the mapping of the human genome, which was completed in 2001. His methods, including the use of messenger RNA to identify active genes, revolutionized the field but also brought criticism for their unorthodox nature. After leaving the NIH in 1992, he founded The Institute for Genomic Research and later Celera Genomics, where he led the effort to sequence the human genome. In 2006, he established the J. Craig Venter Institute, which created the world's first synthetic life form, an organism named Synthia. Dr. Venter's work has been both praised for its innovation and criticized for its commercial and competitive nature. He has also pursued environmental projects, such as sequencing marine microbial genomes, aiming to address environmental issues and reduce dependence on oil.

The study found that four out of five children in England who ate school lunches had tried food at school that they had not tried at home. Half of the parents surveyed said their children had asked for foods they had eaten at school to be cooked at home. The survey, which included about 1,000 parents, revealed that the most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were among the least popular. The research was commissioned by England's School Food Trust after a survey by the Mumsnet website suggested that some parents gave their children packed lunches because they thought they were too fussy to eat anything else. The Trust's chairman, Rob Rees, stated that school meals can be a great way to encourage children to try new foods and increase the variety of foods in their diet. Mumsnet co-founder Carrie Longton mentioned that getting children to eat healthily is every parent's dream, but meal times at home can often be a battleground. She also noted that once at school, there's a desire to fit in with everyone else and some positive peer pressure to boast about the variety of foods they can eat. School meals in England now have to comply with strict nutritional guidelines, and about four in 10 primary school children in England now eat school lunches, slightly more than in secondary schools. More children in Scotland eat school lunches, about 46%. The survey was conducted online between February 26 and March 5 among a panel of parents who had at least one child in school aged 4-17 years old.

Morata, a 23-year-old striker for Spain at Euro 2016, joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid. The transfer included an option for Real to buy him back for a reported fee of up to 30 million euros. Morata has scored three goals for Spain in France and 27 goals in two years for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He played in back-to-back Champions League finals, appearing as a substitute in Real's 2014 win and scoring in Juventus' 3-1 defeat by Barcelona in 2015. Morata came through the ranks at Real, making his first-team debut at 18 and scoring 10 goals for the La Liga side.

Wilson, a 30-year-old player, rejoined Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013. He was released in May and has been without a team since. Wilson made 51 appearances in his second spell at the City Ground, having spent four seasons at the club before signing for Celtic. He has also previously played for Preston North End and Notts County.

The British supermarket giant Tesco, the world's third-largest retailer, is selling its loss-making US food chain Fresh & Easy to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity company. Around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business, and Tesco will loan the new business around £80m. The remaining 50 shops will be closed, costing Tesco £150m to dispose of the Fresh & Easy brand. If Yucaipa is successful and the business becomes profitable, Tesco has the option to buy a stake. Tesco reported its first fall in annual profits for 20 years in April.

The passage discusses an athlete who initially faced racial abuse but overcame it and is now aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. It also mentions that the athlete briefly considered representing France. Additionally, it provides a link to a guide on how to get into martial arts.

The ice fields in the French Alps have significantly decreased in size over the past 40 years. In the late 1960s/early 1970s, the ice fields covered about 375 sq km, but by the late 2000s, this area had fallen to about 275 sq km, representing an average loss of 26%. The retreat is not uniform across the French Alps, with the greatest losses seen in the southern sectors. The northern region, including the largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace, has seen less retreat. The new French Alps glaciers inventory was produced by Marie Gardent and colleagues, using map archives, past satellite imagery, and aerial photographs. Manual inspection was used to verify the satellite data. The retreat is attributed to lower elevation and different climatic conditions in the southern Alps. Efforts to assess and monitor glacier health are ongoing across the Alpine region.

Scotland's women's football team, unbeaten in their qualifiers, faces a crucial match against Iceland at Falkirk Stadium. A win would significantly boost their chances of qualifying for the finals in the Netherlands, avoiding the play-offs. Iceland, ranked one place above Scotland, is also unbeaten, making the upcoming matches pivotal. The team, featuring players from top leagues worldwide, benefits from the diverse experiences and competitiveness these leagues offer.

Stuart Campbell, a Scottish independence campaigner and founder of the Wings Over Scotland blog, was arrested in the west of England following a harassment complaint from a woman in south London. The alleged harassment took place over two years and involved tweets from Campbell's Twitter account. Campbell, who was released on bail, denied the tweets were threatening and accused the media of encouraging wild speculations. He stated that the tweets were still publicly visible and not deleted. Campbell has been bailed pending further inquiries to a date in mid-September.

People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) has proposed replacing Skegness's Jolly Fisherman mascot with a fish mascot and the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice." PETA argues that the current mascot evokes images of cruelty to animals, while the new mascot would rebrand Skegness as a progressive holiday destination. However, the mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, believes that the Jolly Fisherman is loved by both adults and children and does not portray animal cruelty. He stated that the mascot is accepted as happy and friendly and does a wonderful job for Skegness. The proposal will be considered by the council, but the mayor believes that if it isn't broken, there is no need to fix it.

Scotland secured a convincing victory over Georgia in a match marked by dominant possession and clinical finishing. Despite an early try by Georgia's Vasil Lobzhanidze, Scotland quickly took control, scoring through Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg to lead comfortably at halftime. Hamish Watson extended the lead early in the second half, and Hogg added another after a brilliant counter-attack. Georgia managed two tries, both from powerful scrums, but Scotland's overall control and effective counter-attacking play ensured a comprehensive win. Coach Vern Cotter praised the team's pragmatic approach and improving game management.

Widnes secured a 38-28 victory over Castleford, despite a late comeback from the Tigers. Widnes led 14-6 at halftime with tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge, while Paddy Flynn scored for Castleford. Flynn scored again early in the second half, but Widnes extended their lead to 38-12 with tries from Ah Van, Lloyd White (2), and Joe Mellor. Castleford fought back with tries from Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Flynn's hat-trick score, but Widnes held on for the win. The victory moved Widnes above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford remains in sixth.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti, was released from Guantanamo Bay after a US review panel concluded he was not a significant threat. He had been detained since 2002 on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, charges he denies. Al-Odah, who had challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court, was flown to Kuwait on a government plane. His release was based on a July decision by Guantanamo's Periodic Review Board, which found his continued detention unnecessary. As part of the release terms, he will spend at least a year in a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait. The Kuwaiti government had been advocating for the release of all Kuwaiti detainees at Guantanamo. Al-Odah's release brings the total number of inmates at the US naval base to 148. The US opened the facility in January 2002, following the 9/11 attacks, and President Barack Obama has repeatedly promised to shut it down.

Thousands attended the early morning Anzac Day service at Hyde Park Corner, with up to 400 people participating in a parade before the wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. Anzac Day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One. A service was also held at Westminster Abbey, where the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia were sung. The first Anzac Day commemoration in the capital was in 1916, a year after the Anzac landings at Gallipoli.

Alexander Downer, Australian high commissioner to the UK, addressed the crowds at the dawn service, reflecting on the courage and heroism of the Anzac troops. Members of veterans' associations, service and ex-service personnel, and their families took part in the parade at the Cenotaph. Crowds, including Australia and New Zealand ex-pats, lined the streets to watch the ceremony, which featured prayers read by schoolchildren and the national anthems of all three countries.

The eight-month campaign on the Gallipoli peninsula in Turkey was one of the bloodiest of the war, and the allied operation was an attempt to force the Ottoman Empire out of the war.

Clarkson, 30, joined Premiership Well for a second spell in July and could make his St Mirren debut in the Championship against Alloa on Saturday. He scored nine goals at Dundee last season and has mainly featured as a substitute this term. Clarkson has made almost 400 senior appearances at club level, including stints at Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. He has been capped twice for Scotland and scored one international goal. St Mirren are currently eighth in the Championship, seven points clear of bottom side Alloa.

The turkey firm was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan on Tuesday. There were concerns about the new owners not taking on the existing workers' pension scheme, but Unite regional officer Steve Harley confirmed that all current agreements will be honored after productive talks. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004, and members now have an alternative pension scheme that is unaffected by the takeover. The Boparan Private Office confirmed that the current pension arrangements with Bernard Matthews would continue under the new ownership. Harley met with representatives from Boparan at the Great Witchingham headquarters, where it was made clear that the new owner wishes to restore Bernard Matthews to its former position as a highly profitable business through greater investment, cost savings, and utilizing the present spare capacity to process chicken and not just turkeys.

The council discussed the issues surrounding the new chain ferry at a scrutiny meeting. The council leader, Dave Stewart, announced that the crossing at Cowes would be free until July 2 to allow feedback and recognize the problems. He also mentioned that the council had ordered a review of the project by auditors. The ferry has faced several issues since its launch, including breakdowns, running aground, and suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training issues. Cars have also been damaged while getting on and off the ferry. Shopkeeper Angie Booth expressed concerns about the impact on local businesses and asked about compensation. Transport councillor Ian Ward stated that compensation was up for discussion and addressed the issues, mentioning that they were teething problems and had been resolved.

The House of Lords European Union Committee has released a report highlighting the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry post-Brexit. While the industry sees Brexit as an opportunity to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation, the report warns that continued market access to the EU may come at the cost of allowing EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters. The report also emphasizes the need to retain elements of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) and ensure that quotas are based on scientific advice. Additionally, the report raises concerns about the potential for four different fisheries management regimes in the UK post-Brexit. Despite these challenges, many in the fishing industry remain optimistic about the future, with some seeing Brexit as an opportunity for fairer shares in catching opportunity and better fisheries management.

Timothy Geaney, a 69-year-old teacher, was removed from the professional register and prohibited from re-applying for two years after admitting to taking or permitting the taking of images of young boys in erotic poses between April 2004 and February 2014. He was sentenced to a community payback order and required to participate in a special program for sex offenders. The General Teaching Council Scotland hearing found his conduct fundamentally incompatible with being a registered teacher and noted a strong likelihood of recurring offending behavior.

Firefighters spent several days at the site in Duncan Street following a fire on 2 March, which reduced train services and caused travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the fire. The firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, the fire service said. Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited, whose site was run by Asset and Land Group, could not be contacted for a comment. It has until 7 August to appeal the decision. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) visited the premises nine times in the last 12 months. Geoff Harris, GMFRS area manager, said: "The site operators, Asset and Land, have been broadly compliant with fire safety legislation throughout that time." The fire service raised concerns to the EA in February over the impact a fire could have on nearby residents, transport, and the environment. The EA were very interested in our concerns, which resulted in our fire safety officers conducting joint visits to the site with EA staff, the EA decided to take enforcement action against the site operators," Mr Harris said. An EA spokesman said: "After consideration of all the facts relating to the company and the site, the EA has now decided to revoke the environmental permit." Subject to any appeal, the revocation takes effect on 7 August, which means after that date the company will no longer be able to operate from that site. The company is still required to remove all the waste. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Syria missed the deadline to hand over its chemical weapons stockpile, citing attacks on shipments by "terrorist groups." Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad defended the government's actions, denying the use of barrel bombs and accusing the US of supporting terrorists. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported civilian casualties from barrel bomb attacks in Aleppo, while state media denied rebel control of Aleppo's central prison. The OPCW oversees the chemical weapons destruction, slowed by security concerns, with a new deadline for removal set for March 1.

England leveled the series with a dominant win over Pakistan at Old Trafford, securing victory with a day to spare. Joe Root, promoted to number three, was named man of the match for his outstanding performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second. He also contributed with four catches and a wicket. England's captain, Alastair Cook, praised Root's performance, describing it as "as good an innings as I've seen."

Coach Trevor Bayliss commended Root's hard work and determination, while former England batsman Geoffrey Boycott highlighted the team's overall quality and discipline. Despite the convincing win, Michael Vaughan believes the series will be tightly contested. Pakistan's captain, Misbah-ul-Haq, expressed disappointment in his team's performance, citing poor shot selection and a lack of confidence.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She will gather evidence from pensioners, their friends, and families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will highlight both good and poor care and its impact on older people. The commissioner will assess factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Care providers, social care staff, and public bodies will also be consulted. The chair of Care Forum Wales, Mario Kreft, expressed support for the review but criticized the lack of a provider expert on the main advisory panel.

Paul Sheerin, a former Dons midfielder and player-manager at Arbroath since 2010, has been appointed as the new manager at Aberdeen, replacing Neil Cooper. Despite Arbroath's relegation to Scottish League Two in the 2013-14 season, Sheerin's achievements, including winning the Scottish Third Division title and promotion in 2011, caught the attention of Aberdeen's chief executive Duncan Fraser and manager Derek McInnes. Sheerin, who played for several Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden, also won a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will take charge of Swansea's match against Bournemouth after Bob Bradley's sacking. Swansea wants to appoint a new boss as soon as possible, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement as the first choice. Curtis believes the club has lost its way since Michael Laudrup left in 2014, with a change of management and a loss of the 'Swansea Way.' He thinks the current squad is good enough to stay up and reminds every new signing of how far the club has come.

Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, is known for his significant contributions to genomics and synthetic biology. He played a key role in accelerating the mapping of the human genome, which was completed in 2001. Despite facing criticism for his methods and commercial approach, his work has undeniably sped up the process of genomic research. After this achievement, he focused on creating synthetic life, leading to the development of an organism called Synthia, detailed in the journal Science.

Born in 1946, Dr. Venter's early life was marked by a lack of academic interest until he was drafted into the Vietnam War in 1967. His experiences as a naval orderly during the Tet offensive inspired him to pursue medicine and instilled in him a sense of urgency. Excelling in research during his medical training, he became involved in molecular biology and gene decoding. His innovative approach to gene sequencing, focusing on messenger RNA, allowed him to achieve unprecedented speeds in gene sequencing.

In 1995, he unveiled the first complete genome of a free-living organism, Haemophilus influenzae. In 1998, he announced the formation of Celera Genomics to decode the human genome in just three years, a task that the public project was aiming to complete in ten years. Both projects published their results in 2001. His commercial approach and disregard for traditional scientific conventions brought him both criticism and financial success.

In 2006, he founded the J. Craig Venter Institute, which spearheaded the creation of the world's first synthetic life form. Alongside this, he has conducted a genetic treasure hunt, collecting and sequencing microbes from the oceans to better understand gene evolution and function. His work on synthetic life, announced as a potential new industrial revolution, aims to create microbes that could help reduce dependence on oil and mitigate environmental damage by capturing carbon dioxide.

The Sutton Trust warns that many apprenticeships in England are of low quality and too short, hindering economic competitiveness and young people's job prospects. The report by the Boston Consulting Group reveals that fewer than 20% of employers offer apprenticeships, compared to over 50% in Germany. Most apprenticeships are below level three (A-level equivalent) and target older workers, leaving 11 young people competing for each position. The report calls for a radical expansion of apprenticeships, prioritizing level three and above, and improving careers advice and guidance. The Department for Education is reforming apprenticeships to drive up standards, with plans to be published later this month.

The Briton won the race in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing more than two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. She can win a 17th title in Saturday's road race. Storey, who is targeting further Paralympic success at next year's Games in Rio de Janeiro, is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals. She has won 11 gold, eight silver, and three bronze medals in both cycling and swimming across six Paralympics. Storey won four golds at the 2012 Games in London and has now won 21 world titles across both sports. She began her sporting career in the pool, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics before switching to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United has been expelled from the Football Conference due to their failure to meet financial obligations, including a debt of £148,000 to football creditors. Despite multiple extensions, the club, now under new ownership by Tommy Agombar, could not meet the final deadline of 12 June. This decision comes after a dramatic final day of the season where Hereford narrowly avoided relegation, only to be reinstated later. The club's financial troubles have been exacerbated by falling attendance and debts totaling £225,000. An offer from the Hereford United Supporters' Trust to buy the club for £1 and clear its debts was not accepted, leading to the eventual takeover by Agombar. The expulsion marks a sad turn for Hereford, with players who fought hard to keep the team in the Conference Premier seeing their efforts come to naught.

James Milner, a former Manchester City player, has retired from international football after winning 61 caps for England. He made his senior debut in 2009 and was a squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships, but only played for three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player, with 46 caps after his first appearance in 2004. He scored his first and only international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova during the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and influential figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after an illness lasting several months. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service planned for a later date. Hogwood founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directed it across six continents for 30 years, producing over 200 CDs, including the first-ever complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. His 1980 recording of Handel's Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson was named one of the top 20 recordings of all time by BBC Music Magazine. Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge and with notable musicians like Zuzana Ruzickova and Gustav Leonhardt. He held various positions, including artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, and was a tutor at Harvard and an honorary professor at Cambridge. Tributes from colleagues and friends highlight his generosity, intellect, and significant contributions to music.

The boy, from Northern Ireland, has been out of school since June due to not coping in mainstream education. His parents requested a place in a special school, but all schools in the South Eastern Education Board area are full. The family was told an extra classroom assistant has been employed at a local special school, and they hope their son can start there soon. However, the boy's mother is concerned about the capacity of the special needs school system. The Education Authority stated they cannot comment on individual cases and are reviewing the need for special school places in Northern Ireland.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) has made a bid to take over Newport Gwent Dragons, with a vote scheduled for May 9th. The WRU plans to install an artificial surface at Rodney Parade, which is against Football League rules. However, Newport County, who have a lease to use the ground until 2023, expect their contract to be honored. The WRU has been made aware of this, and both County and Newport Squash Club are protected under their current agreements. On the pitch, County are two points clear of the League Two relegation zone with two games remaining and can secure survival this weekend if they win and rivals Hartlepool lose. Relegation to the National League would be a "massive" blow for the fans and the city of Newport.

The passage recounts the life of a former child soldier in Sierra Leone who, after being abducted by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) during the civil war, endured horrific experiences, including forced drug use and violence. After escaping and finding support from a preacher, he turned his life around and became involved in community rebuilding efforts. During the Ebola crisis, he played a key role in educating communities, providing support, and setting up treatment units, saving many lives despite the challenges and dangers. He now focuses on investing in young people, believing in their potential to change the world.

The Wedgwood Museum's collection of 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs was at risk of being auctioned to pay off the pension debt of the collapsed pottery firm, Waterford Wedgwood plc. However, a public fundraising campaign led by the Art Fund successfully raised the necessary funds in just a month. The collection will remain on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, and will be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum before being loaned back to the Wedgwood Museum. The successful campaign was praised by administrators, museum representatives, and politicians, who highlighted the importance of preserving the collection for its cultural and historical significance.

Billericay, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, has been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is investing £10,000 a week in the club. The club recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky. There are reports that Mark Wright, a former non-league football player and runner-up in I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, may buy 20% of the club and become a director, although the details of the deal have not yet been released.

Blackpool and Colchester United played to a 1-1 draw in a match marked by missed opportunities and dramatic saves. Blackpool took the lead in the 12th minute with a goal from Jamille Matt, assisted by Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalized in the 17th minute through Kurtis Guthrie after a goalmouth scramble. Both teams had chances to win, with Blackpool's Tom Aldred missing a crucial header and Colchester's George Elokobi and Guthrie coming close in the first half. The match ended with Colchester reduced to 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle in injury time.

The Fawley power station chimney, standing at 198 meters, is set to become the tallest attraction south of London's Shard as the centerpiece of a £1 billion "merchant city" development by Fawley Waterside. The oil-fired power station, capable of powering one million homes, was commissioned in 1971 and closed in 2013 after over 40 years of operation. The 300-acre site, sold to Fawley Waterside in 2016, will feature a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The development plans include a petal-shaped glass structure, with building expected to start in 2018 following an application for outline planning permission later this year.

The 23-year-old Latham secured a bronze medal for Great Britain at the Hong Kong championships, marking GB's second medal after Elinor Barker's silver in the women's scratch. Latham chased down Adrian Teklinski of Poland, who won gold, and Lucass Liss of Germany, who got silver. In the men's team pursuit, GB was beaten to the bronze medal by Italy.
