Paul Merson and Andros Townsend have reignited their row after Townsend was brought on in the 83rd minute of Tottenham's 0-0 draw with Burnley. Merson initially criticized Townsend's call-up to the England squad, but later admitted he was wrong after Townsend scored a stunning equalizer for England against Italy. However, Merson couldn't resist having another dig at Townsend after his appearance for Tottenham against Burnley. Townsend hit back at Merson on Twitter after scoring for England, but any bad feeling between the pair seemed to have passed.

Chelsea has made a formal offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward, Yoshinori Muto, with a view to acquiring him in the summer. The Japan international, who recently graduated with an economics degree from Keio University, has scored 16 goals in 37 appearances for FC Tokyo since 2013 and has earned 11 caps for his country. If the move goes through, Muto will join Chelsea's Dutch partner club, Vitesse Arnhem, on loan next season. The £4 million deal is not connected to Chelsea's £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber, which will become the club's official shirt sponsor from the start of the 2015-16 season. Muto has expressed his honor at receiving the offer but has not yet decided whether to join the Premier League title chasers.

A large-scale study has found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. The Finnish researchers compared the weight and height of over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds with records of antibiotic prescriptions. They found that one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese by the age of two, and children who had taken antibiotics as young babies were particularly likely to be overweight. Repeated prescriptions before the age of two also raised the odds of being overweight. Boys seemed particularly prone to weight gain after being given antibiotics and were also slightly taller than boys who hadn't been given the drugs. The study didn't prove that antibiotics caused weight gain, but if they do, it may be because they kill off gut bugs that would normally feed on some of the food eaten, freeing up more food for the body. Killing certain gut bugs may also increase appetite. The lead author warned that antibiotic exposure before six months of age or repeatedly during infancy was associated with increased body mass in healthy children, and such effects may play a role in the worldwide childhood obesity epidemic. The study comes amid growing concern that the over-prescription of antibiotics is leading to the pills losing their power and making common infections harder to treat.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard, causing him to drop his rifle and knock his bearskin. The incident, which was caught on camera by a tourist, left the guard embarrassed as he quickly got up and realized how many people had seen his fall. The guard is believed to have slipped due to metal protectors on his boots. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

The iconic 1977 miniseries "Roots," which chronicled the life of African-American slave Kunta Kinte and his descendants, is being remade by A&E Networks for a 2016 release. The new version, described as "original" and "contemporary," will draw more from Alex Haley's classic novel and will be simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History. LeVar Burton, who portrayed Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the remake. Producers will consult scholars in African and African-American history for added authenticity. The new "Roots" will encounter a new generation of viewers who have witnessed Barack Obama make history as the nation's first African-American president and "12 Years a Slave" win the Oscar for Best Picture, but also widespread racial unrest over police treatment of black suspects in many U.S. cities.

Police are investigating claims by Christopher Lawler, a former royal footman, that he was sexually assaulted by palace aides on his first day of work at Clarence House in 1978. Lawler alleges that he was accosted by two men, one of whom was a senior staff member, who attempted to undress him and perform sexual acts on him. He managed to escape but was followed and threatened to keep quiet. Lawler reported the incident to Clarence House but was met with an angry response, prompting him to leave the job immediately. He was haunted by the incident for years and decided to contact the Palace again last year after hearing about investigations into historical cases of child abuse. His complaints were initially ignored but were eventually passed on to Scotland Yard. A retired royal aide, now in his 80s, was interviewed but denied involvement. The Palace has stated that it will cooperate fully with the police investigation.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy through a rap video set to the theme song of the '90s sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, which has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube, features the couple rapping about their journey to parenthood. They share their excitement and the reactions of their family and friends. The video ends with the couple sharing a sonogram of their unborn child. The couple made the video for loved ones living far away, and its success was unexpected. The couple is considering making another video after finding out the gender of their child.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at auction. The outfit, a jacket and full skirt ensemble, was featured in several key scenes of the movie but has faded from its original slate blue-gray color to light gray over the years. The dress was part of a private collection of more than 300,000 pieces of memorabilia amassed by James Tumblin, formerly in charge of the hair and makeup department at Universal Studios. Tumblin acquired the dress for $20 from the Western Costume Company, where it was about to be thrown away. Other top-selling items from the auction included a straw hat worn by Leigh, which sold for $52,500, and the trousers and jacket from a suit worn by Clark Gable as Rhett Butler, which sold for $55,000.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents allegedly dangled him over the edge. The boy was rescued by his parents and taken to the hospital with minor injuries. The cheetahs did not approach the boy or his parents. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family.

A speed camera in Birmingham, West Midlands, has been turned to face a house after being decommissioned two years ago. The camera, which used to enforce the 30mph speed limit, is one of around 300 that were switched off in March 2013 due to obsolete technology. The local council is aware of the issue and plans to take action, but the camera will not be part of a new pilot using digital technology. The owners of the house were unavailable for comment.

Usain Bolt will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3. Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medalist, expressed his excitement about being part of the Jamaican team and his readiness to run. He also emphasized Jamaica's strong relay tradition and his commitment to making his country proud. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle confirmed Bolt's availability and anticipated sprint magic from him at the event. The full Jamaican team list will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves demonstrated their commitment to Barcelona by attending the basketball team's Euro League match against Real Madrid, which Barcelona won 85-80. Neymar's sister Rafaella also joined them. Despite this victory, Real Madrid remains at the top of their Euro League division. Neymar had previously led Brazil to a 1-0 win over Chile at the Emirates Stadium, enduring several harsh challenges during the match. Before the international break, Barcelona had secured a 4-point lead in La Liga with a win in El Clasico. They will resume their campaign against Celta Vigo as they aim for a treble of trophies.

Italy is experiencing a surge in migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe, with over 8,000 rescued between Friday and Monday. The Italian coast guard received distress calls from 20 boats on Monday alone. However, there are concerns about a ship carrying 550 people that reportedly capsized off the Libyan coast, with 400 migrants feared missing. Despite search efforts, no evidence of the capsized boat has been found. The International Organization for Migration reports that over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy in the first three months of 2015, with most coming from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit country. At least 480 migrants have died this year due to bad weather, overcrowded vessels, and abandonment by smugglers.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased that Alexis Sanchez, who has scored 19 goals this season, chose to join Arsenal over Liverpool. Wenger believes that Sanchez's quick adaptation to a new environment proves his quality. Wenger also played down speculation linking him with Liverpool winger Raheem Sterling.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break the UCI Hour Record at London's Olympic Velodrome on June 7. The current record, set by Australian Rohan Dennis, stands at 52.491km. Wiggins, who finished his Team Sky career at the Paris-Roubaix race, will ride in the Tour de Yorkshire before preparing for the Hour Record. The event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports, and tickets will be available for purchase from April 19. Wiggins aims to set a record that will stand for a long time and motivate others to challenge themselves.

Serena Williams, the world No. 1 and two-time French Open champion, struggled to defeat Sara Errani in the Fed Cup play-off on Sunday. Despite winning 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3, Williams admitted that the match was a wake-up call for her as she prepares for the claycourt season. She acknowledged that she needs to adjust her game to the clay surface and be prepared to hit a lot of shots. The US team was ultimately defeated 3-2, with Williams and Alison Riske losing in the doubles rubber to Errani and Flavia Pennetta. This defeat resulted in the US being relegated to World Group II. US captain Mary Joe Fernandez emphasized the need for the team to work harder and expressed hope for future success.

River Plate is interested in signing Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao, who previously played for the Argentine club before leaving for Porto in 2009. Despite his struggles on loan at Manchester United, scoring only four Premier League goals this season, Falcao has been in good form for Colombia, equaling the country's all-time goalscoring record with 24 goals. River Plate's vice president, Matias Patanian, expressed the club's desire to bring Falcao back, stating, "We dream of Falcao Garcia. The doors are open." Falcao scored 34 goals in 90 appearances for River Plate during his four seasons with the first team.

Ella Henderson, the X Factor finalist and pop star, has been announced as the face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson in various hairstyles, including a tousled half-ponytail and a wavy style, against a blurred city background. The partnership between the platinum award-winning artist and the UK's number 1 dry shampoo brand was facilitated by the MILES agency and launched with a TV advertising campaign featuring Henderson's latest single, Mirror Man. Henderson expressed her excitement about working with the brand, which she uses regularly. Mark Hargreaves, CEO of Crown Talent & Media Group, commented on the synergies between the artist and the brand, looking forward to an exciting 2015.

The family and friends of Aaron Siler, a 26-year-old man who was fatally shot by police officer Pablo Torres on March 14, are in shock after a billboard featuring Torres and his dog was erected in Kenosha, Wisconsin. The billboard, which reads "Thank you for your support, Kenosha," was paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association and has been called "disrespectful" by Siler's family and friends. Siler was shot and killed by Torres following a vehicle and foot pursuit, after being confronted by the officer. The shooting occurred just 10 days after Torres shot and wounded a 66-year-old man who was armed with two knives. The investigation into Siler's death is ongoing.

The passage reports on a deadly clash between Iranian border guards and militants near the Pakistan border, resulting in the deaths of eight guards and three militants. The Jaish al Adal group, an anti-Iranian Sunni militant organization, claimed responsibility. Iranian officials criticized Pakistan for not preventing such attacks, while Pakistan condemned the incident and pledged to investigate and bring the perpetrators to justice.

The Japanese government's top military official, Defense Minister Gen Nakatani, stated that the Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered an extraterrestrial unidentified flying object (UFO). Nakatani explained that when the ASDF detects indications of a UFO that could violate Japan's airspace, it scrambles fighter jets for visual observation. He clarified that while they sometimes find birds or other flying objects, there have been no cases of finding a UFO believed to have come from outer space.

The query about extraterrestrial threats and research into alien visitors was posed by flamboyant former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki during an Upper House Budget Committee meeting. Inoki, known for his colossal chin and once-ever-present red scarf, claims to have seen a UFO but admitted he doesn't know if aliens exist. This isn't the first time Japanese politicians have discussed the implications of visitors from another planet; in 2007, then-Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba pondered the legal ramifications of a defense against an invasion from outer space.

A 35-year-old passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after breaking a toilet at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in China. Jin was squatting on the toilet rim, reportedly to avoid contact with the seat due to cleanliness concerns, when it tipped over and shattered. Initially, he told his friends he was squatting but later told the police he was sitting, possibly to avoid paying compensation. Authorities believe the incident was an accident and reminded the public that toilets are for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden camera in her bathroom. The camera was traced back to Rebbie, who is accused of sexually abusing the girl in her home over a four-year period and filming her and others with the hidden camera. Rebbie faces several charges, including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. The investigation began in March when the girl found the camera under the sink in her bathroom. She told investigators that Rebbie had been watching her for years while she undressed and when he believed she was asleep. She also said that from the ages of nine to 13, Rebbie would come into her bedroom while she was sleeping and molest her. Investigators found 41 videos from the hidden camera, 34 of which showed victims as they showered. Rebbie uploaded the videos, some of which included close-up images of children's genitalia, to his computer to view later. The videos were captured over a three- or four-year period. Rebbie admitted to filming several victims, including other juveniles, but had purchased the camera specifically to record the now-15-year-old victim while she undressed and showered. Rebbie's preliminary hearing is on May 1, and he is being held on a $500,000 bail.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama's latest series of images captures po-faced teenagers standing next to their fathers leaping into the air. The daughters look directly into the camera and smile while their fathers pull dramatic poses. The images are from Aoyama's latest book, which roughly translates to Daughter and Salary Man. The photographer's website states that the images allow the fathers, who usually have to act serious, to express their fun side by being "a hero jumping the sky, enfolding strong excitement and hope." The fathers are dressed in sharply tailored suits, while the daughters wear casual clothing. The families pose in front of various Japanese landmarks. Some of the older fathers adopt a pained expression as they make their jump. The images are already generating a lot of interest online for their curious nature.

The dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director has paved the way for Kevin Pietersen's potential return to the international cricket set-up. Pietersen, who was controversially axed by Downton in 2014, has rejoined Surrey in an attempt to force his way back into the Test set-up. The 34-year-old batsman was in a jovial mood as he posed for the Surrey team photo before the start of the new County Championship season. Pietersen, who last featured for England during the disastrous Ashes tour of Australia last year, hopes to regain the urn this summer on home soil.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian club facing relegation, has sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. The former Brazil defender, who played for Inter Milan and Parma, was initially fired after a poor run but was reinstated the next day by owner Angelo Massone. However, after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani, Ze Maria was sacked again, leaving Ceahlaul 16th in the standings, six points from safety. He will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate Nabil Dirar believes the Colombian striker regrets his failed loan move to Manchester United. Despite not being happy in France, Falcao has struggled to replicate his previous form at Old Trafford, scoring only four goals all season. With a £46 million price tag to make the transfer permanent, it is unlikely that United will take up the option. Dirar thinks Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he would have played and participated in the Champions League.

New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a man who robbed a Christchurch dairy while wearing a distinctive cartoon mask. The incident occurred on Saturday around 12:30 PM at a Union St dairy in east Christchurch. The offender, described as very tall and wearing a fluoro orange sweatshirt, demanded cash from the owner's daughter. He fled with the till drawer containing approximately $1,500. No weapons were reported, and the robber remains at large. Police urge anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers at 0800 555 111 or message them online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested for the second time on Monday following allegations of an inappropriate relationship with a 15-year-old student. Granado was first arrested on March 19 after admitting to kissing a 15-year-old student and allowing him to touch her breasts in April of the previous year. She was released on bail and suspended from teaching. Days later, on March 24, a second 15-year-old student accused Granado of having sex with him on two consecutive nights in January. The abuse came to light after a school police officer learned of the possible relationships. Granado was booked into Irving County Jail and released after posting a $50,000 bail. The school district has reassured families that they took immediate and appropriate action, and Granado is on administrative leave, preventing her from working with students or being present on any Irving ISD property.

A video of a crocodile swimming through a public marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its jaws has been viewed over half a million times online. The dog, belonging to the local bike shop owner, was attacked after approaching the water's edge out of curiosity. The crocodile, which is part of a nearby sanctuary, held onto its catch for hours before disappearing. Tourists and locals were shocked by the sight, and social media users expressed horror and dislike towards crocodiles. Puerto Vallarta, built among mangroves, is home to "American Crocodiles" that can grow up to 6 meters long and are increasingly living closer to humans due to urbanization.

Hull City manager Steve Bruce remains confident about avoiding relegation from the Premier League despite a 2-0 loss to Southampton, which left them just two points above the drop zone. Bruce initially targeted 10 wins for survival but now hopes eight or nine might suffice. Hull, who have six games remaining, including tough matches against top teams, have been hindered by long-term injuries to key players. Southampton, meanwhile, moved up to fifth place with the win, but manager Ronald Koeman faces disciplinary issues after a penalty dispute involving Sadio Mane and James Ward-Prowse.

A teacher, Ian Guffick, has been banned from the classroom for at least two years after he let pupils change their SATs exam answers after the exam session had finished, invalidating the whole school's results. Guffick also altered some of the pupil's answers himself before the papers were sent off. The Department for Education annulled all SATs exam results for the school after an investigation by the local education authority found that some pupils had changed answers outside exam conditions and that Guffick had done the same. Guffick was forced to give up his job at the school and had since admitted the allegations and accepted it amounted to unacceptable professional conduct. However, he insisted that he did not ask the pupils to change their answers, but to make them more legible. The panel, run by the National College for Teaching and Leadership, said that no changes of any kind should be made to exam scripts outside test conditions. The panel chair, Martin Pilkington, said that although Guffick's conduct had been dishonest, it fell short of fraud or serious dishonesty. Paul Heathcote, acting on behalf of Education Secretary Nicky Morgan, banned Guffick from the classroom for at least two years. He said that Guffick's actions were deliberate and had a serious impact on the school. Guffick was given 28 days in which to appeal against the decision to the High Court.

Anders Lindegaard, the Manchester United goalkeeper, enjoyed a sunny day with his stunning wife, Misse Beqiri, a Swedish model with Albanian roots. The couple, who have a son together, tied the knot last year in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius. Lindegaard, who has struggled for playing time at Manchester United since joining in 2010, posted a picture on Instagram with the message, "Day off with my sunshine @missebeqiri #cheshire #manchester." Despite his limited appearances on the pitch, Lindegaard is clearly winning off the field.

The iconic glowing blue letters that once adorned Yankee Stadium failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction, despite an estimated value of $300,000 to $600,000. The only bid, for $260,000, came from a Sotheby's employee attempting to initiate the bidding. The letters, which had been a fixture since 1976, were purchased by Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson after the stadium's final game in 2008. Jackson, who attended the auction, bought the letters "on a lark" and expressed a desire for a new generation to own this piece of Yankees and New York City history. In contrast, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 1960s, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has addressed the recent controversies involving Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe, emphasizing the importance of professional responsibilities. Sterling was exposed for inhaling nitrous oxide, and both he and Ibe were pictured with shisha pipes. Rodgers spoke to the players but decided not to discipline them, aiming to move past the incidents. He highlighted the challenges young players face in balancing normal activities with their professional image. Additionally, Rodgers expressed his focus on preparing for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, with captain Steven Gerrard available after a suspension, though he did not confirm if Gerrard would start. He also reflected on the learning process of overcoming setbacks, drawing parallels to successful athletes who have experienced both victories and defeats.

Arsenal midfielder Mesut Ozil, who joined the club from Real Madrid in 2013 for £42.5 million, is in fine form since returning from injury, scoring three goals and providing four assists. He missed Arsenal's last game against Newcastle due to illness but is expected to start against Liverpool. Ozil, who was in fine form as Germany beat Georgia 2-0 in a Euro 2016 qualifier, posted a picture on Twitter of him relaxing with his dog, captioned "Home Sweet Home." He says he is finally adjusting to English football and prefers playing in many matches.

Barcelona's president, Josep Maria Bartomeu, has dismissed rumors about replacing Luis Enrique, expressing satisfaction with the manager's performance. Enrique, who joined last summer on a two-year contract, has led the team to a strong position, competing for three trophies. Bartomeu highlighted Enrique's dedication and the team's impressive form, including a recent victory over Valencia with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Liverpool midfielder Jordan Henderson is set to sign a new long-term contract at Anfield, worth around £100,000-a-week and running until the summer of 2020. Henderson, who has been one of the most improved players under Brendan Rodgers, has contributed 13 assists and seven goals from midfield this season. He is expected to be considered for the role of club captain when Steven Gerrard moves to LA Galaxy. Talks with Raheem Sterling are not expected to resume until the end of the season, but Liverpool's Chief Executive, Ian Ayre, last week said he expected the England forward to be at Anfield for 'a long time'.

Filipe Luis, despite struggling to secure the left-back position at Chelsea and interest from Atletico Madrid to re-sign him, has expressed his desire to stay at Chelsea until the end of his contract. He emphasized his happiness at the club and his commitment to the team's focus and determination to win every game, as stressed by manager Jose Mourinho. With nine challenging games remaining in the Premier League, Luis believes the team is prepared to handle the tough situation and maintain their lead in the title race.

Nathan Hughes's three-match ban for accidentally knocking out George North with his knee during a match on March 27 was overturned on appeal. The Wasps No. 8 was initially suspended for being 'reckless,' but the appeal panel found no act of foul play, as the incident was deemed accidental. North was left unconscious and had to be taken off on a stretcher, marking the third time he had been knocked out in two months. Hughes missed Wasps' Champions Cup quarter-final loss to Toulon but is now free to return to action.

The Pacific Northwest experienced intense red sunsets over the weekend due to smoke from wildfires in southeastern Siberia. The fires, started by farmers burning grass, grew out of control on April 14 due to strong winds, destroying dozens of villages. The smoke was carried across the Pacific Ocean by atmospheric winds and brought to parts of Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The smoke particles filtered out shorter wavelength colors, leaving only red and orange to penetrate the air unfiltered. The colors were especially intense during sunrises and sunsets due to the increased amount of atmosphere the light had to travel through. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve, and the fiery sunsets will lose their reddish hue.

A Missouri woman, Becky Schoenig, had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. The car was later found by police with red rims, red detailing on the sides, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of being upset, Schoenig took to Facebook to thank the car thieves for "pimping out" her vehicle. However, she is now getting the car professionally cleaned due to the strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana. Schoenig is also creating a smoothie at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, to honor the man who located her car and notified police.

Manchester City players will lose £500,000-a-man in bonuses if they fail to qualify for the Champions League this season. The Premier League title holders give star players like Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure incentivized contracts to make sure the club stays within financial fair play requirements. They will miss out on a big payday if City fails to reach the group stages of Europe's top competition. Manuel Pellegrini's team is in fourth place and will be just four points ahead of main rivals Liverpool after defeat in the Manchester derby. The top three finishers in the Premier League qualify automatically for the Champions League, with the fourth-place team required to win a qualifying round to join them. In total, the City squad has around £12 million resting on reaching their European target. Pellegrini has admitted City has let their season disintegrate after starting 2015 joint-top with Chelsea. They have subsequently lost seven times, including early exits in the FA Cup and Champions League.

Manchester United's Under-18s secured a 1-0 victory over Manchester City in the 'mini-derby' at Moss Lane. The match featured 13 English players, 10 of whom were Mancunian. Callum Gribbin scored the winning goal with a free-kick, while Marcus Rashford missed two opportunities. The match was played in front of nearly 1,000 spectators, with free entry. United's formation included three at the back and supporting wingbacks. The result leaves United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while injury-ravaged City have lost both matches in the play-off series. The match showcased the potential of young talents from both sides.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart has praised Italian veteran Gianluigi Buffon as a 'legend of the game' after Buffon earned his 147th cap in a 1-1 draw with England. Hart, who earned his 50th cap in the same match, expressed his admiration for Buffon's longevity and skill, stating that he still has much to learn from the 37-year-old. Hart also celebrated his own milestone, emphasizing his desire to continue representing his country and adding to his international caps.

Chipotle has partnered with the Postmates app to offer delivery services in 67 cities, charging a nine percent service fee and delivery fees starting at $5. This move aligns Chipotle with other chains like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King, which are also exploring or implementing delivery services. The decision comes as Chipotle continues to grow in popularity, with notable political figures like Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton recently spotted dining at their restaurants.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, have written an opinion piece in The Boston Globe urging the Justice Department to take the death penalty off the table for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was convicted on all 30 charges related to the bombings. The Richards argue that years of appeals would prolong their pain and that they want to move forward and rebuild their lives. They stress that they are only speaking for themselves and hope for a better future for their family, Boston, and the country.

The images showcase a custom-built Boeing 747-8, transformed into a luxury home for a billionaire. The £400 million jet, which normally accommodates 600 passengers, now features bedrooms, lounges, a dining room, and an onboard restaurant. The plane includes a master bedroom, a conference room, and an "aeroloft" with eight full beds. The interior, designed by Greenpoint Technologies, resembles a luxury hotel, with a lounge, state room, and a kitchen for a private chef. The plane can carry dozens of guests and is one of the most luxurious private planes ever built.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed cargo spacecraft called Dragon on a flight from Cape Canaveral, Florida, to the International Space Station. The company unsuccessfully attempted to land a rocket stage on a floating barge. SpaceX has said it will keep trying and, after it masters landing at sea, hopes to someday land rockets on the ground. The Dragon will dock with the space station to deliver more than 4,300 pounds of supplies, including research equipment and an espresso maker. The space station crew will spend about five weeks unpacking the Dragon and then stuff it with over 3,000 pounds of science experiments, trash, and other stuff to send back to Earth. When they're done, Dragon will leave the space station and mission controllers will guide it to splashdown in the Pacific Ocean off California. This is the sixth SpaceX mission to the International Space Station.

Priscilla Presley will serve as a witness at the first wedding to be held at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas. The chapel is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit of Elvis Presley's artifacts outside his iconic Memphis, Tennessee, home. The winning couple will be announced next Monday and will tie the knot on Thursday, April 23. Along with the singer's former wife in the audience, the winning couple will win a free wedding reception and hotel suite for two nights. Airfares and concert tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show will also be thrown in. Couples wanting to be the first to wed at the chapel must submit a video or photos along with an explanation detailing why they deserve the prize.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League after a tough season. Liverpool won 2-0 against Newcastle United on Monday night, with Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen scoring the goals. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet played their 47th game of the season, equaling the record for appearances in the top five European leagues. Liverpool is four points behind Manchester City, who lost 4-2 to Manchester United. Henderson thinks Liverpool can put pressure on City and make up ground by continuing to win games.

Roma ended their four-month home winless streak with a 1-0 victory over Napoli in a crucial Serie A match for Champions League qualification. Miralem Pjanic scored the lone goal in the 25th minute, finishing off a swift counter-attack. Goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made several key saves in the second half to preserve the lead. The win moved second-place Roma four points ahead of city rivals Lazio, who play later on Saturday. Napoli, meanwhile, extended their winless streak to five matches and remained in fifth place. The match was played under tight security, with no reports of problems, following a shooting incident involving Napoli fans last season.

Doncaster Rovers and Fleetwood Town played out a goalless draw in a League One match at the Keepmoat Stadium. The match was uneventful, with little action to report. The Doncaster media team faced a challenge in compiling the match highlights, which they condensed into a 27-second video with only 14 seconds of match action. The video included the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

The passage describes a man, Roland Giroux, who has developed a unique bond with his blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid fish first bred in Taiwan in 1986. Despite the usual lack of tactile interaction with marine pets, Giroux strokes and massages his fish, which appears to enjoy the interaction. The fish initially moves away but always returns, even swimming up his arm and circling his fingers. Giroux feeds the fish by hand and spends at least 15 minutes each day interacting with it. The bond developed after he removed two other fish from the tank that were bullying his prized pet. The fish, which becomes frustrated if not played with daily, follows Giroux's hand to the surface when he stops.

Ben Stokes, known for his fiery character, has returned to the England cricket team after a year of ups and downs, including a wrist injury from punching a locker. His aggressive style, as seen in clashes with Marlon Samuels and Mitchell Johnson, is seen as a positive for the team, but he will need careful management to ensure his natural exuberance is not quashed. England wants Stokes to play as much as possible to help him reach his full potential, and while there may be lows along with the highs, his aggression can bring runs and wickets to the team.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12 has sold out, with 33,000 tickets sold. The match, to be played at the Cardiff City Stadium, is crucial as both teams are tied on 11 points in Group B, with Belgium leading on goal difference. Wales' recent 3-0 victory over Israel has boosted expectations for qualification to the 2016 finals in France. The Football Association of Wales has been overwhelmed with ticket demand. Despite interest, the match will not be moved to the larger Millennium Stadium due to UEFA rules. The Welsh team prefers the Cardiff City Stadium, where they last played in 2011.

England's Under-17 squad for the UEFA European Championship in Bulgaria has been announced by coach John Peacock. The defending champions, who qualified with a perfect record, are in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland. Their first match is against Italy on May 7. The squad includes players from several Premier League clubs, such as Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, and Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi, with Willock being called up for the first time. Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold return after missing the Elite Round of qualifiers. The other matches are against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13.

Manchester City is interested in signing 14-year-old playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis from Anderlecht. The Belgian starlet, considered one of the best talents to emerge from Anderlecht's youth set-up, has also attracted attention from Arsenal and Barcelona. He previously rejected a move to Barcelona's La Masia academy at the age of 12 to continue his studies. City has held discussions with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock to agree on a compensation package. Manager Manuel Pellegrini is looking to build for the future by acquiring the promising young talent.

A 33-year-old Mexican national, Vanessa Santillan, was found strangled and beaten to death in a flat in Fulham, south west London, at the end of March. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death but has been bailed and is due to return for further questioning. Scotland Yard is appealing for anyone who may have had contact with Miss Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward. Miss Santillan worked as a transgender escort in London, Paris, and Miami, and spoke of her love for London and Paris online in the weeks before her death.

A woman named Dawn, who has suffered seven miscarriages, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle Show to accuse her long-term friend Jamie of stealing £207 that was set aside for a £500 gravestone for her baby Daniel James. Jamie, a convicted burglar who lives with Dawn and her partner, initially denied the accusation. However, a lie detector test revealed that he had indeed taken the money. Jamie sent a Facebook message to Dawn during the journey to London, confessing to taking the money but blaming it on his girlfriend Carol. Dawn was devastated by the betrayal and burst into tears before storming off the stage.

ISIS released more than 200 Yazidis, a minority group that has long suffered persecution, on Wednesday. Most of those released were women and children; the rest were ill or elderly. The freed Yazidis were received by Peshmerga and sent to the Kurdish regional capital, Irbil. It wasn't immediately clear what motivated Wednesday's release. ISIS previously released scores of other Yazidis -- largely children and the elderly -- since attacking the group's towns last year. The Sunni Islamist militant group steamrolled into Iraq's north last summer, forcing hundreds of thousands of minorities -- Yazidis among them -- from their homes. ISIS' conquest of the town of Sinjar provoked a major humanitarian crisis as some Yazidis fled into the mountains and others fled by foot into neighboring Syria. ISIS slaughtered Yazidis by the hundreds and reports emerged from some Yazidi survivors that ISIS raped and enslaved female Yazidi captives. An international coalition responded, first by airdropping supplies in the mountains. Rescues came next. And then, starting in August, the United States and other nations conducted airstrikes targeting ISIS in Iraq and Syria. The U.S. State Department estimates that 500,000 Yazidis live in northern Iraq, accounting for less than 1% of the country's population.

The passage discusses Harry Kane's remarkable season, highlighting his nominations for the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards. It mentions his animated celebrations on the pitch and his inclusion in a new animation by Copa90, which showcases some of his best goals and celebrations. The video, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', features his long-range strike against Chelsea, a headed goal against Arsenal, and his goal on his England debut. The animation is released ahead of the awards ceremony, where Kane is competing against top players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers should remain as Liverpool's manager despite a season without trophies and a likely finish outside the top four. Carragher, who received a Beacon Award for his community work on Merseyside, emphasized that Rodgers' future should not be determined by one game. He acknowledged the challenges faced by new signings in adapting to the team and expressed hope for improvement next season. Carragher also highlighted his efforts to support underprivileged areas in Liverpool through his 23 Foundation, aiming to inspire and assist youngsters in realizing their goals.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his plastic Nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport after it was deemed a security risk. The toy, which fires sponge darts, was packed in his hand luggage for a family trip to Lanzarote. Security officers, described as "over-zealous" by James's father, Phil Hayward, demanded the toy be handed over and performed a thorough pat-down on the child. Phil criticized the security checks as "ludicrous" and expressed frustration at the delay caused by the incident. After returning from their holiday, James was bought a replacement toy gun. East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience but defended their actions, stating that regulations set by the government prohibit items resembling prohibited items from passing through security.

A 31-year-old man from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, named "Rich" has posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. The ad outlines his preferences and requirements for a potential partner, including being fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, a good cook, and skilled in bed. The successful candidate will receive various benefits, such as accommodation, a company car, phone, and laptop. Rich describes himself as athletic, tattooed, and financially successful, with a love for outdoor activities and a dislike for drinking, smoking, and drugs. He also mentions his willingness to spend money on his partner and states that all reasonable offers will be considered, except from former partners.

The Football Association chairman, Greg Dyke, has proposed increasing the minimum number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12 and changing the definition of 'home-grown' to mean having trained in England for three years before the age of 18, rather than before 21. This proposal is facing opposition from the Premier League. Five former England managers, Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren, have backed Dyke's call, warning that the English game will suffer if the proposals are blocked. They argue that the pool of English talent playing at the top level is shrinking, which is a clear disadvantage for any England manager. However, they also see signs of encouragement with the emergence of a new generation of young players, such as Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane. The former managers believe that these players are not being offered the most important thing: opportunity.

The passage discusses the latest episode of the TV show Poldark, focusing on the birth of Ross and Demelza Poldark's baby daughter. It highlights the rapid progression of Demelza's pregnancy, which is noted by fans for its unrealistic timeline. Despite Ross marrying Demelza out of duty, his deep affection for her is evident. The passage also mentions the public's admiration for Ross Poldark, portrayed by Aidan Turner, and includes a fan's humorous tweet about the show's depiction of pregnancy.

Leicester manager Nigel Pearson has urged his players to focus on their own performance and not worry about their relegation rivals during the run-in. Despite being bottom of the table, Leicester's back-to-back wins, including a 3-2 victory against West Brom, have given them a survival lifeline. Pearson emphasized the importance of staying focused on their own games and not getting caught up in the optimism surrounding their recent results. He believes that as long as they take care of their own performance, they have a realistic chance of survival.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has set a new record for the longest mammal migration ever recorded, traveling nearly 14,000 miles from her feeding ground off Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This journey surpasses the previous record held by a humpback whale. Varvara's trip included visits to three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggesting that she might actually be an eastern gray whale rather than a western gray whale as previously thought. This revelation could have implications for the conservation of western gray whales, as their population is believed to be only around 150.

A 1,000ft stretch of seabed emerged overnight along the coastline of Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu, on Hokkaido Island, Japan, rising as high as 50ft from the sea surface in some places. Geologists believe the emergence was caused by a landslide nearby, when melting ice and snow caused a section of land to drop, pivoting the underwater area into the air. The new stretch of land came as a complete surprise to the locals, as there was no indication of the land movement overnight. Authorities have not been able to determine exactly when the landslide hit the snow-covered coastline, but they do not expect it to expand further.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied claims that he is set to leave Paris Saint-Germain in the summer and instead reiterated his 'love' for the club. The Dutchman recently had a falling out with his boss Laurent Blanc after the decision to drop the full back for the Champions League clash against Chelsea. But Van der Wiel insists he's happy in Paris and is making no plans to leave the Ligue 1 side. He told L'Equipe: 'I am genuinely happy at PSG. 'I love the club, I love the city and I love my team-mates. Everything is perfect for me here. 'There is absolutely no reason for me to leave. I want to sign a new contract. 'If the coach decides not to play me, that is his decision. But I am ready whenever I am called upon.' The Parisians continue to be linked with Barcelona star Dani Alves, so it remains to be seen whether Van der Wiel has any choice in staying with the club.

Carlos Tevez, currently with Juventus, has expressed his desire to return to his former club, Boca Juniors, in Argentina. Although his contract with Juventus runs until 2016, he has asked to leave this summer. Boca Juniors are close to finalizing a deal for the 31-year-old, but club president Daniel Angelici emphasized that Tevez must first terminate his contract with Juventus. Despite Juventus' reluctance to lose their top scorer, they have started looking for potential replacements. Tevez's international manager, Tata Martino, stated that the move would not affect Tevez's future with the Argentina national team.

Bayern Munich's manager, Pep Guardiola, experienced an unexpected wardrobe malfunction during their Champions League match against Porto, tearing a hole in his trousers. This incident occurred during an exciting match where Bayern dominated, winning 6-1 and securing a spot in the semi-finals. Despite the mishap, Guardiola's team's performance was outstanding, with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and a brace from Robert Lewandowski. Porto, who had a two-goal lead from the first leg, were overwhelmed by Bayern's superior play.

A multi-vehicle crash involving three cars occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2 km south of Fernvale, on Wednesday afternoon. Ten people, including four children, were involved. A 40-year-old man with chest and shoulder injuries and a five-year-old boy with chest pain were airlifted to the Princess Alexandra Hospital. A 27-year-old woman with arm injuries and a six-year-old girl with abdominal pain were also airlifted. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for further assessment. A man suffered hand lacerations, and two females escaped injuries. The highway was closed, with diversions in place south of Fernvale. Emergency crews found one person trapped and used hydraulic cutting gear to free them. The Rescue 500 helicopter airlifted several patients to the hospital.

Arsenal midfielder Mesut Ozil is excited about his new Apple Watch, which he received as a gift during a visit to an Apple store. He compared the gadget to Michael Knight's watch from the TV show Knight Rider. Ozil, who has scored four goals in 25 matches for Arsenal this season, is expected to start in the crucial Premier League match against Chelsea on Sunday. Arsenal, currently 10 points behind Chelsea, have been boosted by the return of Jack Wilshere, who was on the bench in their FA Cup semi-final win over Reading. Club legend Ray Parlour believes Wilshere's fitness is the only thing holding him back from reaching his potential in the Arsenal midfield.

Mark Clattenburg will referee the Manchester derby at Old Trafford on Sunday, despite having sent off three players from United and City this season. Clattenburg has only sent off two players in the Premier League this season, both from United. He will be joined by assistants Simon Beck and Jake Collin, while Jonathan Moss will serve as the fourth official. The match could ultimately decide who finishes second behind expected winners Chelsea.

Bob Katter, a federal MP of Lebanese descent, has accused the Queensland Government of assuming that Billy Gordon, a recently accused MP, would resign due to domestic violence allegations and his criminal past. Katter defended his use of the term "black puppet" by citing his personal experiences with racism. He also cited examples of independents becoming government puppets but vowed that Gordon would not make the same mistake. The statement has sparked criticism on social media, with some users questioning his terminology.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois with cerebral palsy, is challenging stereotypes and inspiring others through her dance videos. Despite facing bullying and stares, she aims to change how people with disabilities are represented in media and society. Dayna's videos, including one where she dances to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off," showcase her determination and positivity. She emphasizes that while she may do things differently, she is just like everyone else. Dayna, who was once told she might never walk, now drives, attends college, and has started motivational speaking at local schools.

Orlando City has expressed interest in signing Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who is currently on loan at Real Madrid. The MLS side, coached by Adrian Heath, sees Hernandez as a commercial draw due to their large Latin-American fanbase. However, eight European clubs, including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan, are also interested in the 26-year-old striker. Meanwhile, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old midfielder Andreas Pereira, who has attracted interest from Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord after rejecting United's initial offer.

A group of at least three people set a white Dodge Charger on fire at a South Los Angeles gas station early Saturday morning after an argument with the driver. The suspects attempted to carjack the man, and when he fled, they sprayed the car with gasoline and lit it on fire. The driver and two passengers were not injured, but the car was completely destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, and the suspects remain at large.

A southern Iowa chiropractor, Charles Manuel, has surrendered his state license after admitting to bartering sex for services and performing exorcisms on patients. The Iowa Board of Chiropractic released a report detailing the charges against Manuel, who signed an agreement last month pledging not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years. Despite the charges, Manuel has received outstanding evaluations for patient satisfaction on HealthGrades.com. The agreement requires that Manuel prove any circumstances surrounding the revocation of his license no longer exist before he can resume practicing chiropractic in the state.

The United States has lodged a complaint with Moscow following an incident in which a Russian fighter jet intercepted a U.S. reconnaissance plane in an "unsafe and unprofessional manner" over the Baltic Sea. The U.S. crew reported aggressive maneuvers and high speeds by the Russian pilot. Russia claims the U.S. plane had its transponder switched off, which the U.S. denies. The Pentagon and State Department plan to address the matter through diplomatic channels. Similar incidents have occurred in the past, with the U.S. previously complaining about a close pass by a Russian jet near a U.S. plane over the Sea of Okhotsk. Encounters between Russian and U.S. aircraft are common in Northern Europe and the area between the Russian Far East and Alaska.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his car in the parking lot of the Marriott Springhill Suites in Salt Lake City, just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The rifle was stored in a hard case, secured with padlocks and chains, but the thief broke the rear right passenger-side window, tied a rope around the case, and used another vehicle to rip the case free. The car's window frame was also damaged. The theft occurred overnight on March 27, and while some of the agent's belongings were recovered at a nearby hotel, the rifle remains missing. The Secret Service was notified before Obama's visit, but it's unclear if the theft prompted increased security.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of killing his elderly neighbor, Terrence Freebody, in July 2012. The incident occurred in the dining room of Costa's home on Mugga Way in Red Hill, Canberra. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen examined Costa after the attack and believes there was evidence of the accused's state of mind declining in the lead-up to the incident and also during the event. Professor Mullen told the court that the triple 0 calls which Costa made 'almost certainly' during the incident proved that his mood fluctuated from 'moment to moment.' He also said the trail of feces from the crime scene to the toilet where police found Costa suggested his confused mental state. Professor Mullen believes that at the time of the killing, Mr. Costa's brain was compromised by dementia and that when you add alcohol to this, it led to a confused state. Prosecutor Shane Drumgold suggested that Costa feigned his failing memory while being interviewed by Professor Mullin, who denied these claims. Costa's state of mind is critical to the case, as the jury can return a not guilty verdict if Costa's unstable mindset at the time of the attack can be proven.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley's decision to take a penalty, which was saved by Burnley goalkeeper Tom Heaton, in their 1-0 win at Goodison Park. Despite Leighton Baines' impressive penalty record, Barkley took the 10th-minute kick, awarded for a foul by David Jones on Aaron Lennon. Martinez supported Barkley's decision, stating that he was within his rights to request the duty and that he showed incredible responsibility. The manager also emphasized his preference for having multiple penalty takers and allowing them to decide based on their feelings at the moment. Although Barkley's penalty was well-struck, it wasn't placed in the corner, allowing Heaton to make the save. Fortunately, Kevin Mirallas scored the only goal of the game after 29 minutes, ensuring the miss didn't prove costly.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the ms Ryndam cruise ship in Puerto Rico, in what appears to be a murder-suicide. The cleaning staff discovered the deceased passengers after knocking on the cabin's door. The authorities, including the FBI, were notified and are investigating the incident. The ship left Tampa, Florida, on March 29 on a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise and is currently in San Juan, Puerto Rico.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has led Curacao to the second qualifying round of the 2018 World Cup in CONCACAF. Curacao advanced by drawing 2-2 in the second-leg match at Montserrat, winning 4-3 on aggregate. Kluivert's team had previously won 2-1 in Willemstad. The decisive goal was scored by Charlton Vicento in the 87th minute. Curacao will face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, was a losing semi-finalist in the 1998 World Cup as a player and last year as assistant to coach Louis van Gaal.

Esteban Cambiasso, a seasoned midfielder with an impressive career at clubs like Inter Milan and Real Madrid, has expressed that helping Leicester City avoid relegation would rank among his greatest achievements. Despite Leicester being seven points adrift at the bottom of the Premier League table with only eight games left, Cambiasso remains optimistic about their chances. He likens the challenge of keeping Leicester in the Premier League to winning a trophy, emphasizing the importance of the objective. Cambiasso, who joined Leicester in the summer on a one-year deal, has quickly become a key player and is open to staying beyond his current contract, indicating his satisfaction with life in the East Midlands.

A 23-year-old mother of two, Gemma, faces the risk of being banned from seeing her children by her mother, Debbie, due to her lifestyle of drinking, partying, and suspected theft. Gemma handed over her children to Debbie when they were four months old. Debbie, who has been caring for the children, claims Gemma is unfit to care for them, accusing her of stealing and prioritizing her party lifestyle over her maternal responsibilities. Despite Gemma's denials of some allegations, a lie detector test revealed she did steal. Debbie, frustrated and at her wit's end, is considering banning Gemma from her home and from seeing the children.

During Chelsea's match against Manchester United, Eden Hazard scored a goal, but the Sky Sports pundits believed there was a foul in the build-up. Chelsea captain John Terry made a strong challenge from behind on Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao, causing him to lose the ball. Cesc Fabregas then collected the loose ball and passed it to Oscar, who back-heeled it to Hazard to score. The pundits, including Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness, agreed that Terry's challenge should have been called a foul. Souness described it as a "decent forearm smash" and Henry expressed sympathy for Falcao, saying he would have wanted a foul in that situation. Redknapp admitted that while Falcao could have stayed on his feet, Terry's challenge from behind was still a foul.

Hillary Scott, the co-lead singer of Lady Antebellum, was traveling on a tour bus that caught fire on a Texas freeway Thursday morning. The bus stopped after a rear tire blew out, and everyone on board, including Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver, were safely evacuated. The fire destroyed everything in the bus's back lounge except for Scott's Bible. The band's two other members, Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood, were not on the bus. Lady Antebellum is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards on Sunday in Arlington, Texas.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman is developing a space laser system that converts sunlight into energy using satellites equipped with mirrors. The energy is then transmitted back to Earth as laser light, potentially making solar power viable in regions like Scotland and providing instant power restoration to disaster-hit areas. Initial trials in Scotland were successful, and further trials are planned for Portugal. Unlike the powerful lasers depicted in science fiction, these lasers are not strong enough to cause harm or be weaponized. However, Dr. Quarterman acknowledges the need to consider who controls the satellites.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile with a history of sexual offences against children, has gone missing from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire. He was last seen leaving the hospital at 6:15 pm on Tuesday. Munden, who suffers from learning difficulties and autism, was detained under the Mental Health Act after being convicted of sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus. He has a history of possessing indecent images of children and was described by a court as having a "fanatical obsession" with young girls. Police have released images of Munden, who is about 5ft 8ins tall and of heavy build, with both facial hair and a clean shave, as they believe he may have shaved off his beard before leaving the hospital. The public is urged to contact authorities with any information on his whereabouts.

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano to pay back more than $2.6 million in gifts from Donald Sterling after Sterling's wife, Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling, sued Stiviano. Shelly Sterling accused Stiviano of targeting extremely wealthy older men and claimed that Donald Sterling used the couple's money to buy Stiviano a Ferrari, two Bentleys, a Range Rover, and a $1.8 million duplex. Stiviano countered that there was nothing wrong with Donald Sterling giving her gifts and that she never took advantage of him. Shelly Sterling's lawyer called the court decision a victory for the Sterling family and said it sets a precedent that the injured spouse can recover damages from the recipient of ill-begotten gifts. The gifts from Donald Sterling to Stiviano included a $391 Easter bunny costume, a $299 two-speed blender, and a $12 lace thong. Donald Sterling's downfall came after an audio recording surfaced of him arguing with Stiviano, in which he chastised her for posting pictures on social media of her posing with African-Americans, including basketball legend Magic Johnson. NBA Commissioner Adam Silver banned Sterling from the league, fined him $2.5 million, and pushed through a charge to terminate all of his ownership rights in the franchise.

Thierry Henry has criticized Arsenal's recent transfer dealings and urged the club to sign four top players in the summer to have a chance of winning the Premier League title. Henry believes Arsenal need a goalkeeper, center-back, defensive midfielder, and striker. He also questioned whether Arsenal can win the title with Olivier Giroud as their first-choice striker, despite his 14 league goals this season. Henry emphasized the need for a competitive group to win the league and cited Chelsea's successful signings as an example. Arsenal are currently third in the Premier League, level on points with Manchester City but with a game in hand.

A young woman who was subjected to years of abuse by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn has told a court of the severe impact it had on her life. The wealthy NSW businessman has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including the most serious charge of persistent sexual abuse of a child. The young woman, who cannot be named, said when he abused her as a child she didn't know it was wrong. She said she hadn't spoken up about the abuse until the day she heard he had been caught, and since then had attempted to take her own life. She says she wonders when Van Ryn, who is now in custody will be out in the community again, and she worries what he did to her will forever affect how she relates to men. She said she has suffered depression since she was 14 and had been hospitalised for self harm and attempted suicide.

Arsenal midfielder Serge Gnabry, who has been out for over a year due to a serious knee injury, is feeling better and is ready to return to action. The 19-year-old played 90 minutes for Arsenal Under 21s against Reading on Monday, his second full game in a week. Gnabry, who impressed for the Gunners last season, is now over his injury and is looking forward to the next game.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant, tragically died after falling 70ft off a cliff while fleeing from a taxi to avoid paying the fare. The incident occurred in Penarth, South Wales, after a night out with friends. Phillips, who worked for Pretty Green and had studied at the University of Birmingham, was disoriented in the dark and unaware of the cliff's proximity. The coroner ruled his death as accidental, noting that he could not have known the danger ahead.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer's passport delay fiasco have not received compensation, while managers at the passport agency received bonuses of up to £3,500. Despite a £42 million profit made by the agency during the chaos, ministers refused to provide a blanket refund to families who had to pay extra for rushed travel documents or missed trips. The problems began a year ago as HM Passport Office struggled to cope with 3.6 million applications, leading to over half a million passports stuck in the system by mid-June. While urgent cases were given a free upgrade to the fast-track service, many still missed trips due to delayed passports. Only 2,191 compensation applications were approved, with an average payout of £92.68. The Home Affairs Select Committee's demand for full compensation was rejected by ministers, and only one holidaymaker out of a dozen contacted by The Mail on Sunday received any money back.

A semi-detached home in Horfield, Bristol, that has remained unchanged since the 1930s is up for auction with a guide price of £200,000 to £250,000. The house features original stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, a mint green and black bathroom, wood-panelled hallway, and vintage kitchen cupboards. The property also includes retro jars of popular food from the past, such as Cadbury’s Marvel dried milk, Tate and Lyle sugar, and Colman’s Mustard. While some features have been upgraded, such as double glazing, the potential cost of renovations may deter developers. The auction will take place on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick began his professional career as a backup to Alex Smith but became the 49ers' starter in the middle of the 2012 season after Smith suffered a concussion. He remained the team's starting quarterback for the rest of the season and led the 49ers to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans and spent much of her early life there before moving to Texas and later to San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, that connects the New Jersey Turnpike (Interstate 95, I-95) at exits 16E and 17 in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 (NY 495) inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through the NBCUniversal division NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in Leytonstone, East London, and Colchester, Essex, met Graham Coxon at the Stanway School, leading to the formation of Blur. Their debut album, "Leisure," was released in 1991 to mixed reviews. Blur's self-titled album in 2001 achieved worldwide success, influenced by various genres like alternative rock, trip hop, hip hop, electronica, dub, reggae, and pop. Albarn's debut solo album, "Everyday Robots," co-produced by Richard Russell, was released in 2014, featuring collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, and samples of Lord Buckley's rants.
Mogadishu, also known as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia. It houses many important national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by Nine Inch Nails from their 1992 EP, Broken.
Andrew Kevin Walker is an American BAFTA-nominated screenwriter born on August 14, 1964.

The 2007 film "Shooter" follows Force Recon veteran Bob Lee Swagger, played by Mark Wahlberg, who is framed for murder by a rogue secret private military company unit. The TV series "Shooter" stars Ryan Phillippe as Bob Lee Swagger, an expert marksman living in exile who is coaxed back into action after learning of a plot to kill the president.
House, also known as House, M.D., is an American medical drama television series that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was convicted in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate, carried out by members of his group at his instruction. He was also convicted of the murders of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. After his arrest, recordings of songs written and performed by Manson were released commercially.

Sean Justin Penn, born on August 17, 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist. He began his acting career in television with a brief appearance in an episode of Little House on the Prairie in 1974, directed by his father, Leo Penn. Penn's film debut was in the drama Taps in 1981, followed by diverse film roles in the 1980s, including Fast Times at Ridgemont High. He gained critical acclaim for his roles in crime dramas such as At Close Range, State of Grace, and Carlito's Way. Penn became a prominent leading actor with the drama Dead Man Walking, earning his first Academy Award nomination and the Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival. He received two more Oscar nominations for Sweet and Lowdown and I Am Sam before winning his first Academy Award for Best Actor in 2003 for Mystic River and a second one in 2008 for Milk.

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman, AC (27 August 1908 – 25 February 2001), often referred to as "The Don," was an Australian cricketer widely regarded as the greatest batsman of all time. After retiring, he continued to hold a prominent position in the sport as an administrator, selector, and writer for three decades.
L.A. Reid has held prominent positions in the music industry, including chairman and CEO of Epic Records, president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is a renowned drummer, best known for his work with the rock bands Rage Against the Machine (1991–2000; 2007–11) and Audioslave (2001–07). He began his career with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in 1991. Currently, he plays in Prophets of Rage with Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Additionally, Rage is a German heavy metal band formed in 1984 by Peter "Peavy" Wagner.

The Millers was a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015. It ran for 34 episodes over two seasons before being canceled by CBS on November 14, 2014, four episodes into its second season.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (1933-2006) was the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995, and the second woman to hold that office. She gained national attention as Texas state treasurer when she delivered the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. Richards was known for her outspoken feminism and memorable one-liners. She was defeated for re-election in 1994 by George W. Bush. Additionally, Ann Richards (1935-1982) was an American jazz singer and the wife of pianist Stan Kenton.
Drake Bell released an EP titled A Reminder independently in 2011.

Boardwalk is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman, and directed by Verona. Janet Leigh, born Jeanette Helen Morrison on July 6, 1927, and passing on October 3, 2004, was an American actress, singer, dancer, and author. She wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón Bolívar (1783-1830), known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader who played a key role in the independence of several South American countries from Spanish rule. He helped establish Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as sovereign states.

The Bermuda Triangle, also known as the Devil's Triangle, is a region in the western part of the North Atlantic Ocean where numerous aircraft and ships have reportedly vanished under mysterious circumstances.

Colin Kaepernick began his professional career as a backup to Alex Smith but became the 49ers' starter in the middle of the 2012 season after Smith suffered a concussion. He led the 49ers to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, losing to the Baltimore Ravens. In his first full season as a starter in 2013, Kaepernick helped the 49ers reach the NFC Championship, losing to the Seattle Seahawks.
Marnie is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is a form of marketing communication that uses nonpersonal messages to promote or sell a product, service, or idea. It is communicated through various mass media, including old media such as newspapers, magazines, television, radio, outdoor advertising, or direct mail, and new media such as search results, blogs, websites, or text messages.
Private Lives is a 1930 comedy of manners in three acts by Noël Coward. It was adapted into a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.
Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton, was a British Conservative politician and statesman who served as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 10 January 1957 to 19 October 1963.

Aristotle (384-322 BC) was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist from Stagira, Chalkidice. At 17 or 18, he joined Plato's Academy in Athens, staying until 347 BC. After Plato's death, he tutored Alexander the Great at the request of Philip II of Macedon in 343 BC.

David Mordechai Packouz is an American entrepreneur, inventor, musician, and former arms dealer. He is the CEO of Singular Sound, a music technology company, and the inventor of the BeatBuddy, a guitar pedal drum machine.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons, winning championships in high school and college before being selected first overall in the 1979 NBA draft. He won a championship and an NBA Finals Most Valuable Player Award in his rookie season and won four more championships with the Lakers during the 1980s. After protests from his fellow players, he retired for four years but returned in 1996 to play 32 games before retiring for the third and final time. Van Buren was a key supporter and organizer for Jackson in the 1828 election and ran for Governor of New York to boost Jackson's campaign. After serving as governor for two months, he resigned to become Jackson's Secretary of State. In 1831, following his resignation as Secretary of State, which helped Jackson resolve the Petticoat affair, Jackson appointed Van Buren as the American minister to Britain.

Camden, New Jersey, is home to two educational institutions: Rutgers University--Camden, established in 1926 as the South Jersey Law School, and Cooper Medical School of Rowan University, which opened in 2012.

Michigan is a U.S. state located in the Great Lakes and Midwestern regions of the country. It is the tenth most populous state and has the 11th largest total area, making it the largest state east of the Mississippi River. Michigan is unique in that it consists of two peninsulas, making it a leading state for recreational boating.

Penguin Books revolutionized publishing in the 1930s by introducing inexpensive, high-quality paperbacks sold for sixpence through Woolworths and other high street stores, making both fiction and non-fiction accessible to the mass market.
The 2008 film Australia was produced in Sydney, Darwin, Kununurra, and Bowen.

Billy Ray Cyrus is an American country music singer, songwriter, actor, and philanthropist who helped make country music a worldwide phenomenon. Excuse My French is the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana. Excuse My French is also a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama, based on Salama's own experiences at a public middle school in Egypt after his return from Saudi Arabia. The film was initially deemed too sensitive by the censorship board, and Salama was forced to adjust the script while trying to preserve the film's core concept of religious discrimination.
Derek Hough starred in the 2013 South Korean-American independent dance film Make Your Move, which is a Romeo and Juliet-inspired story.

"Bad Romance" is a globally successful song by Lady Gaga from her 2009 extended play The Fame Monster. It was released after an illegal demo leak and showcased at Alexander McQueen's Paris Fashion Week show. The song topped charts in various markets and sold 12 million copies worldwide, making it one of the best-selling singles of all time. Additionally, there is a 2011 independent drama film titled "Bad Romance" (Les Mauvais Romans).

DreamWorks Animation has released 34 feature films, including popular franchises like Shrek, Madagascar, Kung Fu Panda, How to Train Your Dragon, and Trolls. Other notable films include Monsters vs. Aliens, Rise of the Guardians, The Croods, and Home. The studio also produced Trollhunters, an American computer-animated fantasy television series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro.

Chris Eubank is a British former professional boxer who competed from 1985 to 1998. His son, Chris Eubank Jr., is a British professional boxer who has held the IBO super-middleweight title since February 2017, having previously held the WBA interim middleweight title in 2015 and the British middleweight title in 2016. As of May 2017, Eubank Jr. is ranked as the world's fifth best super middleweight by BoxRec, seventh best middleweight by The Ring magazine, and eighth by the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board.
