In the women's team pursuit, GB finished fifth in the heats and failed to make the bronze-medal ride. However, Olympic gold medallist Chris Boardman and six-time Olympic gold medallist Sir Chris Hoy praised Latham's performance, highlighting his well-timed final charge and sensible positioning throughout the race.

In other events, Britain's sole rider in the men's keirin, Joe Truman, was outclassed in his semi-final. Katy Marchant, the Olympic bronze medallist, was eliminated from the women's sprint in the first round but remained positive about her preparation for the Tokyo Olympics.

Ross Kemp will return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for a brief appearance in Barbara Windsor's final episodes. Windsor, who plays Peggy Mitchell, announced her character's death from cancer. Kemp expressed his excitement to reunite with his on-screen family and film classic episodes. Grant Mitchell, a memorable character in the soap's history, was involved in family dramas, including affairs with his brother's wife and ex-wife. EastEnders executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins praised the opportunity to showcase Ross Kemp and Steve McFadden's talents in emotional scenes.

Spurs suffered a disappointing loss at Anfield, with Sadio Mane scoring twice in quick succession. Manager Pochettino criticized the team's lack of desire and inability to cope with pressure, highlighting their poor away record against top-six rivals. Spurs have won only once in their last 17 away games against top-six teams. Danny Murphy also pointed out their defensive struggles and lack of pace in away games, emphasizing the need for improvement.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in Nigeria's recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which had been in power for 16 years. The APC's Muhammadu Buhari, who won the presidential election last month, will be inaugurated on May 29. The PDP lost key northern states and control of Adamawa, one of the states most affected by the Boko Haram insurgency, but managed to hold on to Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The PDP won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east, while the APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states. The elections were marred by violence in some areas, but overall, they were more peaceful than in previous years. The PDP will need to rebuild itself under a new leader after suffering from defections and allegations of corruption.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, will feature an augmented reality app allowing visitors to access online information, including videos and band interviews, by scanning signs and posters on-site. This feature will enhance the festival experience for attendees and enable global audiences to interact with the event and experience its atmosphere remotely. The app will be updated with new content before and during the festival, providing instant access to information, interviews, and ticket purchasing.

The passage discusses the findings of Ofsted inspections at several Birmingham schools, including Park View and Nansen Primary, which were rated inadequate. The Department for Education has issued warnings to these schools, threatening to terminate their funding agreements unless significant improvements are made. The inspections revealed a range of issues, including inadequate safeguarding measures, external speakers with extremist views, and a culture of fear and intimidation. Parents have criticized the reports, accusing inspectors of bias and pushing their own agendas. The schools have been given until July 4 to address the concerns raised by Ofsted.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution told Ipswich Crown Court that the conduct of eye specialist Honey Rose, 35, was so far below the expected standard that it was "criminal." Ms. Rose denies a charge of gross negligence manslaughter. Jonathan Rees QC said the alleged failure of Ms. Rose to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs during the routine test and refer him for further investigation was "at the heart of the prosecution case." A build-up of fluid in his brain increased pressure in Vinnie's skull and ultimately led to his death, the court heard. The prosecution alleges that Vinnie's death was preventable and would have been prevented had Ms. Rose done her job properly. The trial continues.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was convicted of coercing a woman into sexual activity and intercourse with a man he found through an adult website and filming them. He was also found guilty of causing the woman's sister and father to view sexual images and behaving in a threatening manner. Weatherhogg, who had denied the charges, was placed on the sex offenders register and remanded in custody ahead of sentencing. The case was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to its greater sentencing powers. Defense counsel Jonathan Crowe stated that Weatherhogg had been assessed as posing "a moderate risk" of sexual re-offending.

Ireland scored 165-5 in their T20 match against Afghanistan, with Stuart Thompson hitting 56 and Gary Wilson (41 no) and William Porterfield (39) adding valuable runs. However, Afghanistan chased down the target with two overs to spare, thanks to Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47), who put on an opening stand of 51. Irish captain William Porterfield acknowledged that they fell short of a big score and didn't execute well with the ball. The loss of paceman Boyd Rankin due to a back problem was another setback for the Irish. The two teams will meet again in the second T20 at the same venue on Friday.

Barcelona has made a complimentary tax declaration of €13.55 million to cover any potential interpretations of the contracts related to the signing of Neymar. The club paid £48.6 million for the Santos striker in the summer, with his parents receiving £34 million of the fee. However, it has been alleged that the actual cost of the player was far greater than the initial fee. The club denies any tax-related crime and insists that the original tax payment was in line with their fiscal obligations. The case is still under investigation, and there has been no confirmation whether it will be dropped after Barcelona's payment. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances for Barcelona this season, as well as netting three in seven Champions League matches.

The bodies of David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found on a beach in Koh Tao on September 15. Two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, both 21, are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, and could face the death penalty if found guilty. Thai police claim DNA found on Ms. Witheridge matched samples taken from the suspects. However, the UK Foreign Office has expressed concerns about the police investigation, including the verification of DNA samples and allegations of mistreatment of the suspects. UK detectives have completed their review of the investigation and will now compile a report and update the families of the victims.

Scotland's women's football team, unbeaten in their qualifiers, faces a crucial match against Iceland at Falkirk Stadium. A win would significantly boost their chances of qualifying for the finals in the Netherlands, avoiding the play-offs. Iceland, ranked one place above Scotland, is also unbeaten, making this match and the return fixture pivotal. Scotland's squad, featuring players from top leagues worldwide, benefits from the diverse experiences and competitiveness these players bring.

Apple has introduced a two-step verification system for iCloud in response to recent hacks that exploited third-party software to steal intimate photos of celebrities. This security measure requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted mobile phone number or via Apple's Find My iPhone app, in addition to their username and password, when accessing their account from an unfamiliar device. If the code is not entered, access to iCloud is denied, and users are blocked from making purchases on iTunes, iBooks, or the App Store. However, users can regain access using a 14-character recovery key.

Previously, Apple's two-step verification did not apply to its backup service, allowing hackers to use tools like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker to download complete backups of user data. Apple's new implementation prevents this technique and notifies account owners via email when a backup is downloaded, regardless of whether two-factor authentication is enabled.

Security experts have praised these changes but also raised concerns. Vladimir Katalov, owner of Elcomsoft, highlighted the risk of losing the recovery key and the potential for it to be stolen. On the other hand, Prof. Alan Woodward from the University of Surrey suggested that two-factor authentication should be the default setting for all major tech companies, not just Apple. Apple's CEO, Tim Cook, acknowledged the need for greater awareness and plans to more aggressively encourage users to adopt stronger security measures.

The passage provides a summary of the campaign spending and vote outcomes for several political parties in the May election. UKIP won the election, spending £2,956,737, which translates to 68p per vote. The Tories spent slightly more at £2,980,815, with a cost of 79p per vote. Labour, which came second, spent £1,027,339, amounting to 26p per vote. The Lib Dems, despite spending £1,580,575, lost all but one of their MEPs, with a cost of £1.45 per vote. The Green Party spent £534,249, equating to 43p per vote. The SNP spent £267,372. In total, the six highest-spending parties spent £9,347,087 on campaigning, as reported by the Electoral Commission. All parties except Labour spent more than they did in the 2009 European election campaign.

Barrow's center-back Anderson, 27, has terminated his contract by mutual consent to join their National League rivals. Anderson, who has also played in Italy, could face his former club on February 18. Striker Keating, 21, was recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. Keating has previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, with his move subject to international clearance. Nicholson described Anderson as a leader and Keating as young and hungry. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone and have won only one of their last six games.

The 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed that the horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary hemorrhage." Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, but had never collapsed before. The horse had won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. Trainer Oliver Sherwood described him as the "horse of a lifetime." The report concludes that Many Clouds was the victim of a hemorrhage rarely seen on the racetrack.

Tricia Marwick, the presiding officer, was moved to tears as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond bid farewell to the Scottish Parliament. Both are stepping down as MSPs ahead of the election on May 5. In his valedictory address, Salmond reiterated his belief that Scotland is "not divided, but diverse" and emphasized the need for the parliament to assume greater responsibility for governance. He welcomed the transfer of powers under the Scotland Bill but insisted it did not fulfill the pledges made by unionist politicians during the referendum campaign. Salmond also joked about facing competition from the "major attraction" of the champion chase at Cheltenham racecourse and wished everyone standing in the forthcoming election good luck, "albeit with varying degrees of enthusiasm." He concluded by saying, "Let me leave you with these final thoughts - there is no greater honor in public life than to be a member of this parliament." Marwick thanked Salmond for his service to the parliament and Scotland. Earlier, she had been moved to tears by a powerful final speech from Duncan McNeil, who warned that Holyrood had things to learn from Westminster, particularly with regard to the committee system. Annabel Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative MSP, also bid farewell, joking about her dealings with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

The live-action adaptation of Disney's "Beauty and the Beast" has announced its cast, including Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou. Joining them are Emma Thompson as Mrs. Potts and Kevin Kline as Maurice. The film will be directed by Bill Condon and is set to begin filming in May at Shepperton Studios, with a US release date of March 17, 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce its decision on whether to bring charges against 23 suspects related to the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, in which 96 football fans were fatally injured. The decision will be revealed at a private meeting with victims' relatives in Warrington. The suspects are being investigated for their roles in the disaster and the subsequent conduct of South Yorkshire Police and West Midlands Police. The Hillsborough Family Support Group, chaired by Margaret Aspinall, whose son died in the disaster, has expressed hope that this will mark the end of their long struggle for accountability.

Chelmsford Prison has reported multiple incidents of packages being thrown over the wall, with a former inmate claiming the jail is "flooded" with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. A local resident has witnessed such incidents four times in two weeks and expressed concern, while the Ministry of Justice stated that staff are working hard to prevent contraband from entering prisons. The Ministry also mentioned that new laws have been introduced, allowing people who smuggle packages over prison walls to be jailed for up to two years. However, there is no evidence of drones being used to smuggle contraband into the Chelmsford site.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by a car driven by Brian Wright, 55, outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright, who denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, told Luton Crown Court that he was blinded by the setting sun and could not remember if the traffic lights were red or green. He expressed remorse for the incident, stating that he thinks of nothing else other than Sylvia Blackburn and her family. The trial is ongoing.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner, will miss the Commonwealth Games in Australia next year due to her veterinary medicine studies. Despite her disappointment, she prioritizes completing her final year at university. Muir finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, setting a new outdoor personal best in the 5,000m. She expressed happiness with her performance and sees potential for future events, including possibly competing in the World Indoor Championships in March.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old from County Kildare, was last seen walking home from a Christmas party in December 2000. A search of a three-acre site in Chapelizod, Dublin, began on Saturday morning and is expected to take several weeks. The search involves excavations and follows a complete review of Mr. Deely's disappearance by a team of six detectives earlier this year. Enhanced CCTV footage from the night he went missing shows him talking to a man dressed in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street, where he worked. Detectives believe this man followed Mr. Deely a short time later on Haddington Road. The man has not yet been identified, and detectives renewed their appeal for him to come forward.

Del Potro, ranked 165th after a long injury hiatus, defeated Wawrinka in a thrilling match at Wimbledon. He will next face either Pouille or Young. Kyrgios also advanced, beating Brown in a rain-affected match. He will play Lopez in the third round. Berdych and Tsonga had straightforward victories in their matches.

Tunisia and Morocco faced challenges in participating in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Tunisia was on the verge of expulsion due to complaints lodged against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) during the 2015 tournament. However, they avoided expulsion by apologizing. Morocco, on the other hand, was initially banned from the 2017 qualifying draw but had the ban overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas). Both teams are now set to participate in the 2017 tournament, with Tunisia in Group A and Morocco in Group F.

McLaren's F1 history has been a cycle of triumph and decline. They have won 182 grands prix, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles. Despite their current struggles, they have two world champions in the cockpit, including Fernando Alonso. The slump started in 2013 due to chassis design issues, and now the problems lie with the Honda power unit. McLaren's greatest successes were with Honda in the late 1980s and early 1990s. They also had success with Mercedes engines in the late 1990s. However, scandals and a lack of titles in recent years have plagued the team. McLaren's current predicament is not surprising, as their history has been marked by cycles of success and decline. Despite this, McLaren's leadership remains optimistic about the future and believes that success will return.

The judge ordered the closure of Joe's Bar in Dungiven for three months after police found several people still at the bar at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014, with till receipts showing alcohol was being served as late as 04:49 BST. Colleen O'Neill, 43, the license holder, and James Thomas, 44, both of Kevin Lynch Park in the town, were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The defense solicitor acknowledged that the licensing laws in Dungiven were not strictly adhered to and that the premises had not been run in a proper manner. The judge expressed concern that he did not have the power to impose a custodial sentence and described the case as "as bad a case as I have come across and as bad a record." Ms. O'Neill was fined £3,000, while Mr. Thomas was fined £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most three-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry hit eight three-pointers, surpassing his previous record of 272 made in a single season. Klay Thompson added 26 points to help the Warriors avoid their first three-game losing streak of the season. LaMarcus Aldridge had 27 points and six rebounds, and Damian Lillard added 20 points and eight assists for the Blazers.

In another game, the Chicago Bulls came back from a 19-point halftime deficit to beat the Miami Heat 89-78. Pau Gasol had 16 points and 15 rebounds, and Aaron Brooks and Taj Gibson each scored 14 points for the Bulls. The Heat missed their first 12 shots after halftime and were outscored 57-27 in the second half. Hassan Whiteside had 19 points and 16 rebounds for the Heat, while Dwyane Wade scored just nine points on 4-for-20 shooting.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were surprised when YouTube star Bas van Velzen arrived at Melwood. Initially believed to be a competition winner, van Velzen showcased his free-kick skills, impressing the Liverpool quartet. The players, including Balotelli, also took part in the free-kick action. Van Velzen, known for his YouTube videos of free-kick exploits, described the experience as amazing and enjoyed pretending not to be very good at free-kicks. He also had a surprise for Balotelli, unveiling the Liverpool forward's infamous slogan.

Carriers of the BRCA1 gene, such as Angelina Jolie, can reduce their risk of death from breast cancer by undergoing an oophorectomy (removal of ovaries). A study found that BRCA1 carriers who had this procedure after breast cancer diagnosis had a 62% lower risk of dying from breast cancer. The protective effect was most significant when the surgery was performed within two years of diagnosis. However, this benefit was not observed in BRCA2 carriers. The study also noted a 65% reduction in death from all causes associated with oophorectomy. These findings suggest that oophorectomy should be considered as part of the treatment discussion for BRCA1 carriers diagnosed with early-stage breast cancer.

An Amtrak train struck and killed a married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, on Easter morning in Durham, North Carolina. The incident occurred on tracks owned by Norfolk-Southern as the train, en route from Charlotte to New York City, was passing through. None of the 166 passengers aboard were injured, though a man who fell ill during the delay received treatment. The train was delayed for about two hours and 45 minutes before continuing its journey. Authorities suspect the couple may have been living in a homeless camp.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for the promise of U.S. citizenship. He provided crucial information that led to the prosecution of major figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite his significant contributions, Toro's citizenship was never granted, and he now faces deportation after his final temporary visa expired. His health has forced him to retire, leaving him technically living in the U.S. illegally. Toro fears for his life if deported back to Colombia, stating that he would be killed within hours. His plight has gained attention, with a former DEA agent and colleague supporting his case, but the DEA has refused to assist him further.

The U.S. body that regulates internet addresses is investigating a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for using the new '.sucks' domain name to charge high fees from celebrities and companies seeking to protect their reputations. Vox Populi began selling '.sucks' domains on March 30, initially targeting trademark holders and celebrities, charging $2,499 a year. The company plans to offer these domains to the public for $10 a year starting in September. The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) has asked U.S. and Canadian regulators to determine if Vox Populi's actions are illegal. If found illegal, ICANN could declare Vox Populi in breach of its contract and seek to alter its practices.

The body of a baby boy was found in a pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk, in 1988. The case remained unsolved for 27 years until the baby's body was exhumed and a DNA sample led police to his mother. The woman, who has not been named, was arrested on suspicion of infanticide, but the charge was dropped after she explained that the baby had been stillborn and that she had concealed the pregnancy from her family and friends. She placed the baby's body in the pond, where it was found by teenagers. The woman remains on bail while the CPS decides whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial. The baby was re-buried in the churchyard on the 26th anniversary of his discovery and was named Peter after the name of the church.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, has been ordered to pay compensation to a passenger, Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of the moving car. Hicks, then 23, was on his way home from a night out in Bath, Somerset, with his girlfriend in 2010 when the incident occurred. Young, a former soldier, mistakenly believed Hicks was planning to "do a runner" and decided to drive him back to the rank to teach him a lesson. Hicks objected, and Young continued driving for almost a mile, leading Hicks to jump from the vehicle while it was traveling at more than 20 mph. Hicks suffered devastating brain injuries, developed epilepsy, and now requires round-the-clock care from his mother.

The family took Young to the High Court, where a judge ruled that he had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks and was therefore entitled to damages. The exact amount of compensation is yet to be decided but is set to be around 50 percent of what the family had requested, which is thought to be "hundreds of thousands of pounds." Both sides were given permission to appeal, and a further hearing will determine the amount Young will have to pay.

Tornado sirens blared in Kansas on Wednesday night as several storms brought reports of twisters. Spotters reported a tornado about 6 miles northwest of Goddard, which is less than 15 miles west of Wichita. That storm moved to the northeast, missing the city but posing potential risks to other communities. Other reports of tornadoes came in from southwestern Kansas. Kansas wasn't the only state affected by the storms, as the National Weather Service indicated a tornado may have touched down in the small town of Potosi, Missouri. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida are set to face off in a middleweight clash in New Jersey this weekend. Rockhold, who has won his last three fights, is confident in his ability to dominate Machida by cutting him off and forcing him to fight his fight. He believes he has identified weaknesses in Machida's game and is prepared to exploit them. Rockhold respects Machida's skills and fighting style but is determined to impose his own style and come out victorious. On the other hand, Machida is also coming off a win and is confident in his ability to stop Rockhold by applying his own style and strategy. He sees weaknesses in Rockhold's game and is prepared to capitalize on any mistakes he makes. Both fighters are eager to secure a title shot with a win in this highly anticipated matchup.

An Aerostar plane touched down on a runway without deploying its landing gear, causing it to skid along the tarmac on its belly. The incident occurred at the Aero Acres residential airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, and was captured on video. The plane's propellers ricocheted off the ground, and its wings bounced from the impact. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, managed to re-engage the engines and take off again, flying 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, where he landed safely. The FAA is investigating the incident.

Manuel Pellegrini has expressed his disappointment in Yaya Touré's performance this season but has pledged to support the Manchester City midfielder until the end of the season. Despite criticism and speculation about Touré's future, Pellegrini emphasized the importance of the Ivorian player and dismissed the idea of giving him a break. City, struggling in their Premier League defense, faces West Ham without their captain Vincent Kompany, who may be out for the rest of the season due to a muscle injury. Meanwhile, West Ham's manager, Sam Allardyce, has cautioned Aaron Cresswell against making a move to Manchester City, citing the experiences of other English players who struggled for playing time after joining big clubs.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian Mafia fugitive known as the "Godfather of Uxbridge," will be allowed to remain in the UK after his seven-year sentence for being a member of the Cosa Nostra expired last October. Rancadore, who has lived in Britain for over 20 years, was convicted in absentia in Italy in 1999. He was arrested in 2013 on a European Arrest Warrant but fought extradition, citing concerns about Italian prison conditions and his serious heart condition. The Italian court of appeal agreed to extinguish his conviction, and his European Arrest Warrant is to be withdrawn. The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) admitted to making a mistake by failing to serve appeal papers on time in March 2014, which contributed to the expiration of Rancadore's sentence.

Mr. Mole, AP McCoy's mount in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, has been installed as one of three 7-2 co-favourites in the seven-runner line-up. The Paul Nicholls-trained Mr. Mole is bracketed with Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's Sprinter Sacre, who will be ridden by Cheltenham Gold Cup winner Nico de Boinville in the absence of injured Barry Geraghty. AP McCoy and Mr. Mole will have six rivals in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. Mr. Mole will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race. His book of rides for his final day as a professional jockey will not be finalised until Friday morning. Ironically, it was after riding Mr. Mole to victory at Newbury in February that McCoy shocked the racing world by announcing his intention to quit riding. Other runners in the Celebration Chase include Mick Channon's Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter's daughter, Marcia, was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Marcia's body was found 33 days after she disappeared. Ritter's then-husband advised her against seeing the body and the crime scene photos, but last year, Ritter asked to see the crime scene photos of her daughter's body and now says she wants revenge. Ritter viewed the photos on the laptop of Metro Police lead investigator Mickey Miller. She described her daughter's body as having a black mouth, a swollen face, vomit across her, hair pulled out in parts, and blood on her scalp. Ritter shouted, "If I had a gun, I'd kill him!" Marcia's body was found 150 yards from her home amid the clutter of a rarely used, windowless garage, under a shower curtain and a child's wading pool. She had been strangled and sexually assaulted, and her cookie money was missing. Cookies were scattered around the clothed body, and a neck bone was fractured. The case was Nashville's most notorious unsolved murder for 33 years. In 1979, police charged a Trimble neighbor with the slaying, but prosecutors dropped the charges about a year later due to a lack of evidence. Barrett, 68, was living in Memphis when he was arrested in 2006. He was brought in after police matched the DNA on the murdered child's clothing to his. The match happened after he was arrested for the 1975 murder of Vanderbilt University student Sarah Vannatta Des Prez. Barrett had been in prison on sex charges between 1974 and 2002, except for about a year when Marcia disappeared. In 2009, he was found guilty of second-degree murder of Marcia, and a Davidson County Criminal Court jury imposed a sentence of 44 years.

Rory McIlroy believes it is unthinkable that he will not win the Masters at some point to complete the career grand slam. The world number one has revealed how his final-round collapse at Augusta National in 2011 was the most important day of his career. McIlroy is looking to claim his first green jacket and become just the sixth player to win all four major titles after Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus, and Tiger Woods. He has just one top-10 finish to his name in six Masters appearances, finishing joint eighth last year. McIlroy is hoping to complete his grand slam of majors with a victory at Augusta later this month. He believes that if he had not had the whole unravelling and lost by one, he might not have learned as much. McIlroy's extraordinary success last year came despite the distractions of calling off his wedding to Caroline Wozniacki and a legal dispute with his former management company. He hopes he can again use the golf course as his sanctuary from the pressure and hype surrounding Augusta.

This week's trending stories included:

1. Four rainbows appeared in the New York area after heavy rain.
2. China cracked down on the practice of hiring exotic dancers for wakes.
3. Robert Downey Jr. grew agitated during an interview where his private life was questioned.
4. The #kyliejennerchallenge, where people suck on a jar to plump their lips, became popular.
5. 102-year-old Alice Barker watched herself dance in old films.
6. A prom-posal referencing bombs was banned by a school, leading to accusations of racism.
7. Ewan McGregor was cast as Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast."
8. Johnny Depp was nearly unrecognizable in the "Black Mass" trailer.
9. A unique pregnancy announcement referenced "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air."
10. A military dad photobombed his son.

Hundreds of children were admitted to hospital last year after being born brain damaged following exposure to alcohol in the womb, according to alarming new figures. In total, 272 youngsters left disabled by foetal alcohol syndrome were hospitalised in England over the past 12 months, according to data from the official health and social care information centre. However, the actual number affected by their mother's drinking could be far greater, experts have warned. Research by the World Health Organisation suggests that at least one in 100 babies born in the UK could suffer learning, behavioural and physical problems such as deformed limbs because of exposure to alcohol. That equates to about 7,500 every year. Elizabeth Mitchell, of the National Organisation for Foetal Alcohol Syndrome, said: "Children born with the syndrome don't get better. It is an enormous problem and one that is terribly sad and vastly under-diagnosed."

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender, was jailed for six years after attempting to rob a store in County Durham. McKerry, who had a history of criminal activity since the age of 12, entered the Shildon Post Office and Stores on March 15, waving an axe and demanding cash. However, his attempt was foiled when the shopkeeper, Sab Dhillon, tackled him to the floor, and Dhillon's wife, Sam, hit McKerry with a baseball bat, causing him to drop the weapon. McKerry, who had earned the nickname "Boomerang Boy" for always returning home after committing crimes, was arrested by the police minutes later. He had previously pleaded guilty to attempted robbery at Durham Crown Court.

Four Royal Navy sailors, Joshua Finbow, Simon Radford, Craig Stoner, and Darren Smalley, have been charged with the gang rape of a young woman at a party in a Canadian barracks. The alleged incident occurred on April 10, after the sailors had returned to the barracks from a hockey game. The victim, who is in her early 20s, had accompanied a friend who had been invited to the party by local Canadian servicemen. The sailors have been ordered to stay in Nova Scotia until their trial and have been given identical but unusual bail conditions that could see them having to live on a Canadian naval base for the next few years. They have been ordered to surrender their passports, not leave the province of Nova Scotia, and not apply for new passports. They must also remain employed by the Navy and must not resign without the court's permission. The sailors have been charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, which are punishable by up to 14 years in prison. The investigation is still at an early stage, and the results of forensic tests could result in additional charges.

A mother of a four-year-old boy with a rare skin disease was shocked when a stranger reported her to the police for child abuse. The boy, RJ Jackson, suffers from Netherton's Syndrome, a rare congenital skin disease that affects only 70 people worldwide. His skin appears red and scaly, and his mother has to regularly apply creams to prevent it from drying out. While shopping, she was surrounded by armed police, who had been called by a member of the public who mistook RJ's condition for signs of abuse. The mother, Valerie Jackson, has also faced taunts and accusations from other mothers and strangers in the street. Despite the challenges, she remains positive and describes her son as the most beautiful boy in the world.

Transport for London (TfL) has confirmed that the controversial Protein World "Are you beach body ready?" advertisements, featuring a bikini-clad model, are being removed from the London Underground after a three-week advertising period. The posters, which have sparked outrage among feminists and body image campaigners, have been defaced and attracted over 50,000 signatures on a Change.org petition. The Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) has received over 200 complaints, and a protest against Protein World is planned for May 2 in Hyde Park. Despite the backlash, Protein World has defended its campaign, stating that the image is unphotoshopped and aimed at promoting health and fitness. The company's head of global marketing, Richard Staveley, has dismissed the criticism as coming from an "irrational minority" and revealed that the company has received threats, including a bomb threat. The ASA is assessing the complaints to determine if further action is necessary.

Rail firms are planning fare hikes of up to 87% just ten days after the general election, despite promises from party leaders to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has written to First Great Western, urging them to review the decision to almost double fares on the London to Cotswolds route, which passes through his Witney constituency. The planned changes have angered Mr. Cameron's constituents, prompting him to personally intervene. Train companies have three windows every year in which they can increase "unregulated" fares, which make up around half of their total revenue. Unregulated fares can include journeys such as off-peak leisure and advance-purchase tickets. First Great Western has insisted the reason for the change is to bring the North Cotswolds route in line with its other services. The firm is also offering some customers a cheaper option in advanced single tickets, potentially allowing them to buy a return for £20 if they book ahead. Other sharp price hikes to be introduced include an off-peak first-class single from Crewe to Northampton on London Midlands, which will rise from £30 to £37, according to Trainsplit.com. The cost of an anytime return between Stafford and Liverpool, traveling with Virgin, will leap from £26.50 to £33 - a 24.5% hike. Virgin has said the "vast majority" of its price hikes affected "Virgin trains-only fares" - which are at least 20% cheaper than tickets offered by rival firms.

John Young, a 66-year-old retired HGV driver and former soldier, was blinded in one eye after being struck by a brick thrown by vandals at his home in Oldham, Greater Manchester. The incident occurred when Mr. Young confronted the attackers after they pelted his front window with stones. Despite undergoing emergency surgery, doctors could not save his eyesight. The attack took place just three weeks after Mr. Young and his wife, Elaine, got married. The couple has since decided to move to Southport, feeling unsafe in their neighborhood. Police are investigating the incident but have not identified a motive.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton has signed a one-year contract extension, keeping him with the county until the end of the 2016 season. Poynton missed the entire 2014 campaign due to leg injuries sustained in a road accident in which his father, Keith, died. The former England under-19 international made his playing comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. Graeme Welch, Derbyshire's elite performance director, praised Poynton's exceptional character and hard work in his return to the field.

Harley Renshaw, a five-year-old boy from Stretford, was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer. The cancer was found in his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. During his radiotherapy treatment, Harley wore a superhero mask and asked to decorate it like a Ninja Turtle, which helped him feel stronger. His story gained widespread attention, and he received presents from Nickelodeon. After a year of treatment, including chemotherapy, surgery, and a stem cell transplant, Harley was declared cancer-free. He will continue to have regular check-ups. Harley's bravery earned him a Cancer Research UK Little Star Award and made him the face of the charity's Kids and Teens campaign.

Tim Sherwood believes that Jack Grealish should focus on his Aston Villa career rather than his international future. Sherwood has been impressed with the 19-year-old who starred for Villa in their FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool on Sunday and is now at the center of a tug of war between the Republic of Ireland and England. Sherwood wants Grealish to focus on continuing to force his way into the Villa first team. Grealish is expected to choose between Ireland and England at the end of the season and is currently split between the two countries.

The text discusses the high landing fees charged at various airports for private jets, highlighting the significant costs associated with this mode of travel. It mentions that these fees can reach thousands of dollars per landing, with some of the most expensive airports being in Japan, including Haneda Airport in Tokyo, which charges £4,559 ($6,850) for landing. Other expensive airports include Narita International Airport and Kansai International Airport, also in Japan. The text also notes that the UK's Bristol Airport and Dublin Airport in Ireland are among the top 10 most expensive for landing fees. Additionally, it points out that private jet travel is a growing trend, with millions of flights recorded annually, and it is particularly popular during major sporting events like the Super Bowl and the Monaco Grand Prix.

Cooper, a Labrador, is known for his speedy eating habits, as seen in a viral video where he devours an ice cream cone in one bite at a McDonald's drive-thru. His owner, Katie Gallegos, ensures that Daisy, a smaller dog, gets her share first. Despite some criticism for feeding her dogs ice cream, Gallegos defends the practice, citing Cooper's excellent health and the longevity of her previous dog, who also enjoyed weekly ice creams. The video has garnered over seven million views, and Cooper's love for fast food extends to enjoying "pup-uccinos" at Starbucks, where he similarly consumes the treat in one go.

Kilmarnock interim manager Gary Locke has been appointed on a permanent basis after signing a three-year deal. The former Hearts boss joined the club as assistant boss to Allan Johnston last summer but took control of the team when his ex-Tynecastle team-mate quit at the start of February. The 41-year-old, who will speak at a press conference on Friday morning, has lost just once in seven games since taking over at Rugby Park.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, has accused Seminole County Elementary of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, because of the essential oils he wears to help combat his illness. Kemp says she applies the oils, manufactured by doTERRA, to his head and neck to help him stay calm and focused. She claims he has been using them all year, but a teacher's aide recently complained. The school board sent her a letter stating the oils had created a "problem" for staff and students. Despite the threat of punishment, Kemp says she will continue to fight the decision, insisting the oils have a positive impact on her son. However, the Lake County School District has stated they would not suspend Logan, calling it a "health issue."

A beach-side apartment complex in the Hamptons was destroyed by a fire on Wednesday afternoon. The fire, which is being investigated, started near a car parked by the complex and spread through 90 condos before the building eventually collapsed. Twelve fire crews were deployed to control the flames, but they could not get inside any of the summer homes. The fire was so intense that it melted the paint off nearby buildings and could be seen from three miles away. The Sandpiper complex, which is used as a holiday home by residents between May and November, was completely destroyed.

The Queen, who is approaching her 89th birthday, was spotted enjoying a ride on her black Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, through Windsor Great Park. Despite her age and a niggling knee injury, the Queen remains an enthusiastic equestrienne and breeds Fell ponies and Highland ponies. She has been riding since the age of four and has a long history of equine enthusiasm, with a succession of steeds in the royal stables. The Queen is known for her love of horses and her reluctance to wear riding helmets, preferring silk scarves instead.

A dispute between two Brisbane neighbors over noise levels has resulted in the death of one man and the charging of another with manslaughter. Leon Yeaman, 55, was allegedly killed by a single punch to the head from 28-year-old shift worker Phillip Pama during an argument in front of their North Brisbane homes. Yeaman was reportedly making noise in his yard on Muller Road at around 9 pm on Thursday night. Pama, a married father of three who works a 3 am shift at a nearby warehouse, was sleeping at the time of the commotion. Pama's defense lawyer, Bruce Peters, stated that Yeaman was known for getting drunk, playing loud music, and yelling. Pama confronted Yeaman, and the situation escalated, resulting in Yeaman's death. Paramedics were unable to revive Yeaman, who was pronounced dead at the scene at around 11 pm on Thursday night. Pama was granted conditional bail and ordered to surrender his passport, adhere to a curfew from 6 pm to 2 am, and report to the local police station twice a week. The case is due to return to court on May 18.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old Russian music teacher, faces 15 years in prison after attempting to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old ex-lover, Damian Vanya. The affair between Simonova and Vanya lasted a year, during which she showered him with gifts and money. After Vanya ended the relationship for a classmate, Simonova offered 100,000 rubles (approximately £1,400) to a friend to find someone willing to carry out the hit. Police set up a sting operation, sending an undercover officer to pose as a hitman. Simonova was caught on camera detailing her plan to have Vanya beaten and mutilated before she would "finish him." She was arrested after handing over expense money to the undercover officer and is now remanded in custody on charges of attempted murder. Vanya expressed relief at her arrest, stating, "I hope they throw away the key."

Chelsea football manager José Mourinho has revealed that he prays to God daily but never about football. He also stated that he never discusses the game with his wife. Mourinho emphasized his strong faith in God and his commitment to prayer, although he does not attend church regularly except when in Portugal. He expressed his belief in God and his dedication to prayer, but clarified that his prayers are focused on personal matters, not football. Mourinho also highlighted his efforts to separate his professional and family life, describing himself as a good family person and friend. He acknowledged that while he may make mistakes in his professional life, it is only a part of who he is as a person.

Bob Barker, the iconic host of "The Price is Right" for 35 years, made a surprise return to the show on April 1, 2015, after an eight-year absence. At 91 years old, Barker appeared spry and seamlessly hosted the first price-guessing game, "Lucky Seven," before handing over the reins to current host Drew Carey.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington, D.C., on charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property. Baldwin was taken into custody by the Metropolitan Police after allegedly attempting to break into a house on the 3200 block of D Street SE. The Secret Service has since revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave. Baldwin's arrest follows a series of recent incidents involving misconduct within the agency, which is responsible for protecting the president and his family.

Atif Saeed, a freelance photographer from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to capture a close-up image of a hungry lion in the city's safari park. Armed only with a camera, he crept to within 10 feet of the lion, lying on the ground to capture the animal's character and status. The clicking sound of the camera's shutter alerted the lion, forcing Saeed to retreat rapidly to the safety of his car. Reflecting on the incident, Saeed admitted that he would not attempt such a close encounter again.

New York City police have released an image of a tattoo found on the body of a woman who died on a Brooklyn street nearly a month ago in hopes of identifying her. The woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was discovered unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn. Paramedics were unable to revive her, and she was pronounced dead that evening. The woman had no identification on her, but she had a distinctive tattoo on her right leg. Investigators believe the faded body art was the name "Monique" etched across a tattooed ribbon within a heart topped with a rose. The NYPD is still awaiting a medical examiner's report to determine the cause of the woman's death. Anyone with information about the unidentified woman is being asked to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a solar-powered, two-bedroom home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK in 2009. The project took a year and a half and cost about $25,000. The home, now located on a lot in Nelson, New Zealand, is mostly self-sufficient, with solar panels providing most of the electricity, a gas-powered stove and hot water, and water from a nearby spring. The couple enjoys a cozy, wood-lined interior and a natural surrounding with trees and a babbling brook. They plan to build another similar home in the future.

The study found that kindergarten students who shared iPads in class performed significantly better on early literacy tests than those who used iPads individually or did not use them at all. The research, conducted with 352 students, showed that shared iPad students scored around 30 points higher. The researcher, Courtney Blackwell, suggests that the collaborative learning environment created by sharing devices, rather than just the collaboration itself, contributed to the improved outcomes. She recommends that schools reconsider how tablets are used in early grades to maximize their effectiveness.

A piglet born without back legs in Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, China, has become an internet sensation after a video of it learning to walk on its front legs went viral. The piglet, nicknamed "Super Pig," balances on its front trotters and wobbles around while foraging for food. Despite several close calls, the piglet always manages to regain its balance. The piglet belongs to farmer Ms. Duan, who noticed the piglet's missing hind legs when it was feeding. Villagers have flocked to see the curious animal, and it happily mixes with the rest of the litter, which has all been born with a full complement of legs. The piglet's remarkable balance and determination have captured the hearts of thousands since the video went online.

During the IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, Dayle Coyne Racing's front-outside tire changer, Todd Phillips, was injured when he was struck by Francesco Dracone's car. Dracone spun while exiting his pit box, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips was treated at the infield care center, where he received stitches for a cut on his leg and was subsequently released. Many cars struggled with traction during the race due to rain that had fallen for hours leading up to the green flag. Dracone did not finish the race and ended up in 23rd place.

A horrific CCTV footage has emerged of a husband smashing his dancer wife's head into concrete paving 11 times and then shooting her in the face five times. The husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, later confessed that he carried out the brutal act because he was jealous of men looking at her. The sickening video, captured on security cameras, shows Severiano dragging the limp body of his wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, 29, into the garden of their apartment in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. He then dumps her on the ground before grabbing her by the hair and savagely slamming the back of her head into the concrete 11 times before viciously punching her in the face another 10 times. Leaving the battered and unconscious dancer on the ground, he goes into the house and returns with a handgun, shooting her in the face five times at point-blank range. After shooting his wife, who went by the stage name of Amanda Bueno, Severiano stole a neighbor's car but was picked up by police after crashing it during his getaway. Police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in Severiano's getaway car. He now faces life in jail.

Sarah Wilson, author of the best-selling book I Quit Sugar, has revealed her personal battle with mental illness, including a near-suicide attempt. In an interview with Women's Weekly Australia, Wilson shared how anxiety led her to believe her life was no longer worth living. She cited mounting stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and feelings of isolation as contributing factors. Wilson emphasized the link between depression and anxiety, calling for greater awareness and support. She also highlighted the increasing prevalence of anxiety among Australian women, urging those in need to seek help from organizations like Beyond Blue and Lifeline.

An Oregon woman, Elena Curtin, who was seven months pregnant, was charged with second-degree assault after striking her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014. Curtin found the ex-girlfriend using heroin in her bathroom and asked her to leave, but the ex-girlfriend refused. Curtin then beat her with a crowbar. Oregon law allows for the use of physical force against an intruder who won't leave a resident's home. Curtin's defense attorney argued that the ex-girlfriend was "jealous and bitter" and had been harassing and threatening Curtin for two years. The ex-girlfriend and Curtin's boyfriend had a five-year-old child together and had gotten high at the apartment before. The ex-girlfriend had also stolen from Curtin and plotted to drag the boyfriend back into addiction. Curtin has since reconciled with her boyfriend and is now living with her parents. The boyfriend has not been a part of his new child's life. Prosecutors dropped the charge against Curtin, stating that she was "completely justified in her outrage." If convicted, Curtin would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of almost six years.

Gemma the pit bull was filmed at home in California being fed some treats. However, her owner threw a broccoli spear into the mix to trick her. The dog immediately pulled a look of disgust as she chomped on the vegetable and then proceeded to spit it out on the floor. When she's not eating, other videos show Gemma enjoys sleeping and hanging out with her human family.

HSBC has apologized after a link on its official website directed visitors to a pornographic page. The link, which was part of the bank's Young Entrepreneur Awards page, was removed after the awards were scrapped in 2011. The organizers allowed the registration on hsbc.com.hk to retire, and the website's URL address transferred visitors to the porn business instead. HSBC removed the hyperlink from its main website after realizing the mistake and denied any association with the external site. The bank's internet banking service remains secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, were trapped in a second-floor bedroom after a fire broke out on the first floor of their home in Clinton on Sunday morning. Marcus called 911 and stayed calm throughout the 11-minute call, providing instructions to the dispatcher and soothing his sister. He told the dispatcher that his older brother, mother, and stepfather were also in the home. Firefighters were able to enter the room by breaking a window and rescued the siblings. Marcus and Aaliyah were taken to the hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while the other family members escaped on their own and were taken to the hospital.

The passage describes the emergence of blue fluorescent algae, caused by millions of plankton emitting light, along Australia's east coast. The phenomenon was captured in stunning images taken in Jervis Bay, New South Wales, by photographer Andy Hutchinson, who described it as a "beautiful supernatural scene." A similar display occurred in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. Iain Suthers, an oceanography expert from the University of New South Wales, explained that the glow is caused by a single-celled phytoplankton called Noctiluca scintillans, which blossoms in spring and autumn and emits light as a defense mechanism.

Breast cancer patients may be spared chemotherapy thanks to new tests that pinpoint genetic markers in the tumor and determine its aggressiveness. After surgery, the cancer cells are sent to a lab where they are screened, and women can be told within days whether they have a high or low risk of the disease returning. For some women, the test can accurately tell if the risk is as low as five percent, which is as good as if not better than the odds for those who have chemotherapy. The majority of women who have breast cancer are routinely given the grueling drug treatment following the removal of the tumor to prevent recurrence. Although the medication kills off cancer cells, the side effects can be difficult to live with. For some women, the prospect of chemotherapy is more daunting than the surgery itself. But experts have long believed that the risk of cancer recurrence for certain women is a lot less than for others, and that for some, chemotherapy may not be necessary. If the newest of the tests, called Endopredict, shows a low score, patients can opt not to have chemotherapy. Most of the tests are available only privately and cost about £2,500, although breast specialists hope they may soon become properly available on the NHS.

Over 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, including at least one from HMS Illustrious, nicknamed "HMS Lusty" by the crew. Emergency evacuations occurred on 18 other ships, including HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond. A Ministry of Defence spokesman confirmed a strict "no touching" rule at sea, suggesting the women conceived before boarding or during leave. This comes nine months after Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was flown back to the UK following claims of a sexual relationship with a crew member.

A drone carrying traces of a radioactive material was discovered on the rooftop of the Japanese Prime Minister's residence. The drone, equipped with a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing cesium, was spotted by a staff member. This discovery has raised concerns about terrorism, especially in light of the upcoming Olympics and G7 summit. The Japanese government is now reviewing how to handle the threat of terrorism from drones.

Lu Xincai, a security guard from Zhejiang province in eastern China, takes his 84-year-old mother, who suffers from Alzheimer's, to work with him on the back of his motorbike every day. He ties a sash around both of their waists to ensure she does not fall off. Lu's mother used to get lost when left alone, and after his father passed away earlier this year, he decided to take her to work with him as there was no one else to care for her. His wife works in a different city, and his son is still in school. Lu helps his mother get up at 5 am every morning, and the journey to work takes an hour. Even at work, he checks up on her to ensure she has not wandered off. Lu feels it is his duty to care for his mother, who devoted her life to caring for her children.

The study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington, published in the American Journal of Public Health, found that heavy drinking among Americans rose 17.2 percent between 2005 and 2012, largely due to rising rates among women. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention defines heavy drinking as exceeding an average of one drink per day during the past month for women and two drinks per day for men, while binge drinking is defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more drinks for men on a single occasion at least once during the past month. The increases are driven largely by women's drinking habits as social norms change, with women's binge drinking rates rising by nearly 36 percent between 2002 and 2012, compared with 23 percent among men. In 2012, 8 percent of Americans were considered heavy drinkers and 18 percent were binge drinkers. Despite the increases in heavy drinking, the percentage of people who drink any alcohol has remained relatively unchanged over time.

The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned that doctors are performing too many unnecessary caesarean sections, putting the health of women and their babies at risk. While the procedure can save lives, it can also lead to infections, disabilities, and even death. The WHO recommends that the ideal rate of caesarean sections should be between 10% and 15%, but in England, the rate has more than doubled since the early 1990s, with just over a quarter of women now having the procedure. The NHS guidelines allow women to have the operation even when there is no medical justification, but the WHO says that doctors are underestimating the risks and diverting precious resources away from other patients.

A woman named Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, has been charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property after she allegedly broke into a home on Martha's Vineyard, lived inside for at least a week, and sold items belonging to the owners in a yard sale. Filkins was discovered at the Court Street property in Edgartown by the owner, Mark Conklin, on April 17. When Conklin confronted her, she claimed that she owned the house and fled in a gray Nissan pickup truck when he called the police. Filkins was arrested several hours later after attempting to get back into the home, thinking Conklin had left. She is next scheduled to be in court on May 14. Police are asking anyone who received items from the home to return them to the Edgartown Police Department.

Bella Crooke's lost iPhone was returned to her after police posted a series of humorous photos and updates on her Facebook page. The phone was handed in to Albury Police Station on the NSW-Victoria border on Sunday morning. Officers used the unlocked phone to post selfies and puns on Bella's Facebook page, including a photo of the phone in a holding "cell" and reassurances that it was in safe hands. Bella eventually reclaimed her phone after officers recognized her from her Facebook page. She has since put a password on her phone and expressed gratitude to the police for their good humor and for returning her phone.

The passage describes a tragic incident in which a five-day-old baby hippopotamus was caught in a fight between two adult males in the Isimangaliso Wetland Park, South Africa. The calf was flung into the air and dragged along the water's surface, leading to fatal injuries. The mother hippo, who had been protecting her calf from younger hippos, watched helplessly as the incident unfolded. The calf died hours later.

A three-bedroom apartment in the exclusive Egerton Place, Knightsbridge, London, has been listed for £575,000, significantly lower than neighboring properties. The catch is that the lease has only three years remaining, making the cost equivalent to renting in the area. Extending the lease for 90 years could raise the property's value to over £6 million, but this would require a substantial additional investment of £3.35 to £4.5 million. The property, in need of modernization, includes three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, a utility room, a lift, parking, and a communal garden. It is being sold by Russell Simpson, who describes it as a rare opportunity. The larger maisonette on the same street is also for sale at £595,000.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage affecting registers at 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, leading to free drinks being given away. The outage, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, began in the early evening on the East Coast and late afternoon on the West Coast. Many stores closed early to avoid giving away free products, while others continued to serve customers. The issue was resolved, and stores were expected to open as usual on Saturday. The potentially costly tech snafu followed record quarterly earnings for Starbucks, with net revenues of $4.6 billion.

Terrorists are undergoing training in rural areas of West Wales, including Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire. Locations in these areas are also being used to radicalize Muslims, according to Detective Constable Gareth Jones from the Wales Extremism and Counter-Terrorism Unit. Jones emphasized that terrorism is not confined to large cities and that community intelligence is vital in addressing these issues. Incidents of Islamic extremist activity in Wales can be traced back to 1998, and there have been several cases of terrorist-related activities in the region since then.

A rare Omura's whale was discovered on a remote beach in Western Australia after a tropical cyclone. The species, which was only described in scientific journals in 2003, is usually found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The discovery is significant for whale scientists as very little is known about the species. The carcass has been buried, and the skeleton will be recovered in a few years for further scientific investigation and possibly for public display in museums.

The article discusses the role of gender and hormones in leadership, particularly in the context of presidential candidates. Cheryl Rios, a female businesswoman, expressed her belief that women, including Hillary Clinton, should not be president due to hormonal differences that could lead to irrational decision-making. This view has sparked criticism, with some pointing out that male hormones have also historically impaired decision-making in male leaders. Studies suggest that women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks than their male counterparts. The article highlights the pervasive gender bias in the workplace, using examples to illustrate the overt and covert forms of this bias. It emphasizes the need for a serious discussion about ending gender bias to ensure equality and its benefits for everyone. The article concludes by addressing the bias against women in leadership roles and the importance of changing perceptions to create a more equitable society.

Robert Hardy, a veteran actor known for his roles in All Creatures Great and Small and as Winston Churchill, is auctioning off his collection of antiques, including over 200 items collected over his career. The auction, taking place at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire, features items such as a diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a longbow with a mother-of-pearl handle, and a portrait of Hardy holding the bow. The collection also includes furniture, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, crystal chandeliers, and dozens of books dating back to the 17th century. Hardy, a military historian and expert on the medieval longbow, expressed sadness at parting with his collection but hopes the new owners will find as much joy in the items as he did.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57, whose body was found at the home they shared in Winter Garden, Florida. He is on the run from police and was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication. Shemansky has a history of bipolar mental illness, was involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward for an attempted suicide, and is already on parole for battery on law enforcement. He failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother's body was discovered. Neighbors believe that divorce proceedings may have pushed him over the edge, and his estranged wife has filed a domestic violence injunction against him.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The decision was made by the International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council, which bypassed the usual bidding process due to what it saw as a unique strategic opportunity to host the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene had previously failed in its bid to host the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, Qatar. The IAAF Council's decision was influenced by the support of public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and an enthusiastic public. The 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan, were also awarded without a bidding process.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model, has been sentenced to 16 years in prison for the manslaughter of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan. Granger targeted Hassan after spotting him flashing £50 notes at a London casino. She befriended him, and he showered her with gifts and cash. After going back to his flat one night, she left the door unlocked, allowing her boyfriend and an accomplice to enter. They tied up Hassan, kicked him to death, and ransacked his home, leaving him with multiple broken bones and drowning in his own blood. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter, while her co-defendants, Kyrron Jackson and Nicholas Chandler, were convicted of murder and sentenced to life with a minimum term of 36 years.

Cesc Fabregas' form has significantly declined in the second half of the season, raising questions about his durability. Despite a strong start at Chelsea, with 15 Premier League assists by mid-January, he has only managed one assist in his last five games and four in 15 appearances for club and country in 2015. His struggles were evident in Spain's 2-0 defeat to Holland, where he was rated poorly. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho will be concerned about Fabregas' fatigue and will demand more from him in the Premier League run-in. With nine games remaining, Chelsea may need as many as six wins, and Fabregas' form will be crucial in securing the title.

West Ham are in discussions to sign Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, who impressed during a trial with the club. The 17-year-old, who is considered one of the hottest prospects from the Caribbean, has also received offers from clubs in Belgium. Additionally, West Ham have announced that season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will be priced as low as £289, making them the cheapest in the Barclays Premier League as they prepare to move to the 54,000-capacity stadium for the 2016-17 season.

Wiltshire Police have dropped an investigation into a violent attack on a huntsman, Mike Lane, despite substantial evidence, including video footage and suspect details. The attack occurred on January 24 during a hunt, where Lane was assaulted by balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars and ropes. He suffered severe injuries, including concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. Despite the evidence provided, including car registration numbers and a suspect's photograph, the police have shelved the case due to insufficient evidence. This decision has sparked outrage among hunt supporters and raised concerns about the challenges faced by police in identifying suspects wearing face coverings. The Countryside Alliance is now campaigning to ban saboteurs from wearing face coverings to facilitate justice.

Adam Gadahn, a U.S. citizen and prominent Al Qaeda member, was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January. Known as Azzam the American, he was born in 1978 and grew up on a farm in rural California before converting to Islam in 1995 and moving to Pakistan in 1998. Gadahn became Al Qaeda's chief English-language propagandist, appearing in videos threatening attacks and urging Muslims to target U.S. and Western interests. He was indicted for treason in 2006 and was on the FBI's Most Wanted Terrorists list. Gadahn's final video was posted in September 2014, calling for the overthrow of governments in Saudi Arabia and Pakistan. He was married to an Afghan Muslim woman and had at least one child.

A viral video of a five-year-old Chinese boy named Mai Zizhuo showcasing his exceptional basketball skills has taken China by storm. The video shows him scoring multiple hoops and dribbling two basketballs simultaneously with remarkable focus and rhythm. His skills have earned him a large fan base and admiration from netizens, some of whom express disbelief and awe at his talent. Mai started playing basketball at just two and a half years old, and his potential has stunned many, drawing comparisons to China's biggest basketball star, Yao Ming.

Tom O'Carroll, a leading member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), which campaigned to legalize child sex in the 1970s and 80s, has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll, a former Open University information officer and key activist for PIE, attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off, formed in the wake of the phone-hacking scandal, is campaigning against what it sees as the "biased and unfair" Independent Press Standards Organisation and wants MPs to set up a statutory body to regulate the press, as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. The news that O'Carroll is a backer of Hacked Off will be an embarrassment to the group. PIE was formed in 1974 to campaign for sex with children to be legalized and formed an alliance with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL). The NCCL lobbied Parliament for the age of sexual consent to be cut to ten as long as the child "understood the nature of the act" and apparently consented. The group also wanted incest to be legalized. O'Carroll was on the NCCL's gay rights sub-committee. The 69-year-old was jailed in 1981 for "corrupting public morals." He wrote a blog after the February meeting, chaired by comedian John Cleese, confirming his attendance. A Hacked Off spokesman said that the meeting was "open to and free for all members of the public to attend."

Bondi's Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to create a unique catwalk for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The empty pool was used as the unusual catwalk setting for the Ten Pieces presentation. The lifestyle brand, headed up by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and his partner Lucy Hinckfuss, produces unisex collections of ten pieces. A presentation of entirely monochrome creations saw models walking through the concrete pool and along the break wall with a backdrop of the ocean. The collection of ten is designed to be worn in 20 different ways and is suitable for day-to-night wear. Guests were treated to nibbles by Icebergs and drinks from Santa Vittoria as they took in the minimalist, androgynous designs. The show took place on an unseasonably warm 28-degree Celsius day, with beautiful blue sky and sunshine throughout.

Amir Khan, a Bolton-born boxer, spent his Friday at a safari park in Northern California with his family. He posed with and fed a rare white tiger, as well as giraffes and sea lions. Khan was joined by his wife, Faryal Makhdoom Khan, and their daughter, Lamysa. Earlier this week, Khan announced his next fight will be against Chris Algieri at welterweight on May 30, ending speculation over his next opponent. He had been under pressure to take on British rival and IBF welterweight champion Kell Brook in June, but Khan stated he was already in negotiations to fight someone else.

The Israeli National Insurance Institute will remove the name of Mohammed Abu Khdeir, a Palestinian teenager who was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis, from a memorial wall commemorating fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism. Abu Khdeir's father and the organization Almagor, which works on behalf of victims of terrorism, objected to his inclusion on the memorial wall. Almagor described Abu Khdeir's death as a rogue attack and not a terror victim. The organization demanded that Abu Khdeir's name be removed from the memorial wall, and if it is not, members of Almagor want their own family members' names removed. The National Insurance Institute of Israel will remove Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial following his father's complaints.

The passage describes a humorous interaction between a young boy and the family cat, as filmed by the boy's father, Lionel Hutz. The boy repeatedly attempts to use the cat as a pillow, following the feline around the garden as it tries to find a new spot to rest. Despite the boy's persistence, the cat eventually grows tired of being used as a pillow and wanders off indoors. However, the pair later reconcile, with the boy seen feeding the cat treats.

Robert Kushner, a witness in a police corruption trial in Philadelphia, lost his job as a varsity basketball coach at the Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past as a marijuana dealer. Kushner, who had passed a background check when hired in 2010, testified that some of the officers on trial had stolen $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. The school was unaware of this history. Kushner's 2007 charges were expunged, but he was arrested again in 2011 and pleaded guilty to a DUI in 2008. Despite his past, he expressed remorse and stated his commitment to the well-being of the children he coached.

An explosion at a controversial chemical plant in China's southeastern Fujian province sparked a huge fire, injuring six people. The plant, located in Zhangzhou city, produces paraxylene (PX), a reportedly carcinogenic chemical used in the production of polyester films and fabrics. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility Monday night after an oil leak, though local media has not reported any toxic chemical spill. Five out of six people were injured by broken glass and have been sent to the hospital for treatment. More than 600 firefighters were sent to battle the blaze, and the fire is now under control. Residents living close to the plant heard the explosion and took to Weibo to post photos of the fire. The plant was hit by another explosion in July 2013, although there were no reports of casualties or toxic leaks at the time. The construction of PX plants has sparked protests, which have occasionally turned violent, in several cities in recent years. The Zhangzhou plant was slated for Xiamen, but it provoked an angry backlash in 2007 due to pollution concerns and prompted the local government to relocate the factory to its current, more remote location.

Jack Grealish, the Aston Villa teenager, is known for wearing his socks low, just above his shin pads. Despite referees' attempts to get him to pull his socks up, Grealish insists on keeping them that way due to superstition. He wears children's shin pads and hasn't had a kick on his shin yet. Grealish made his first Premier League start in a tough game against QPR, and while he wasn't happy with the result, he was pleased to have finally made his debut and hopes to get more starts before the end of the season.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has "global and irreversible brain damage," according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston.
