Though she is no longer in a medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive. She does not respond to visitors or familiar voices, and her eyes do not follow a person around the room. She also has a tracheostomy in her throat. Bobby Brown said his daughter's condition had improved, and she had made it out of ICU, opened her eyes, and started rehabilitation.

Russia is on the verge of reaching the Fed Cup final with a 2-0 lead over Germany. Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to defeat Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3, while Svetlana Kuznetsova beat Julia Goerges in straight sets. Both players struggled with their serves, with Pavlyuchenkova committing 13 double faults and Lisicki making 63 unforced errors. The result leaves Russia needing one win from Sunday's three matches to reach the final and secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales, still recovering from last week's wild weather, are being warned to prepare for more floods and damage as another storm is expected to hit later this week. Meteorologists predict that an east coast low, similar to the one that caused widespread damage last week, could bring heavy rain from Thursday. The State Emergency Service (SES), which is still dealing with over 4,000 outstanding jobs from last week's storm, is concerned that further wild weather will hamper clean-up efforts. The SES is particularly worried about the impact on the Hunter Region, which was hit hard by flooding and high winds last week. Residents are being urged to prepare their homes and families to prevent further loss and devastation.

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in the video for Ricky Martin's hit song "La Vida Loca," has denied claims that she attempted to take her own life. Italian media reported that Moric was found by her mother in her Milan apartment after an alleged suicide attempt. However, Moric took to Instagram to clarify that she collapsed due to low blood pressure and was treated in the hospital for her injuries. She reassured her fans that she is recovering at home and only needs rest. Moric also addressed past reports of a suicide attempt in 2009, stating that the claims were not entirely correct. She was previously married to paparazzi photographer Fabrizio Corona, who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities with compromising photographs.

The British public is eagerly awaiting the arrival of Kate and William's second child, with many hoping for a baby princess. A recent YouGov survey for The Sunday Times revealed that the most popular name choice for a girl is Diana, in honor of William's late mother, the Princess of Wales. Alice and Charlotte are also popular choices. If the baby is a boy, James and Alexander are the top picks. Social media users have expressed their support for naming the baby Diana, with many stating that they would be emotional if the name is chosen. Additionally, the poll showed that 68% of Brits support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber attacked a group of protesters in eastern Afghanistan, killing 17 people and injuring 64 others, including an Afghan lawmaker. The attack occurred around 10 a.m. local time as the group was on their way to join a larger rally against the provincial governor. The Taliban has denied responsibility for the attack, and no other organization has claimed responsibility.

Dani Alves, the Brazilian right-back, is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. Alves has enjoyed seven successful years at Barcelona, winning four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice. However, the 31-year-old has been unable to agree on a new deal with the Catalan club. His agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that Alves had rejected the offer of a three-year contract extension, which was dependent on the player taking part in 60 percent of matches for the club. Santana stated that the negotiations are over and that it doesn't make sense for Barcelona to wait until April to think about renewing Alves' contract.

Pablo Osvaldo, currently on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has expressed his desire for Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentinian club. Osvaldo believes that the duo's South American style of play would make them a perfect fit for Boca and that the fans at La Bombonera would love to see them play. Osvaldo has described Pirlo and Totti as two of the best players he has played with and would love to have them join him at Boca.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, experienced a spectacular double somersault fall from his horse, Merrion Square, during a race at Wincanton. Despite the dramatic nature of the fall, Ferguson only suffered a cut on his nose and was back to work at Paul Nicholls's yard the next day. The incident, which was captured on video and widely shared online, has made Ferguson an internet sensation. He has received some good-natured ribbing from his fellow jockeys and gained a few hundred new Twitter followers. Ferguson remains undeterred and is eager to get back in the saddle, even joking about a potential gymnastics career in the future.

The passage discusses James Haskell's Instagram post where he dressed as Iron Man to promote the new Avengers: Age of Ultron movie. It also highlights his rugby career, including his return to the London Wasps in 2012 after playing for clubs in France, Japan, and New Zealand. Haskell has since surpassed 100 appearances for the Wasps and has become a key player for the England squad.

The wide-leg trouser is a prominent trend for SS15, offering a refreshing alternative to the skinny jean. Designers like Gucci, Celine, and Stella McCartney have showcased various styles, from denim flares to dressy pants. To pull off this look, high heels and a simple top are recommended to elongate the legs and maintain proportion. Denim is an easy way to embrace the trend, with options available from both high-end and high-street brands.

The University of Michigan has decided to proceed with a screening of the film "American Sniper" despite objections from some students. More than 200 students signed a petition asking the school not to show the movie as part of UMix, a series of social events the university stages for students. Bradley Cooper was nominated for an Oscar for his portrayal of Chris Kyle, a Navy SEAL and the most lethal sniper in U.S. military history. Kyle was fatally shot at a Texas shooting range in 2013. Some students believed the movie's depiction of the Iraq War reflected negatively on the Middle East and people from that region. Michigan's Detroit metropolitan area is home to the nation's largest Arab-American population. But there was a backlash to the decision to yank the movie, and a counter-petition asked school officials to reconsider. On Wednesday, E. Royster Harper, the University of Michigan's vice president for student life, said in a statement that "it was a mistake to cancel the showing of the movie 'American Sniper' on campus as part of a social event for students" and that the show will go on. "The initial decision to cancel the movie was not consistent with the high value the University of Michigan places on freedom of expression and our respect for the right of students to make their own choices in such matters," the statement said. UMix will offer a screening of the family-friendly "Paddington" for those who would rather not attend "American Sniper." The announcement drew praise from Michigan head football coach Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists, aged 18 and 24, were charged with animal cruelty after allegedly igniting an aerosol spray with a lighter, causing a flame to make contact with a quokka on Rottnest Island off Perth in Western Australia on April 3. The quokka, a small animal found on some small islands off the west Australian coast, survived the incident but was singed by the flame. The two men were evicted from the island and will appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old former dancer, was able to see herself dancing for the first time thanks to the efforts of Mark Cantor of jazz-on-film.com and some volunteers. Barker, who performed in New York nightspots such as the Cotton Club and the Cafe Zanzibar in the 1930s and 1940s, had never seen any of the motion pictures made of her performances. Her photographs and memorabilia had also been lost over the years. The video of "soundies" was shown to her at the nursing home where she lives, and she was delighted, saying, "It's just fabulous."

The art of washing your own car appears to be dying out in Britain, with a third of men admitting they have never picked up a bucket or chamois leather to clean their own motor. The study also reveals that three-quarters of women never wash their own car, with drivers more likely to take it to a car wash on a local forecourt. The survey of 1,100 adults by vehicle leasing firm OSV found that 31% of men have never washed their own car, with only 12% of those that do saying they do it regularly. Meanwhile, only 5% of those surveyed said they had ever asked their children to wash the car as a way for them to earn extra pocket money.

Factors behind the decline vary from shops now opening on a Sunday and more live football on TV, meaning more people put off the chore at the weekend. The rise of hand car washes has been blamed for a decrease in drivers washing their own cars. Other reasons given for not washing cars include the fact that 4x4 and off-road vehicles are too large to clean. Brits are more likely to wash their own car during the holidays, as the recent Easter break saw an estimated 15 million cars cleaned by their owners. However, one in four said they only did it as an excuse to get out of the house.

Cars are most likely to be washed by their owners every week in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield and least likely in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh. Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs are most likely to be washed by their owners, while Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes are least often. OSV spokesman Andrew Kirkley said, "A lot of us remember seeing our streets full of men cleaning their cars every Sunday. It was a national tradition. But let's face it, we don't have as much time anymore, the cars are bigger, and even the kids don't seem to want to earn a bit of extra money doing it for us either. On top of that, there is now plenty of choice out there if you want to put the car through an automated machine or get a gang of enthusiastic guys to do it for you fairly cheaply."

Martin Skrtel has praised the impact Steven Gerrard has had on him since arriving at Anfield in 2008. Skrtel believes Liverpool can overcome the difficult challenge of replacing Gerrard, who is set to feature for Liverpool in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley on Sunday. Should Liverpool emerge victorious, Gerrard will sign off his Anfield career in the final, which takes place on his birthday of May 30, before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel believes Gerrard is synonymous with Liverpool and that the midfielder is still one of the game's leading stars. Skrtel was signed by Rafael Benitez from Zenit St Petersburg seven years ago and despite some indifferent form upon arriving in England, the Slovakia international has gone on to become a mainstay in Liverpool's defense. Skrtel revealed that Gerrard helped him to settle at the beginning of his time at the club. While Skrtel admits Liverpool will be a different side without Gerrard, he believes the club has potential replacements for the iconic No. 8. Both Gerrard and Skrtel could return to the Liverpool line-up for the match against Villa after both served three-match bans for violent conduct in the 2-1 defeat to Manchester United in March.

Jack Nicklaus, at 75 years old, hit a hole-in-one on the 130-yard fourth hole during the par-3 contest at Augusta National. This was his first ace on the famed course. The crowd cheered as he achieved this feat alongside golf legends Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. Despite his remarkable shot, Nicklaus's achievement was overshadowed by Camilo Villegas, who also hit two holes-in-one but lost in a playoff to Kevin Streelman. Nicklaus, a six-time Masters champion and the youngest to wear the green jacket in 1963, remains one of five men to complete the career grand slam.

Tornado sirens blared in Kansas on Wednesday night as several storms brought reports of twisters. Spotters reported a tornado about 6 miles northwest of Goddard, which is less than 17 miles west of Wichita. That storm moved to the northeast, missing the city but posing potential risks to other communities. Other reports of tornadoes came in from southwestern Kansas. Kansas wasn't the only state affected by the storms, as the National Weather Service indicated a tornado may have touched down in the small town of Potosi, Missouri. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

A reserve sheriff's deputy in Oklahoma, Robert Bates, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter after fatally shooting Eric Harris during a weapons sting operation. Bates claims he meant to subdue Harris with a Taser but mistakenly used his gun instead. The judge granted Bates permission to go on a family vacation to the Bahamas, which Harris' family criticized as showing apathy towards the shooting. Bates' lawyer released his training documents, which they say prove he had proper law enforcement training. Two deputies involved in Harris' arrest have been reassigned due to threats against them and their families.

Conor McGregor, the 26-year-old Irish MMA fighter, is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11 in Las Vegas. McGregor, known as "The Notorious," recently revealed a new tattoo of a tiger's face on his stomach, adding to his existing chest tattoo of a gorilla eating a heart. McGregor, who grabbed Aldo's belt during a promotional tour in Dublin, claims he has greater motivation to win the title than Aldo has to defend it for the eighth time. The pair have a fractious relationship, with McGregor asserting that Aldo lacks the same drive and desire for the belt.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott skolled a schooner of beer at an Australian rules function, drawing criticism from anti-drinking campaigners. Cultural studies professor Julie Robert said it was "problematic" that Abbott, as Prime Minister, thought it acceptable to "showcase his masculinity" by skolling a beer, setting up a culture that drinking is about how quickly and how much you can drink, rather than socializing with friends. Abbott's actions were defended by Health Minister Sussan Ley, who said there was "nothing wrong" with the Prime Minister's antics and that he works hard to keep fit.

Indiana has seen a significant increase in HIV cases, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases tied to Scott County, primarily involving intravenous drug users using the high-powered painkiller Opana. The outbreak has prompted a 30-day needle exchange program, which has provided 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants and collected about 1,400 used syringes. Health officials and lawmakers are debating whether to extend the program and implement similar programs in other counties, despite concerns about promoting drug use and the lack of public funding for such programs.

An Arsenal fan made his girlfriend take a test on the football club, threatening to break up with her if she failed. The test included multiple-choice questions, tables to complete, and a section for her to explain why Alexis Sanchez is better than Eden Hazard. She scored 43.5 out of 50, earning an "A" grade and avoiding a breakup. The boyfriend marked her answers with red pen and provided feedback, including the need to "learn all player positions" and understand that "Tottenham are scum." The test covered topics such as Arsenal's top goalscorers, the scoreline for the 2014 FA Cup final, and why Arsenal is the best team in English football. The girlfriend's answers, including calling Eden Hazard a "p***k" and praising Thierry Henry as a legend, impressed football fans on Twitter, with some calling her "proper gf material." However, some users thought the boyfriend took things too far.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former member of the Medellin cartel, faces deportation after 27 years of undercover work for the DEA. Toro, who came to the U.S. fleeing death threats in Colombia, provided crucial information leading to the prosecution of major figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite promises of U.S. citizenship, Toro remains without legal status, his final visa expiring on January 1. The DEA has not supported his citizenship efforts, even after he went public. A former DEA agent and colleague have supported Toro, highlighting his significant contributions and the unfairness of his situation. Toro, in poor health and fearing for his life if deported, is prepared to go into hiding while continuing his fight for a green card or passport.

A 14-year-old girl in Uttar Pradesh, India, set herself on fire after allegedly being gang-raped by five men from her village. The incident occurred when she went outside her house to relieve herself. She is now in critical condition at Safdarjung Hospital in Delhi with 70% burns. The accused men have been arrested. This incident follows heightened sensitivity in India to sexual assault, particularly after the gang rape and murder of a student in Delhi, which led to widespread protests and international outrage.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal is eager to secure a victory against rivals Manchester City in Sunday's derby at Old Trafford, aiming to strengthen their position in the Premier League table. However, he will have to do so without Robin van Persie, who has been ruled out due to insufficient fitness. Van Gaal emphasized the importance of controlling aggression in such high-stakes matches and expressed his hope that the team has learned from their previous loss to City. Despite the challenge posed by City, van Gaal remains optimistic about securing a top-four finish and potentially achieving a higher position in the table. He also praised the support of the Manchester United fans and highlighted their positive impact on the team.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested against high ticket prices by leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium. The protest followed the announcement of the Premier League's £5.14 billion TV rights deal. Fans from both clubs expressed disgust at the rising costs, with tickets starting at £64 for the 12.45 pm kick-off. Banners inside and outside the stadium highlighted the issue, with one reading, "£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket." The organizers, including Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly, called for tangible reductions in ticket prices, warning that the rising costs could alienate a generation of fans. Further protests were expected after the match.

A newborn baby named Star Reader, diagnosed with biliary atresia, was saved after receiving a liver transplant from her maternal aunt, Shanell Reader. Star's parents, Jade Reader and Matthew Bygrave, noticed her yellowish skin shortly after birth, which persisted for weeks. Tests revealed blocked bile ducts, a life-threatening condition. Neither parent was a suitable match for the transplant, but Shanell, Jade's twin sister, was an ideal candidate and willingly donated part of her liver. The operation took place in November, and both Star and Shanell have since made good recoveries. Star will require ongoing medical care and anti-rejection medication for the rest of her life.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Aké, Loïc Rémy, and Willian participated in Audi's football challenge. In the first round, Hazard and Aké scored 5-3 against Rémy and Willian by firing balls into a car's boot. The second round, played on a makeshift tennis court with an Audi R8 V10 Plus as the net, was also won by Hazard and Aké with a 6-0 lead. The final round involved long-range shots at convertible Audis, with Rémy and Willian winning despite Willian accidentally smashing a wing mirror.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive, is being sentenced for causing a highway crash in December 2013 that killed a Vermont couple, Jason Timmons and Amanda Murphy, who was eight months pregnant. Dellinger initially claimed he was attempting suicide by driving his pickup truck across a median at over 100 mph, but during his sentencing, he stated he was not suicidal. His wife, Deborah, described him as a man of integrity and ethics, and expressed their devastation over the deaths. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and faces 12 to 24 years in prison. His lawyers attribute his actions to Ambien withdrawal, a psychiatric drug overdose, and advanced symptoms of multiple sclerosis. The prosecution argues he was depressed and loopy from medication. The crash caused injuries so severe that the medical examiner compared them to plane crash injuries.

Lacey Spears of Scottsville, Kentucky, was convicted of second-degree murder in the death of her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, by poisoning him with salt. She was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison, showing no emotion during the sentencing. The boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed his hope on Facebook that she would die in prison, calling her a "crazy woman" and criticizing her lack of emotion. Prosecutors argued that Spears made her son ill for attention, while her lawyer plans to appeal, blaming the hospital for negligence. The judge acknowledged Spears' mental illness but described the crime as "unfathomable in its cruelty."

The Australian influenza vaccine will arrive a month later than expected due to the inclusion of protection against two new strains, H3N2 and B/Phuket, which caused a spike in deaths in Europe and the US. High-risk groups, such as the very young, very old, and most Indigenous Australians, will be able to access free, government-funded flu shots from April 20. Experts recommend that everyone should get vaccinated, as the modified version of the vaccine is a good match for the strains circulating globally and can help prevent more deaths.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb in Springfield, Illinois, are defending the site against criticism in National Geographic magazine and potential budget cuts. The tomb, managed by the state historic preservation agency, faces possible restructuring under Governor Bruce Rauner's proposed budget cuts. Critics, including historian Adam Goodheart, have described the tomb as unimpressive and lacking historical character. Despite these critiques, the tomb has undergone over $2.5 million in recent renovations, including interior plaster and paint, bronze and marble construction, and lighting upgrades. Visitors, such as William Sparks, have expressed admiration for the site, contradicting the negative portrayal in the magazine.

Nineties and noughties fashion trends are making a comeback, with some styles being embraced and others being met with horror. Popular trends include chokers, berry-colored lips, round sunglasses, Calvin Klein logo t-shirts, and JNCO's wide-leg "rave" jeans. Some of the worst offenders include bucket hats, camouflage print, double denim, UGG boots, Daisy Dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outfits, and harem trousers. These trends, once popular among celebrities and fashion icons, are now being revisited by a new generation, with mixed reactions from fashion enthusiasts.

This week's trending stories included a rare sighting of four rainbows in the New York area, captured by Amanda Curtis. In China, the practice of hiring exotic dancers for wakes is now being targeted in a government crackdown on vice. Robert Downey Jr. showed frustration during an interview where his private life was probed. A controversial prom-posal referencing bombs led to accusations of racism by the student involved. Social media buzzed about Ewan McGregor's casting as Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast" and Johnny Depp's transformation in the "Black Mass" trailer. Additionally, creative pregnancy announcements and a military dad's photobomb added lighter moments to the week.

The Miami Open has become a celebration of milestones, with Serena Williams receiving a giant cake to mark her 700th career victory, following Andy Murray's 500th win. Williams advanced to the semi-finals by defeating Sabine Lisicki in a three-set match, avenging her Wimbledon 2013 loss. Her sister Venus was eliminated by Carla Suarez Navarro. Williams will face Simona Halep in the semi-finals, who defeated Sloane Stephens.

Sabeen Mahmud, a prominent advocate for free speech, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship, was shot dead in Karachi, Pakistan, after hosting a discussion on the sensitive topic of forced disappearances in Baluchistan. Known for her vibrant personality and progressive values, Mahmud's cafe, T2F, served as a hub for free thought and artistic expression. Her fearless advocacy made her a national figurehead for humanism, love, and tolerance. Despite receiving death threats, she continued to champion open dialogue, even on controversial issues. Her death has sparked widespread grief and admiration for her courage and commitment to justice and liberty.

The passage discusses the plight of West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) in Indian Kashmir, focusing on their long-standing struggle for citizenship rights. Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu refugee who fled to Kashmir during the partition of India in 1947, exemplifies the challenges faced by these refugees. Despite living in India for decades, WPRs are denied basic rights such as property ownership and voting in state elections, leaving them in abject poverty. The situation stems from fears of upsetting the demographic balance in India's only Muslim-majority state. However, there is hope for change with the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), a Hindu nationalist party, now sharing power in the state. Activists like Labha Ram Gandhi are advocating for state-subject rights for WPRs, warning of potential unrest if their demands are not met. The passage also highlights the broader context of unrest in Kashmir, including recent militant attacks, and the ongoing conflict over the region's status.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a potential move to Premier League leaders Chelsea, who have reportedly made a £4 million offer for the Japan international. Muto, who is keen to join a club where he can play regularly and realize his potential, is taking his time to carefully consider his options. FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane has claimed that Chelsea has made an offer for Muto, and Chelsea boss Jose Mourinho has admitted that he is aware of the player. Muto's former coach, Ranko Popovic, has praised his potential and believes he could be a big hit at Stamford Bridge. Mourinho has also acknowledged the importance of financial considerations in the club's transfer policy.

Australia has made a sensible decision by allowing their best players, regardless of where they play, to be selected for the national team. This leaves England looking outdated, and Stuart Lancaster should have the freedom to choose his best players, no matter their location. The policy of not selecting overseas players is being challenged, with examples like Matt Giteau and Steffon Armitage excelling abroad. The focus should be on fielding the best team for the World Cup, and England's chances would be enhanced by including top players from overseas clubs.

Open Garden has developed a small device called Greenstone, designed to enhance the functionality of wireless mesh networks. This egg-shaped gadget acts as a beacon or booster, facilitating the movement of messages within these networks. It builds upon the success of Open Garden's FireChat app, which allows users to communicate without the need for an internet connection or mobile signal. FireChat utilizes a feature introduced in Apple's iOS 7 called the Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF), which enables the creation of wireless mesh networks. These networks connect devices directly via Bluetooth or Wi-Fi Direct, allowing for message and photo sharing even without a traditional signal. Greenstone is intended to extend the range of these networks, which is typically limited to about 200 feet (61 meters). The device can hold up to 1,000 recent messages and has a battery life of one year. It is envisioned for use in various scenarios, including music festivals, protests, and hospitals, where traditional connectivity might be unavailable or overwhelmed.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer from New Jersey, is challenging the negative connotations associated with the word "fat" by embracing it as a neutral, body-positive descriptor of her own physique. During her TED Talk, Bustle explained that she views "fat" as just another self-descriptor, similar to calling herself "short" or "wife," and that it doesn't have to be used as a synonym for "ugly." She highlighted the prevalence of size discrimination in the workplace and the negative perceptions of bigger people, especially among young girls. Bustle also cited studies showing that exposure to body diversity can lead to greater acceptance and even preference for different body types. She uses her burlesque performances to expose audiences to a "fat" body in a positive, glamorous way, aiming to change perceptions and promote body diversity. Despite some negative comments, Bustle has received overwhelmingly positive feedback, including messages of thanks and personal stories from viewers who have reevaluated their own body image.

Theo Walcott, along with six of his Arsenal teammates, participated in a photoshoot for Lanvin, the club's official tailor since 2013. The photoshoot featured Walcott, Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, Mesut Ozil, and runway model Olga Sherer. Walcott, who has been named on Arsenal's substitutes' bench for 17 of their 33 Barclays Premier League games, came on for the last six minutes of his side's goalless draw with Chelsea on Sunday. The 26-year-old will be hoping to make his first Arsenal start since his side's 3-0 win over West Ham on March 14 when the Gunners face Hull at the KC Stadium on Monday.

Fans of blockbuster films such as Men in Black, Batman Forever, and How the Grinch Stole Christmas will have the opportunity to own a piece of Hollywood history when a collection of props and puppets created by legendary makeup effects artist Rick Baker goes up for auction. The collection, which includes over 400 items from more than 50 productions, will be auctioned off at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles, California, and on propstore.com on May 29. The collection is estimated to be worth $746,100, with some individual items expected to fetch more than $40,000. The auction presents a unique opportunity for collectors and fans to own some of the brilliant creations from their favorite films.

Carwyn Scott-Howell, a seven-year-old British boy, died while skiing with his family in the French Alps. He became separated from his mother and headed into dense woodland, where he fell over a 164-foot drop. His body was found by police following footprints in the snow. Carwyn was described as a competent skier and snowboarder who had started skiing at the age of three. His family described him as a lively, likeable pupil who will be greatly missed. The community is rallying behind the Scott-Howells, who are well known for their award-winning farm shop.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia after becoming obsessed with achieving a "size zero" figure. Her weight loss led to a collapse and hospitalization, where she was put on a heart monitor. Laura's recovery involved support from eating disorder organizations and mental health services. She has since made it to the semi-finals of Miss Teen GB, a competition that promotes positive body image and confidence, moving away from size zero stereotypes.

Liverpool fans made it clear to Raheem Sterling that they expect him to stay at the club during the unveiling of the new home kit at Anfield. The kit, designed by New Balance as part of a £300 million four-year deal, features a gingham design and pays tribute to the Hillsborough disaster with the memorial flame and number 96. Sterling, who recently rejected a £100,000-a-week contract, was joined by teammates Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet at the launch. Despite speculation about his future, Liverpool is determined to keep Sterling, whose contract has two years remaining. The players also expressed their excitement about the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa.

The largest high-definition map of dark matter has been produced, covering 0.4% of the sky and showing clumps of dark matter as red and sparse regions as blue. The map was created using data from the Dark Energy Camera on the Victor M. Blanco Telescope in Chile, as part of the five-year Dark Energy Survey. The goal is to eventually map 12.5% of the sky over five years, creating a 3D map of dark matter and dark energy. The map will allow astronomers to study how galaxies formed and test current cosmological theories by comparing the amounts of dark and visible matter. The survey has just completed its second year, and as scientists expand their search, they will be able to better test current cosmological theories.

Manchester United have made an official approach for PSV Eindhoven star Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal keen to make him one of his first signings this summer. Depay, who worked under van Gaal during Holland's successful 2014 World Cup campaign, has been in prolific form this season, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games. PSV's technical director Marcel Brands confirmed that there has been contact with Manchester United, Paris Saint-Germain, and a third big European club, with bigger amounts of money being discussed this time. Depay, who started his career at VV Moordrecht before joining PSV at the age of 12, is known for his pacy, close control, and ability to run at defenders. He has been tipped to become as good as Dutch star Arjen Robben by PSV manager Phillip Cocu, and has been described as better than a young Cristiano Ronaldo by Ed van Steijn, the man who scouted Ronaldo for Manchester United.

Chelsea's young team secured a commanding 3-1 lead in the first leg of the Youth Cup final against Manchester City, with Tammy Abraham scoring twice and Dominic Solanke adding a late goal. Despite a strong performance from City's Brandon Barker, Chelsea's defense, led by Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter, effectively neutralized City's attack. City's Kean Bryan and Aaron Nemane had chances but couldn't convert, leaving Chelsea in a strong position heading into the second leg.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate, stated that he believes people are born with a sexual preference but does not think same-sex marriage is a constitutional right. He believes that states should decide on the definition of marriage and that courts should not make that decision. Rubio also mentioned that he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, even if he disagreed with the decision, out of respect and love for them. Additionally, he stated that, as a Catholic, he believes divorce is wrong but would not stop loving someone if they were divorced.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a couple from Manchester, have embarked on an open-ended cycling journey around the world with no specific plans or agenda. Their goal is to explore different parts of the planet at their own pace. In their first year, they covered nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries, living on less than three euros each per day. They rely on free accommodation, camping, and hosting websites, with food being their primary expense. Their diet includes simple, affordable foods, and they occasionally receive free meals or forage for wild fruits. The couple documents their journey on their blog, thecrazytravel, and plans to continue into Asia and across the Pacific, aiming to cycle the length of the American continent.

A couple from Texas who celebrated their wedding in 2012 is suing their wedding photographer, James Evans, for allegedly printing racial slurs on the bottom of photo booth snapshots from the event. The couple claims that the photographer did not apologize and instead told them to "sue" him. The couple's lawyer, Cathy Hale, says that the couple wants an apology at the very least and that it is not about money. The case is set for trial in July if mediation does not result in an agreement.

Mike Brown, England's full-back, is adopting a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion setback. He is unsure when he will return to action for his club, Harlequins, after pulling out of their match against Saracens. Brown emphasizes the importance of being aware of concussion symptoms and not rushing back to action. He mentions that he would advise teammates to do the same if they show symptoms. Brown also highlights the significance of the online modules provided by World Rugby in increasing awareness of the dangers of concussion.

The frequency of sexual activity among British couples has been declining since the emergence of the internet. According to research published in Professor David Spiegelhalter's book Sex by Numbers, a typical heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, compared to four times a month in 2000 and five times a month in 1990. Possible factors for the decline include more people living alone and the erosion of boundaries between home, work, and the outside world due to increased technological connectivity. This has resulted in less quiet, empty time and more competing demands on people's time, causing sex to fall lower on the list of priorities.

The Tibetan mastiff, once a highly sought-after status symbol in China, has seen a dramatic decline in popularity. Previously commanding prices of up to £1.2 million, the breed is now being sent to slaughterhouses, with their meat used in cheap hotpots and their skin for leather belts. This decline is attributed to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which has made it less common to give the dogs as gifts to officials. Additionally, bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several cities have impacted their popularity. The breed's boom began in 2005, but unscrupulous breeding practices have led to a glut of poor-quality dogs. The rapid urbanization of China has also made the breed less suited to city living. Recently, animal welfare workers rescued a group of 20 mastiffs being transported to a slaughterhouse, highlighting the cruel fate many of these dogs are now facing.

The survey of 600 women in Paris revealed that every woman had experienced some form of sexual harassment on public transport, with half of them being harassed before the age of 18. The harassment ranged from insults to sex attacks or rape, and it often went unreported. This led to women altering their daily lives to avoid confrontation, limiting their freedom and excluding them from the public arena. The survey also found that six out of ten women were afraid of being attacked on public transport, compared to three out of ten men. The report called for a campaign to stem sexist or threatening behavior on buses and trains, emphasizing the need for women to be able to move about and occupy public space without being threatened.

Leeds-based Direct Line organized a competition called #EverydayFix, where groups designed products to address common problems. The top ten everyday emergencies identified in a survey of 2,000 people included not being able to sleep, losing keys, and running out of phone battery. Three prototypes were shortlisted: "Snooze," an alarm clock that silences phone notifications for better sleep; "Forget Me Lock," a device that confirms if you've locked your door; and "Nipper," the world's smallest mobile phone charger that uses household batteries. The public can vote for their favorite on Twitter, and the winning product will be developed through a Kickstarter campaign.

Vera Baird, the Police and Crime Commissioner for Northumbria, is facing a Ministry of Justice investigation after allocating over £500,000 of public funds to a charity she runs alongside the force's Chief Constable, Sue Sim. Critics have accused them of creating a conflict of interest and a "soap opera" within the force. The funds were allocated after the Home Secretary devolved funding for victims' services to PCCs. Baird defended her decision, stating that all procedures and protocols were followed. Sim, who previously faced bullying allegations, has announced her retirement. The Ministry of Justice will investigate whether any conflict of interest rules were broken.

Three individuals have been imprisoned, and two others are awaiting sentencing for their involvement in a brutal assault on a 53-year-old man, Greg Valecce, in Mayfair, Philadelphia. The ringleader, Corry 'Corey' Campbell, 21, believed Valecce had injured his cat, Pebbles, and stolen money and drugs. Over three days in March 2014, Campbell, along with his girlfriend Sandra Ng, 19, and friend Carl Halin, 18, subjected Valecce to severe physical abuse, including punching, slapping, and spitting, while filming the ordeal. Valecce was then tied to a chair and tattooed with offensive images and phrases by Campbell and Halin. Valecce managed to escape and contact the police. The attackers were charged with aggravated assault, conspiracy, and false imprisonment. Campbell and Halin each received 20-year prison sentences, while Ng was sentenced to 23 months. Two other defendants, David Thomas and Jennifer Pratt, are awaiting sentencing and trial, respectively.

Manchester United have made an official approach for PSV Eindhoven star Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal keen to make him one of his first signings this summer. Depay, who worked under van Gaal during Holland's successful 2014 World Cup campaign, has been in prolific form this season, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games. PSV's technical director Marcel Brands confirmed that there has been contact with Manchester United, Paris Saint-Germain, and a third big European club, with bigger amounts of money being discussed. Depay, who was born in 1994, started his career at VV Moordrecht before joining Sparta Rotterdam and then PSV. He made his first-team debut in September 2011 and has already made over 100 appearances for the Dutch giants. Depay is known for his pace, close control, and ability to run at defenders, and has been tipped to become as good as Arjen Robben by PSV manager Phillip Cocu.

Chelsea's young team secured a commanding 3-1 lead in the first leg of the Youth Cup final against Manchester City, with Tammy Abraham scoring twice and Dominic Solanke adding a late goal. Despite a strong performance from City's defense, including notable efforts from Tosin Adarabioyo and Pablo Maffeo, Chelsea's attack, led by Abraham and Solanke, proved too potent. City's Isaac Buckley-Ricketts managed to level the score briefly, but Chelsea's overall dominance, particularly in midfield, ensured they took a significant step towards lifting the trophy.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate, stated that he believes people are born with a sexual preference but does not think same-sex marriage is a constitutional right. He believes that states should decide on the definition of marriage and that courts should not make that decision. Rubio also mentioned that he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, even if he disagreed with the decision, out of respect and love for them. Additionally, he stated that, as a Catholic, he believes divorce is wrong but would not stop loving someone if they were divorced.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a couple from Manchester, have embarked on an open-ended cycling journey around the world with no specific plans or agenda. Their goal is to explore different parts of the planet at their own pace. In their first year, they covered nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries, living on less than three euros each per day. They rely on free accommodation, camping, and hosting websites, with food being their main expense. Their diet includes simple foods like pasta, bread, and seasonal fruits, often supplemented by the kindness of strangers. They document their journey on their blog, thecrazytravel, and plan to continue into Asia and across the Pacific to cycle the length of the American continent.

Mike Brown, England's full-back, is adopting a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion setback. He is unsure when he will return to action for his club, Harlequins, after pulling out of their match against Saracens. Brown emphasizes the importance of being aware of concussion symptoms and not rushing back to action. He mentions that increased awareness, driven by players undergoing World Rugby online modules, helped him realize he would not be ready to face Ireland. Brown also stresses the importance of being honest about symptoms and the potential long-term dangers of concussions.

The frequency of sexual activity among British couples has been declining since the emergence of the internet. According to Professor David Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University, a typical heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, compared to four times a month in 2000 and five times a month in 1990. Spiegelhalter suggests that the erosion of boundaries between home, work, and the outside world, due to increased technological connectivity, has squeezed out time that would have been spent with partners. Additionally, dealing with work emails late in the evening can leave individuals too connected to focus on their partners at bedtime.

The Tibetan mastiff, once a highly sought-after status symbol in China, has seen a dramatic decline in popularity. Previously commanding prices of up to £1.2 million, the breed is now being sent to slaughterhouses, with their meat used in cheap hotpots and their skin turned into leather belts. This decline is attributed to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which has made it less common for wealthy individuals to gift these dogs to officials. Additionally, bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several cities have impacted the breed's popularity. The market collapse has also been exacerbated by unscrupulous breeding practices and the breed's unsuitability for urban living. Animal welfare workers recently rescued a group of mastiffs found in cramped cages on their way to a slaughterhouse, highlighting the cruel fate many of these dogs now face.

Leeds-based Direct Line organized a competition called #EverydayFix, inviting groups to design products addressing common problems. The top ten everyday emergencies identified in a survey of 2,000 people included not being able to sleep, losing keys, and running out of phone battery. Three prototypes were shortlisted: "Snooze," an alarm clock that silences phone notifications for better sleep; "Forget Me Lock," a device that confirms if a door is locked; and "Nipper," the world's smallest mobile phone charger, which uses household batteries. The public can vote for their favorite on Twitter, and the winning product will be developed through a Kickstarter campaign. Other innovative ideas that didn't make the cut included a smart helmet for cyclists and a parking pin to alert users when a parking space becomes available.
